Full text: - Olaf Scholz of the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD) governs as chancellor at the head of the country's first three-party federal coalition, with the liberal Free Democratic Party (FDP) and The Greens. Germany has a strongly centrist and consensus-based political culture, and EIU expects the coalition to serve its full term, to October 2025. Policymaking has tended towards unwieldy compromises to satisfy the various coalition partners. As these parties have seen their support erode, and experienced disappointments at state elections, they have become less amenable to compromise. This means that frictions and divisions will increase in 2023-25. Progress on improving Germany's defence capabilities has picked up since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, but remains slow.

Germany--highlights: Business environment outlook

- Germany's score in EIU's business environment model rises from 8.14 in the historical period (2018-22) to 8.25 in the forecast period (2023-27). The country climbs three places to eighth in the global ranking, and ranks fourth among its 17 regional peers, behind Denmark, Switzerland and Sweden. We expect gradual reform-led improvements in infrastructure, technological readiness and financing, but rising protectionism globally will result in a hardening of policy towards foreign investment. Germany's main strengths are its skilled labour force, stable political culture, openness to foreign trade and investment, and research and innovation framework. Weaknesses include the tax regime, which places a heavy burden on labour income, and the worsening demographic outlook, which implies that skilled labour shortages will become more common.

- Depressed private consumption and investment spending will cause economic growth to stall this year, as real wages stagnate, still-high inflation constrains household spending, and high interest rates raise the cost of borrowing and put pressure on profit margins. Demand from the EU and the US will be lacklustre, but exports to China will strengthen as that economy experiences a post-pandemic economic bounce-back. Backlogs of work will support German industrial sector growth as global supply-chain frictions ease, and economic activity will normalise from 2024. However, Germany's poor demographic outlook will increasingly constrain growth, and technological disruption in the automotive sector represents a structural risk.

- The pandemic in 2020-21 resulted in a higher death rate, lower net immigration and slightly fewer births than in 2019. The arrival of just over 1m Ukrainian refugees since Russia invaded Ukraine will result in a slight bump to 82.9m in 2023, before the population begins a longer-term trend of decline. As elsewhere in Europe, the population is ageing, with the old-age dependency ratio expected to rise throughout the forecast period. The share of the population that is of working age in Germany dipped below that of Italy in 2018 and the UK in 2020, and is falling more swiftly than in any of the country's regional peers. This is likely to lead to greater pressure on the pensions and healthcare systems, and over time will exacerbate labour shortages.

- Germany will remain the world's fourth-largest economy at market exchange rates in 2027, and the biggest EU economy. It is the largest consumer market in Europe by population, but demand is constrained by a substantial tax wedge and high savings rates. We expect retail sales volumes to fall in 2023 as high inflation eats into disposable incomes, but to return to growth from 2024. Consumer demand for convenience will continue to rise, alongside demand for products that are sustainable; for ethnic, organic and local products; and for the expanding luxury segment. The share of online retail sales was boosted by the pandemic. An ageing demographic profile will increasingly shape demand.

- Our forecast for the economy's long-term average annual growth rate (2023-50) is 1.2%. The poor demographic outlook is the main driver of this weakening overall growth rate; total factor productivity will remain supportive of growth, as will capital spending. The picture looks slightly more favourable on a per-head basis, with average growth of 1.4%. Germany has many attributes that are conducive to sustainable long-term growth, including a highly skilled workforce, stable institutions and openness to innovation. Its openness to trade will ensure continued efforts to protect the multilateral trading system, but trade ties with Russia and China will decline given geopolitical tensions.

Background: The modern German state was founded in 1870. After the second world war (1939-45) Germany was divided into two parts: a liberal parliamentary democracy in the west and a totalitarian communist regime in the east. On October 3rd 1990, after the end of the Soviet Union's hegemony in central and eastern Europe, Germany was reunified.
Political structure: Germany is a federation of 16 states, or Länder, each of which has its own constitution, government and parliament. The states are primarily responsible for policing and education. The federal parliament comprises the directly elected Bundestag (the lower house) and the Bundesrat (the upper house) of representatives of the state governments. The federal chancellor, the head of the executive, is elected by the Bundestag and can be removed only by the election of a successor. Federal coalitions are typically made up of two parties, but voter fragmentation was such in the 2021 election that the current government is the first three-party coalition at the federal level.
Policy issues: Priorities include addressing the impact of high energy prices and inflation on the cost of living; reorienting defence and security policy; managing the transition of the automotive sector towards lower-emission vehicles; building industrial sovereignty and increasing the resilience of supply chains; the rollout of fifth-generation (5G) technology and progress on the Industry 4.0 agenda; and transitioning the energy sector away from reliance on Russia over the long term. Investment spending will increase in the forecast period (2023-27).
Taxation: The federal corporation tax rate was cut from 25% to 15% in 2008. The effective corporate tax rate, including a municipal trade tax and a solidarity tax, is about 30-33%. The solidarity tax was phased out for most income bands from 2021. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45%. Social-security contributions are shared equally between employers and employees. The main value-added tax (VAT) rate is 20%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus came to US$118.6bn in 2022, down from US$230.6bn in 2021 as energy import costs soared. Germany's single largest goods export market is still the EU, but the country has been more successful than most in diversifying its markets and selling into fast-growing emerging markets over the past decade.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Germany is a federal democracy, with major powers delegated to the 16 states (Länder). The 2021 election marked a turning point for the political landscape as Angela Merkel stood down after 16 years as chancellor. Her party, the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), performed poorly in the election, enabling the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD) to lead the next government. However, with these two big-tent parties having seen a sharp decline in their vote share in recent elections, as voter preferences have fragmented and previously solid electoral blocs (such as the blue-collar vote) have dispersed, three parties were needed to reach a majority at the federal level rather than two, for the first time. The SPD therefore governs with the liberal Free Democratic Party (FDP) and The Greens, which saw a notable surge in their support. The far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) and far-left Left Party both lost vote share compared with 2017. The bicameral parliament comprises the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament), whose members are elected on a system of modified proportional representation, and the Bundesrat (the upper house), which consists of representatives of the 16 state governments. The coalition has a majority in the Bundestag, but not in the Bundesrat.

Political outlook: Political stability Olaf Scholz of the SPD governs as chancellor at the head of the country's first three-party federal coalition, with the FDP and The Greens. Germany has a strongly centrist and consensus-based political culture, and EIU expects the coalition to serve its full term, to October 2025.
Russia's invasion of Ukraine created a cross-party consensus around increasing energy security and defence spending-an agreement that also included the CDU. However, poll ratings for all three coalition partners have fallen owing to the war and the energy crisis. The FDP has disappointed its more right-leaning voters, who see it as enabling what is in many respects still a centre-left coalition. The SPD has been criticised for Mr Scholz's perceived indecisiveness, and The Greens have lost their initial boost in support resulting from the party's clarity relating to Russia and energy policy.
As the coalition partners have seen their support erode, and experienced disappointments at state elections, they have become less amenable to compromise. This means that frictions and divisions will increase in 2023-24. As a consequence, Mr Scholz will have to continue to focus his efforts on keeping his domestic government in line, rather than playing a significant role in European affairs-a stark change from his predecessor, Ms Merkel.
Policymaking has leaned towards unwieldy compromises to satisfy the various coalition partners, and this will remain a key characteristic of the current government. Recent examples include the use of off-balance-sheet funds to provide EUR100bn in defence spending and EUR200bn in energy price support, but without suspending the constitutional "debt brake" on deficit spending (a red line for the FDP); and the temporary extension of nuclear power to April 2023 (a compromise between the pro-nuclear FDP and the anti-nuclear Greens). This type of policymaking has already invited legal and constitutional scrutiny, and will constrain the government's ability to plan for the long term.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness The quality of administration is high, and the implementation of policies that have been passed by parliament is sound. The federal structure of the government means that considerable responsibility falls on the 16 states that constitute the republic. An advantage of this is that many issues are decided with the closer democratic involvement of the electorate. States have a strong incentive to improve their own quality of governance, as comparisons with other states are easy to make, although one drawback is that the quality of public services such as education remains heterogeneous across states. Another disadvantage is that co-ordination can be difficult in policy areas in which the states have a large role. For instance, although the federal government has allocated additional funds for infrastructure investment in recent years, state governments have often been unable to use these for additional investment owing to capacity constraints. The design of the system also means that the constitutional powers enjoyed by the Bundesrat may, on occasion, limit the ability of the federal government to push through reforms in the face of opposition at state level, as state interests are represented in the Bundesrat.
A substantial majority of Germans agree that the Bundestag is too big. It has 736 members of parliament (MPs) at present, making it the largest democratically elected parliament in the world, and it is therefore expensive to run. A bill to reduce its size has been passed by the Bundestag but now faces a legal challenge at the Constitutional Court. The bill contains three key changes: a cap on the number of MPs at 630; a more proportional distribution of seats; and a stricter application of the 5% threshold for representation in parliament. If the legal challenge fails, the new, streamlined system could give the current coalition parties a better chance of staying in power.
Thorough coalition agreements support smooth policymaking, up to a point Majority coalitions are the norm in Germany at both the federal and the state levels. This generally ensures smooth policymaking, as the coalition agreement usually sets out in advance what the government will be working on throughout its term (although of course not everything can be anticipated in advance). In the case of the current three-party federal coalition, reaching this agreement involved 22 working groups, bringing together 300 politicians, and resulted in compromises and key wins for each of the parties. The consensus-oriented political culture underpins political stability, but the current federal government is finding that the need to reach compromises between the three ruling parties makes policymaking slower and less coherent than would be ideal.
Political outlook: Election watch The next federal election will be held in 2025. Opinion poll ratings for all three coalition partners have fallen owing to the war and the energy crisis. The FDP has disappointed its more right-leaning voters, who see it as enabling what is in many respects still a centre-left coalition. The SPD has been criticised for Mr Scholz's perceived indecisiveness, and The Greens have lost their initial boost in support resulting from the party's clarity relating to Russia and energy policy. The biggest beneficiary of this has been the CDU, which now leads most opinion polls, although the far-right AfD has also seen its support surge.
State elections have taken place in Bremen and Berlin thus far in 2023, the former of which led to the SPD becoming the largest party, while the latter produced a surge in support for the CDU at the expense of the SPD. However, the predictive value of these elections at the federal level is limited because the states in question are completely urban and relatively small. Two additional state elections scheduled for 2023, in Bavaria and Hesse, will provide a greater sense of the extent to which voters have been disappointed by the parties in the federal governing coalition.
A proposed electoral reform law would remove exceptions to the 5% threshold for proportional seats in order to reduce the size of the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament, currently the largest democratically elected parliament in the world). This would mean that the Left Party and the Christian Social Union (the Bavarian sister party of the CDU) would lose parliamentary representation if they failed to secure more than 5% of the national vote at the 2025 election. However, both parties have announced that they will challenge this in court.
Political outlook: International relations In response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine the EU has imposed ten packages of financial and individual sanctions, closely co-ordinated with the US and other Western allies. These sanctions will remain in place throughout our forecast period and probably beyond as the West and Russia continue their economic decoupling. We expect the war in Ukraine to be a protracted conflict with no clear-cut resolution, and risks of further escalation. As the war drags on and the costs to Ukraine's Western backers increase, public support in some places may start to decline, and deliveries of military support may become less generous. However, we do not expect a change in official positions of support for Ukraine in the forecast period.
Germany's policy shift towards China will probably underwhelm. The previous doctrine of "change through trade" that had long governed German policy towards China has since been seen as naive, and new restrictions on Chinese takeovers are likely in strategic industries such as semiconductors and logistics. However, trade and investment ties will remain substantial, as illustrated by the acquisition of a stake in a Hamburg port terminal by the Chinese state-owned shipping giant Cosco in November 2022.
Germany-EU tensions-in some cases triggered by Mr Scholz's efforts to manage the conflicting demands of his coalition partners-are set to persist on issues such as government support for energy costs, defence spending and relations with China. Disputes over state aid and the green transition will intensify in 2023 as the EU formulates a policy response to match increased US spending on green industrial policy. We expect the EU to be dragged (reluctantly) into the US-China subsidy race; initial proposals suggest that this is likely to advantage Germany over smaller member states with less fiscal firepower. Negotiations over the EU's new fiscal framework are also likely to increase intra-EU tensions, with Germany one of the leading fiscal hawks.

Germany's score in EIU's business environment model rises from 8.14 in the historical period (2018-22) to 8.25 in the forecast period (2023-27). The country climbs three places to eighth in the global ranking, and ranks fourth among its 17 regional peers, behind Denmark, Switzerland and Sweden. We expect that new policy initiatives from the coalition will lead to improvements in infrastructure, technological readiness and financing, bolstered by a post-pandemic reduction in financial distortions from state intervention. This is set against lower scores for policy towards foreign investment, and foreign trade and exchange controls, which largely reflect the unstable geopolitical environment and rising protectionism globally. EU funding will support the clean energy and digital transitions, but overall we expect only a slight improvement in Germany's business environment, with progress constrained by economic headwinds, the lagged effects of previously lacklustre supply-side reforms and exposure to the ripple effects of the war in Ukraine.
Germany's main strengths are its skilled labour force, stable political culture, openness to foreign trade and investment, and a strong research and innovation framework. It has sound legal and regulatory structures, efficient public administration, and a broadly pro-business policy orientation. The financing environment appears resilient and is supportive of business, but strains could emerge in the context of markedly tighter monetary conditions (compared with the past decade). Sentiment towards foreign investment will remain broadly favourable, but tighter screening rules and a focus on "protecting" national sovereignty will dampen capital inflows. Network infrastructure is extensive, but ageing in some areas, and improvements will be gradual. The tax regime places a heavy burden on labour income, and the demographic outlook is poor, which implies an ongoing issue with skilled labour shortages.

Business environment outlook: Germany's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2023-24: Greater state intervention in the energy sector, including price caps and Uniper nationalisation. EU state aid rules still relaxed. EU eases green investment state aid rules to counter the impact of the US Inflation Reduction Act.
2025-27: Limited prospects for reforming regulated service professions. Trend towards industrial sovereignty continues.
Policy towards foreign investment 2023-24: Government generally welcomes foreign direct investment. Prospective tightening of screening rules in "strategic" sectors for non-EU capital inflows, and greater political oversight amid EU-wide pushback.
2025-27: Investment from China is increasingly unwelcome amid concerns about intellectual property leakage.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2023-24: Trade surplus gradually recovers, and imported energy costs fall from record highs, but sustained higher input costs reduce industrial sector competitiveness. Semiconductor shortage gradually unwinds. Sanctions on Russian imports remain in place.
2025-27: EU makes further gradual progress on bilateral trade deals. Deterioration in EU-China relations and trade ties. Carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) instituted in 2026. Risk of escalating US-EU-China subsidy race.
Taxes 2023-24: No changes to headline rates. Scope for reform constrained by economic backdrop and coalition tensions. Modest adjustments aimed at mitigating the energy price shock, incentivising green investment and encouraging clean energy use.
2025-27: Comparatively high labour tax burden persists. Research and development (R&D) tax incentive applies until 2026.
Financing 2023-24: Financing environment for firms is fairly resilient, supported by the national development bank. Significantly tightened monetary conditions and jittery global markets will dampen activity and could expose vulnerabilities.
2025-27: Alternative financing channels remain fairly limited. Weak banking sector profitability remains an issue.
The labour market 2023-24: Unemployment remains low amid subdued economic backdrop. Modest easing of labour immigration rules, but sector-specific skills mismatches and labour shortages will persist.
2025-27: Policy focus on raising labour participation to counter structural challenges arising from ageing demographics.
Infrastructure 2023-24: Energy transition focuses on national hydrogen strategy, power grid improvement and new liquefied natural gas terminals to reduce exposure to Russia. Investment in healthcare infrastructure, the transport network and digital access.
2025-27: Achieving nationwide full-coverage target for gigabit-ready broadband (by 2025) will be challenging.
Technological readiness 2023-24: Government prioritises e-public services (where coverage and quality lag many peer countries), firms' digital adoption, automotive innovation and workforce digital skills.
2025-27: Efforts continue on Industry 4.0, which focuses on upgrading manufacturing through automation and connected systems. Increasing threat from cyber-weapons. Fifth-generation (5G) network rollout supports wider digitalisation drive.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
8.0 8.0 9 13 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Germany has solid macroeconomic fundamentals, with a high employment rate, a track record of fiscal management, a sophisticated export-focused industrial sector, an external surplus, moderate private-sector debt (by regional standards) and a robust institutional framework. Weaker aspects include poor medium-term trends in investment and infrastructure spending (partly due to fiscal restraint), a shrinking working-age population, overvalued property sectors in some cities, and low labour productivity growth. The category score is unchanged. However, we expect a slight deterioration in Germany's global ranking over the forecast period, reflecting the lagged effects of lacklustre supply-side reforms in the past decade in labour supply, digital transformation, network infrastructure and start-up financing. Higher living costs and commodity prices, tighter financing conditions, geopolitical tensions, and a more protectionist external trading environment will also constrain growth.
Germany's heavy historical reliance on Russian gas has proved a vulnerability Despite a less severe downturn over the pandemic than in most peer countries-amid extensive policy support and structural advantages-Germany's recovery since 2022 has lagged the regional average and trailed far behind that of the US. This largely reflects Germany's relatively high exposure to disrupted global trading conditions and supply chains, and its previously high reliance on Russian gas exports. Germany has made good progress in diversifying its energy supplies, but it will take time for badly affected industries, such as the energy-intensive chemicals sector, to recover. Industrial sector competitiveness will be weakened by sustained higher input costs (especially for energy), and subsidy-driven competition for investment with the US will add to structural pressures, particularly in the large automotive sector. Skilled labour shortages will limit growth potential in certain industries.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
8.3 8.3 12 12 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Germany will continue to offer an attractive environment for private enterprise, albeit with more restricted services competition and more complex sectoral regulation than in some peer countries. The category score and regional ranking remain unchanged in the forecast period. Increased state involvement in the economy in response to the pandemic and the Russia-Ukraine war will not be fully reversed. Private enterprise is supported by a robust institutional structure, a stable legal code, strong research and innovation capacity, and an extensive network of global and regional supply chains. The competition authority, the Federal Cartel Office, is reasonably efficient. The regulatory framework can be complex and costly, but is robust and generally transparent. Administrative processes for accessing utilities and credit, obtaining permits, enforcing contracts and resolving insolvency are fairly straightforward. However, the time and costs involved to establish a new business and hire labour tend to be above the OECD average, and there are high barriers to competition in certain transport, utilities, retail and business services sectors. Tax administration can be burden-some, but online registration and value-added tax (VAT) filing has improved since the introduction of an EU One-Stop-Shop e-commerce scheme in 2021.
State interventionism has increased since 2022, and is set to be maintained
- The cut-off of Russian gas has led to increased state intervention in the energy sector. This has involved subsidies, price caps, fuel tax cuts and a EUR50bn bailout (and de facto nationalisation) in late 2022 of Uniper, a power utility. The state will maintain a higher level of involvement in the economy and the energy sector in particular in 2023-27, given ongoing energy diversification efforts and as part of longer-term green-transition climate policies. This will accompany a broader shift towards greater industrial sovereignty and support for "strategically important" domestic firms.
- A temporary suspension of EU state aid rules during the pandemic has been partially rolled back since mid-2022, but investment and solvency support measures will continue until at least 2024. Regional tensions over state aid and the green transition are likely to intensify in 2023-24 as the EU implements a policy response to increased US spending on green industrial policy under its Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). The European Commission has proposed easing state aid restrictions for "investments in renewable energy and decarbonising industry" to counteract the impact of the IRA, which risks diverting investment in green technologies away from the EU by providing tax credits and subsidies for North America-based production. The initial proposals are likely to advantage Germany over smaller member states with less fiscal firepower. The issue of region-specific subsidies and policies relating to green investment will be a source of tension between the EU, the US and China over the forecast period.
- There is a moderate level of state ownership in the economy. The federal government's major holdings include Deutsche Bahn (100%); Uniper (99%); the former telecommunications monopoly, Deutsche Telekom (32%); the former postal monopoly, Deutsche Post (21%); and the country's second-largest financial institution, Commerzbank (16%). The liberal Free Democratic Party (FDP), which controls the Ministry of Finance, campaigned on a platform of reducing state ownership, but, given policy divisions within the three-party coalition and the relatively weak economic outlook, we do not expect major sell-offs of high-profile government stakes in the near to medium term.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
8.7 7.8 10 21 8 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Policy towards foreign direct investment (FDI) is fairly liberal (as in most EU countries), and Germany will remain a major destination for inward investment in 2023-27, given its economic size and solid business environment. However, FDI activity will be constrained by stricter monitoring rules, a weak economy and heightened global subsidy competition to attract clean energy investment. FDI screening procedures have been tightened considerably in recent years, especially for investors linked to China, amid hardened political sentiment towards capital inflows in "strategic" and "security-sensitive" sectors. This trend has been reinforced by the pandemic and the Russia-Ukraine war, which have fostered a global shift towards greater regionalisation and more protectionist trade and investment policies. The monitoring framework has broadened significantly into additional sectors, leading to a marked rise in the share of prospective FDI transactions subject to official review. This more interventionist stance and a more complex regulatory process for investors are reflected in falls in the category score and rankings in 2023-27. Specific nation-wide limitations on foreign ownership or control apply only in a few sectors such as media, defence and infrastructure. Restrictions on hostile takeovers are considerable, whether the acquirer is foreign or domestic; notice of strategic goals and "acting in concert" is mandatory for large investments. Foreign and domestic investors are treated equally in terms of investment incentives (with a focus on support for research and innovation) and protection of real and intellectual property. Germany Trade and Invest (GTAI) is the federal body responsible for FDI, with the state-owned development bank, KfW, the main provider of financing support. Production of semiconductors and electric-vehicle (EV) batteries are among the focus areas for attracting FDI, and two major subsidy-backed investments, from Intel (US) and Northvolt (Sweden), were reportedly close to being agreed as at June 2023.
Scrutiny of FDI transactions will continue to intensify
- Germany was a strong advocate of an EU-wide framework for stricter monitoring of non-EU FDI-which was implemented in 2020-21-and in recent years has progressively tightened the country's investment screening legislation and broadened its scope of application. This follows a period of increased Chinese (and other foreign) acquisitions of German firms, prompting concerns over the transfer of intellectual property and involvement of state-backed foreign actors in sensitive high-tech sectors and critical infrastructure assets. Historically, the government had the power to review (and veto) new investment projects or acquisitions of equity stakes above 25% in German companies by non-EU investors if the transactions were deemed to pose a risk to national security. The most severe threshold is now 10% for investments deemed to fall within a significantly expanded range of "critical" sectors (and which trigger a mandatory review), with less onerous thresholds of 20-25% dependent on the specific industry and investor. The interpretation of "national security risk" has also been broadened, including the potential impact on other EU member states. Mandatory reviews are now more likely for most FDI transactions relating to energy, telecommunications, transport, pharmaceuticals, artificial intelligence (AI), biotechnology, robotics, semiconductors, food security and raw material extraction. Scrutiny of FDI activity is expected to be tightened further over the forecast period and will probably become gradually more politicised.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
10.0 9.6 1 8 1 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
A high category score reflects Germany's traditional openness to international commerce, the importance to the economy of foreign trade and the country's membership of the EU, which provides for freedom of movement of goods, services, capital and persons within the bloc. The score declines slightly for 2023-27, reflecting exposure to what is likely to be a more unstable geopolitical environment and an underlying deterioration in trading conditions, amid increased protectionism and regionalisation, lower FDI activity, tighter bilateral controls on technology, and a deterioration in West-China relations. No tariffs or quotas are permitted within the EU, and most other non-tariff restrictions have been abolished. The EU trades with Norway and Iceland under the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) and has a range of bilateral agreements with Switzerland, a customs union with Turkey and a limited free-trade agreement (FTA) with the UK. Agriculture is excluded from these arrangements. Trade with other non-EU countries is mostly subject to moderate customs duties. Bilateral and regional agreements provide for lower or zero tariffs and co-operation on non-tariff barriers.

- Supply-chain frictions will diminish in 2023, but headwinds will persist in the form of ongoing inflationary pressures, tighter financing conditions and geopolitical tensions. At the regional level, the EU will seek to bolster production and supply-chain resilience in sectors such as pharmaceuticals, biotech, semiconductors and EV batteries over the forecast period. However, industrial competitiveness will be weakened by sustained higher input costs (especially energy) and will also come under strain from the US's IRA clean energy subsidy programme. Amid fears that the IRA will divert investment from Europe-Germany's automotive industry is among the more exposed sectors-the EU is likely to respond with its own package of green incentives, marking a renewed global subsidy race with the US (and Asia). This shift will pose new challenges in EU-US trade relations. We assume that US-EU ties will remain firm in 2023 as shared geopolitical concerns (mainly over Russia and China) overshadow bilateral trade tensions, but this dynamic could shift over time, particularly after the 2024 US presidential election. Europe's push for "strategic autonomy" will prevent uniformity in a transatlantic approach towards China.

A deterioration in EU-China relations is likely
- EU-China tensions have risen over recent years as China has come to be viewed more as a systemic rival, with the EU adopting a tougher approach on human rights abuses, investment screening and an effort to "derisk" economic ties. Amid US pressure on "like-minded governments" for tighter alignment on trade and investment restrictions relating to China, we expect a deterioration in EU-China ties in 2023-27. Developments in recent years have exposed the naivety of Germany's long-standing efforts to enact "change through trade" in its relations with authoritarian states. The government is working to elaborate a new China strategy, although any decoupling will be gradual given Germany's substantial trade and economic links with China. A likely shift will see firms adopt "China plus one" supply-chain strategies, amid a compliance burden of heightened sanctions. Pressure on countries to choose a side between China and the US will be a major trade and geopolitical theme over the forecast period.
- In recent years the EU has finalised FTAs with Canada, Singapore, Vietnam, Japan and the UK, upgraded its deals with Mexico and Chile, and launched trade talks with Indonesia, Australia and New Zealand. We expect the EU to make gradual progress on bilateral trade deals over the forecast period. The current limited scope of the EU-UK Trade and Co-operation Agreement (TCA), especially in services trade, will slowly expand and evolve, as economic realities force a less confrontational stance from the UK government in relations with the bloc (there has been some evidence of this since early 2023). However, the competitive market and regulatory environment implied by the UK's third-country status means that EU-UK tensions will persist.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
7.1 7.1 23 29 6 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The tax regime remains one of the weaker areas of Germany's business environment, and, with only minor changes expected, the country falls back in the global and regional rankings over the forecast period. Complexity will remain an issue, with taxes levied at the federal, state and municipal level. As in most peer countries, the tax/GDP ratio has trended higher in recent years and stood at 42.4% in 2021 (latest comparable Eurostat data), similar to the euro zone average. Taken together, direct taxes on personal income and net social-security contributions (labour taxes) account for a higher than average share of tax receipts. A progressive income tax system levies rates ranging from 14% to 42% on taxable income between EUR10,632 and EUR61,971 (in 2023). The 42% rate applies to income up to EUR277,825, above which there is a 45% top rate. An additional "solidarity surcharge"-a 5.5% levy on income to finance reunification costs-was abolished for most taxpayers in 2021, with a tapered scale for higher earners. Most employees pay social-security contributions into insurance funds covering pensions, healthcare, unemployment and long-term care. Contribution rates range from 18.6% of gross salary (split between employees and employer) for pensions to about 3% for long-term care and unemployment insurance. The standard VAT rate is 19%, slightly less than the EU average, with a reduced rate of 7% on certain goods and services.
A fairly complex corporate tax regime will constrain new investment
- The tax system places a relatively high tax burden on labour income and companies. In 2022 the average single worker faced a tax wedge of 47.8%, the second highest in the OECD. Those with children have a lower, but still above-average, tax wedge. This high burden particularly affects low-income workers and acts as a disincentive for second earners, contributing to Germany's modest full-time employment rate for women. The effective tax burden for companies is also elevated, despite a comparatively low headline federal corporation tax rate of 15%. Including a local trade tax (Gewerbesteuer) and other levies, the effective average corporation tax rate is about 30%, against an EU average of about 21%. Tax incentives are rare, but a EUR1m annual allowance for certain research and development (R&D) activities will apply until 2026. A temporary windfall tax will be levied on electricity producers until mid-2023 and could be extended until April 2024. The overall corporate tax regime is not particularly supportive of new business investment, especially among smaller firms and start-ups. It will remain fairly complex, contributing to high compliance costs and favouring debt over equity, constraining the venture capital market.
- Given the subdued economic backdrop, Germany's long-standing fiscal hawkishness and a coalition agreement (stipulated by the FDP) not to raise headline tax rates, reform measures will be limited. Some modest changes to the corporate tax framework are likely from 2024 that could include more generous rules for depreciation and partnerships, and incentives for firms that invest in climate protection. A carbon pricing system was introduced in 2021 and is likely to be gradually amended, as part of a broader "carrot and stick" approach to climate-related tax measures aimed at influencing transport use and energy efficiency. EV subsidies were cut in 2023 and will be largely phased out by end-2024. Developments at the EU level, such as the bloc's proposed Green Deal Industrial Plan (a response to the US IRA), are likely to play a significant role in shaping firms' climate-related investment plans over the forecast period.
- Other tax plans include a tightening of rules covering the real estate transfer tax (RETT), a further strengthening of measures to combat tax fraud and evasion (following on from the implementation in mid-2021 of the EU's Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive-ATAD), and greater digitalisation of the tax administration. A reform of property tax is due to take effect from 2025 (the current system is based on values dating from the 1960s), although a delay is possible amid issues with the revaluation process and the politically contentious nature of the reform (given the probable rise in property taxes).

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
8.1 9.3 9 1 3 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Financial stability indicators appear robust, despite recent market jitters The financing environment has been resilient amid the economic shocks of recent years, supported by the stabilising effects of substantial policy support, a fairly competitive banking sector and the prominent role of the KfW (the largest national development bank in Europe). As at May 2023, bank capital levels and liquidity coverage were above regulatory minimums, and there was a low level of non-performing loans (NPLs). The higher category score in the forecast period largely reflects a post-pandemic reduction in financial distortions from state intervention. Vulnerabilities mainly stem from structurally low bank profitability (among the weakest in the EU), modest revenue growth and elevated operating costs. Net interest income is rising amid tightened monetary policy, but operating conditions will remain challenging amid ripple effects from the war in Ukraine, subdued economic growth, the unwinding of central bank stimulus (quantitative tightening) and jittery financial markets. The banking system has a three-tiered structure, with large private commercial banks (the two biggest are Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank) and the state-owned regional lenders (Landesbanken) operating alongside an extensive network of local credit co-operatives and public-sector savings banks (owned by local authorities) that primarily service the Mittelstand (small and medium-sized enterprises-SMEs). Alongside the KfW, this offers a range of financing options, but also contributes to downward pressure on banking margins. Internally generated funds account for an above-average share of corporate financing, reflecting firms' low reliance on capital markets. Bank credit is the preferred SME funding channel, being relatively cheap and available at long maturities. Venture capital markets have expanded only slowly and are less developed than in most large high-income countries. Availability of early- and late-stage growth capital for start-ups and smaller firms remains fairly restrictive, amid limited state-backed support measures.

- Financial sector balance sheets appear fairly resilient, and instability risks are generally low. However, there is a risk that fragile linkages between banks and other parts of the financial sector could be exposed by tighter and more volatile financing conditions in 2023-27 than in the past decade, as well as structurally higher inflation. Excessive interest-rate exposure, impaired debt-servicing capacity or a sudden shift in wider financial market sentiment (similar to the market turmoil in the US and Switzerland in March 2023) could trigger more strained liquidity conditions, pushing up bank funding costs and restricting credit availability.

We expect a gradual cooling of the real estate market, but some risks remain
- Vulnerabilities in the German residential and commercial real estate sectors increased steadily over the historical period, in the context of rising investor activity, low borrowing costs, constrained housing supply, loosened credit standards and pandemic-driven changes in property demand. Real estate prices rose strongly, particularly in major cities, with prices in some segments appearing to be increasingly misaligned from fundamentals. Higher interest rates and cost-of-living pressures will dampen mortgage demand in 2023 and drive a slight correction in property prices, but underlying imbalances will persist. The banking sector is not overly exposed to the property market, but a larger than expected asset-price correction, amid higher debt-servicing costs, could trigger instability. Stricter bank capital buffer rules linked to domestic residential housing loans are being phased in over 2022-23, and a modest tightening of macroprudential measures for borrowers is likely.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
7.0 6.9 17 23 8 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Germany's labour market boasts a skilled and reasonably productive workforce, low unemployment, defined employer-employee relations, a statutory national minimum wage, and a well-established framework of vocational training and apprenticeships. Solid labour market indicators before the pandemic, and a resilient performance since 2020, can be traced in part to liberalising reforms implemented by previous governments. However, some aspects hold down the score. Unit labour costs and average living costs are comparatively high. Participation of women in full-time employment is modest, constrained by limited childcare availability (despite reforms since 2017) and tax disincentives for second earners. There is a large gap between employment rates of female EU and non-EU nationals (more so than for men), implying transition issues into the labour market. The share of low-skilled, low-wage employment in the economy has risen steadily. The proportion of information and communication technology (ICT) specialists is slightly above the regional average but lags demand, constraining the pace of digital transformation. Employment prospects (and the participation rate) of older workers have improved, but a declining working-age population implies labour supply challenges and skills shortages.
The labour force will contract absent large-scale immigration
- Germany's short-time work scheme (Kurzarbeit) played an important role in shielding the labour market during the pandemic (many countries implemented similar wage-subsidy programmes), limiting job losses and allowing companies to retain workers with firm-specific skills, mitigating the costs associated with lay-offs and future hiring and training. However, the labour force still contracted, with groups already disadvantaged in the labour market-such as young workers, the lower skilled, women and foreign nationals-disproportionately affected owing to the nature of the lockdowns. Encouragingly, there has been a more concerted policy focus over recent years on programmes aimed at better integrating these groups into the labour market, although their impact will be only gradual. A recent influx of approximately 1m immigrants due to the conflict in Ukraine will provide a near-term boost to labour supply. The government has set out plans for more flexible work-time schemes, and an easing of relatively complex worker immigration rules is expected to be approved by mid-2023. More measures will be needed over the forecast period aimed at increasing labour participation to counter demographic trends.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
8.0 8.3 13 12 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Infrastructure is well developed, but in some instances badly maintained Network infrastructure is extensive and reliable, but weak capital investment over the past decade has led to a gradual deterioration in quality, constrained the pace of digital transformation and raised capacity concerns in the energy transition policy (Energiewende) around renewables. Transport infrastructure is well developed, but years of spending restraint have heightened road congestion and repair backlogs, with poor co-ordination between the different levels of government delaying high-speed rail projects and the planned Fehmarn Belt link with Denmark. Germany has extensive fourth generation (4G) mobile coverage and compares well for "5G-readiness" and the rollout of its 5G network. Broadband availability and pricing are fairly good in a regional context, amid recent progress in expanding network coverage of ultra-fast services. However, speeds are only around the EU average and well below the world's top-performing countries. Availability of fibre-to-the-home (FTTH) broadband connections is limited and far below the EU average.

- We expect an improvement in network infrastructure over the forecast period, with upgraded public investment plans (supported by EU grants) targeted towards digital connectivity and skills, decarbonisation, hydrogen technology, the EV sector, and rail network modernisation. However, the immense scale and disruptive impact of the green and digital transitions imply only a gradual pace of change, with progress likely to be constrained by the fallout from the war in Ukraine (in the form of structurally higher energy costs and the need to focus on cost-of-living issues), regulatory hurdles such as complex planning rules and funding difficulties (the green investment push will require significant private-sector investment).
- Accelerated plans for FTTH rollout, ongoing 5G network builds and targeted policy support (including EU grants from the Recovery and Resilience Facility-RRF) will bring gradual improvements in full-fibre availability and further narrow an urban-rural digital divide. However, achieving nationwide full-coverage targets for gigabit-ready broadband (by 2025) and full-fibre access (by 2030) will be challenging.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
8.9 9.4 11 3 6 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Germany scores well for technological readiness, owing to the scope of its digital infrastructure, fairly strong e-commerce and e-business penetration, a national Industry 4.0 initiative aimed at supporting digital manufacturing, an above-average share of ICT specialists, and a well-developed framework for research and innovation. Weaker aspects are the comparatively slow pace of ultrafast broadband rollout, modest digital adoption (and innovation activity) by SMEs, below-average basic digital skills levels, and below-par scope and quality of e-government services. Investment in R&D was 3.1% of GDP in 2021, one of the highest ratios in the EU. R&D intensity has trended gradually higher over the past decade, driven primarily by large firms in medium- and high-tech manufacturing (the EV shift in the automotive industry has been a major driver). An official target is to raise total R&D investment to 3.5% of GDP by 2025. In recent years Germany has slipped from being an "innovation leader" to a "strong innovator" on the European Commission's Innovation Scoreboard. Germany scores well for business investment and public-private linkages, but lags its peers in entrepreneurship and financing support. Berlin, the capital, is the hub for entrepreneurial dynamism in Germany, but national indicators of innovative high-growth firms, start-up activity and SME innovations have weakened over recent years. Germany has a National Cyber Response Centre, and updated its cyber-security strategy in 2021. According to the Global Cyber-security Index from the International Telecommunication Union (ITU), Germany ranks 13th for its commitment and capacity to deal with cybercrime and cyber-espionage.
Increasing digitalisation, especially among SMEs, will be an area of focus
- There will be a policy focus in 2023-27 on bolstering digital adoption by SMEs, supporting digitalisation of automotive production, improving the quality of e-government services (particularly in the health system, and by harmonising infrastructure across the federal, state and municipal levels), and increasing the share of ICT specialists in the workforce. Funding will be supported by RRF grants, which will also be directed to EU-wide initiatives in microelectronics and next-generation cloud infrastructure.
- The 5G rollout will support increasing digitalisation by companies and the state in areas such as cloud services, data analytics, smart city applications, digital payments and AI solutions. Constraining factors will be labour shortages, data privacy issues, rising geopolitical tensions over technology regulation and competition, and increasing cyber-security risks.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The government has enacted many of its initial social policy priorities, including liberalisation of abortion and drug laws, a pending easing of immigration laws, and a compromise on welfare reform provisions. However, its planned programme of investment and modernisation has been largely superseded by the priorities of the war in Ukraine and the energy crisis. Public investment has focused on energy infrastructure, including the expedited construction of several liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals, the acceleration of new renewable power construction and the reactivation of several mothballed coal plants. Longer-term investment plans around the transition to electric vehicles and digitalisation have slowed. A compromise climate bill has led to greater investment and expedited permit processing for renewable infrastructure and mass transit, but has also weakened sectoral targets for decarbonisation. Efforts to boost defence spending have so far underwhelmed, but are set to accelerate.
The Zeitenwende (turning point) in defence spending promised by the chancellor, Olaf Scholz, is taking time to show results. Military spending and arms deliveries to Ukraine ramped up only slowly in 2022, with lengthy bureaucratic procedures and difficulties in shifting mindsets among senior decision-makers holding back change. The new defence minister, Boris Pistorius, who took office in January, is reorganising defence procurement to speed this up, but has warned that existing gaps in supplies will endure until at least 2030. The publication of the government's new National Security Strategy, scheduled for early 2023, has been delayed until mid-June, reflecting disagreements within the governing parties on how the direction of foreign policy should change.
The government's fiscal plan to 2025 foresees significantly higher capital investment in artificial intelligence, the rollout of 5G mobile technology and innovation in the automotive industry. Boosting electric-vehicle and semiconductor production capacity will be priorities, with the shift away from internal-combustion-engine vehicles set to present major disruption to manufacturers. Additional spending will also include funding for healthcare, education, child care, the energy transition and boosting industrial sovereignty for systemically important areas. The state-owned investment bank, KfW, is likely to play a major role in financing these initiatives.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)
  2022 2023 2024 2025 2026 2027
Government expenditure 49.8 49.2 48.4 48.5 48.2 47.8
Government revenue 47.1 46.7 46.7 47.2 47.5 47.6
Budget balance -2.6 -2.5 -1.6 -1.3 -0.7 -0.2
Government debt 66.3 66.2 64.5 65.5 64.7 63.5
Historically, Germany has had a prudent fiscal policy, bolstered by the constitutional debt brake, which limits annual borrowing to 0.35% of GDP in normal circumstances outside recessions or national emergencies, keeping its debt/GDP ratio manageable. However, in recent years the government has used off-balance-sheet vehicles to get around the constraints of the debt brake. The most significant of these at present are EUR100bn in investment for the armed forces, and the EUR200bn "defence shield" to protect households and industry from high gas prices. The latter initiative has measures running to end-April 2024, including a "gas price brake" that fixes the price of 80% of the typical gas usage of households and small and medium-sized firms, and 70% for large industrial firms-supporting essential usage while also incentivising cutbacks.
With energy costs having moderated, it is unclear how much of this EUR200bn fund will need to be spent. The latest projections from the Ministry of Finance suggest that the 2023 deficit could therefore range from 4.25% of GDP (if all is used) to 1.25% (with none). EIU's forecast is for a shortfall equivalent to 2.5% of GDP in 2023, narrowing thereafter to close to balance by 2027. Major revenue-raising reforms are unlikely during this parliamentary term, given that the coalition agreement committed to no tax rises at the insistence of the FDP.
We expect public debt to decline from 66.3% of GDP in 2022 to 63.5% at end-2027. Over the longer term, changing the debt brake is unlikely, as it would require a two-thirds majority in the Bundestag, and there is limited political appetite for repeal. However, the continued creation of off-balance-sheet funds may undermine the integrity of the official budgeting process, and is already resulting in legal and constitutional scrutiny.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2022 2023 2024 2025 2026 2027
Short-term interest rate (av) 0.3 3.7 3.9 3.0 2.0 1.6
Long-term interest rate (av) 1.3 2.6 2.7 2.2 2.0 1.9
The European Central Bank (ECB) raised its interest rates by another 25 basis points at its most recent monetary policy meeting, in May, as it expects euro zone inflation to remain above its 2% target until 2025. Following a cumulative 375-basis-point increase in policy rates since July 2022, we expect another 25-basis-point rise in both June and July, with the deposit rate settling at 3.75% and the main refinancing rate at 4.25% by July 2023. Headline inflation eased to 6.1% in May, from 7% in April, and underlying price pressures also eased. However, Christine Lagarde, the ECB president, said in early June that there was no clear evidence that core inflation had peaked and pledged to raise interest rates further to bring inflation down to its 2% target "in a timely manner". On the assumption that annual inflation slows more significantly in 2024, we expect the ECB to start easing monetary policy from the second half of that year, with the main refinancing rate likely to settle at about 1.75% in 2026-27.
Households and businesses will continue to face a sharp rise in borrowing costs and tighter credit conditions in the near term. Higher interest rates will dampen private consumption and push up costs for firms, which will also reduce investment. Business bankruptcies will tick up in 2023 as a result. The risk of a liquidity crisis in the euro zone is low, and the ECB would intervene if such a scenario were to materialise. Ms Lagarde has reassured the markets that the bank is ready to "respond as necessary" to preserve financial stability in the euro area.

High energy costs, inflation and tightening monetary policy pushed Germany into a mild technical recession over the winter of 2022/23. Industrial production declined modestly, especially in the most energy-intensive sectors, although the rest of the industrial sector was effective in substituting away from gas. Consumer and business confidence remained depressed, and, along with a pull-back in government spending, this led to an overall decline in GDP.
We expect Germany to register weak quarterly growth for the remainder of the year as declining energy prices and increased industrial demand from China support the industrial sector. However, private consumption will remain weak, driven by stagnant real wages, still-high inflation and rising interest rates, while demand from the EU and US markets for German exports will remain subdued. Despite the return to quarterly growth, we expect a full-year GDP contraction of 0.2% for 2023, making Germany the worst-performing G7 economy and the only one for which we forecast a full-year contraction this year.
We expect still-elevated energy prices and tight monetary policy to result in a period of slow growth until mid-2024. The main downside risk is that monetary tightening continues for longer than we expect in 2023. Our core forecast is for 1.3% growth next year, strengthening to an average of 1.4% in 2025-27. Over the longer term, Germany's poor demographic outlook will constrain potential growth as the working-age population declines.
With gas prices set to remain higher in Europe than their historical norms over the medium term, Germany's cost competitiveness will fall in gas- and energy-intensive sectors. For some firms (particularly in the chemicals and metals sectors), this means that producing in Europe will no longer be a profitable business strategy. BASF, Germany's biggest chemicals firm, has announced that it will permanently downsize its European operations, while developing a EUR10bn plant in China. Technological disruption in the automotive sector also represents a structural risk: Germany has been slow to shift towards electric vehicles, and the supply chains for such vehicles require fewer manufactured components (of which Germany is a world leader) and more scarce raw materials. However, Germany's long-established advantages as an attractive business environment at the heart of Europe mean that the country will still retain significant advantages in industrial production, even though its global share of energy-intensive industries is set to decline.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Services account for about 70% of GDP, industry for almost 30% and agriculture less than 1%. The share of industry in the German economy exceeds those of all the other major economies in Europe, with the UK and France at roughly 20%, and even Italy at only 25%. This proved an advantage for Germany during the pandemic in 2020-21, as industrial production was less disrupted by social-distancing restrictions than contact-intensive services. However, since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Germany's large industrial sector-and historic dependence on Russian gas to fuel this-has come to represent a vulnerability. High energy costs have made energy-intensive sectors, such as chemicals, less competitive on the world stage. We expect Germany's economy to strengthen as energy costs continue to moderate over our forecast period, but in the short term it will continue to underperform those of its peers in western Europe.
The automotive sector is currently managing a structural transition Germany's most important manufacturing sectors are automotive; electrical and mechanical engineering; chemicals; and food, drink and tobacco. Germany is the global leader in the production of premium cars, an industry that has benefited from robust competition between several domestic companies, ownership structures that have enabled firms to make long-term investments, and a host of innovative supplier companies in the mechanical and electrical engineering sectors. Cluster effects are significant, and Germany's industrial champions increasingly provide value added through services supplied in conjunction with manufactured products.
The automotive sector is currently managing a structural transition towards electric and hybrid vehicles, having historically invested heavily in diesel technology and entered the electric market comparatively late. This transition will be particularly disruptive for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that produce intermediate components for the carmaking sector, as electric motors require far fewer components than internal-combustion engines, with the most significant component being the battery. A Tesla (US) gigafactory that opened in March 2022 outside Berlin, the capital, was built in an exceptionally fast 22 months, and will produce batteries as well as electric cars. Northvolt (Sweden) is also planning to build a lithium-ion battery gigafactory in northern Germany, to be financed by subsidies under the EU's answer to the US's green subsidy plan, the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). However, China will continue to dwarf Europe's lithium battery production capacity, and Chinese electric vehicles will present an increasingly robust competitive challenge.
China is Germany's second-largest export market, and trade and investment ties with China are more substantial for Germany than for any other EU country. As such, Germany's efforts to shift towards a tougher stance on China, in line with the EU's policy of derisking, have so far underwhelmed. The sale in October 2022 of a stake in the port of Hamburg-Germany's largest port and the third busiest in the EU-to a Chinese investor was particularly controversial. The Greens and the FDP are in favour of tougher restrictions on trade and investment deals with China, and US pressure will be in the same direction, but Mr Scholz will aim to keep change gradual, to protect German industry.
Most industries derive competitive advantages from Germany's well-developed system of vocational training, good physical infrastructure and research base, and a tax system that encourages capital investment. Fiscal stimulus measures targeted towards infrastructure improvements, the green and digital transitions, and energy security will continue to support the construction sector, although consumer demand is moderating in the face of rising interest rates.
The pandemic has had an asymmetric impact on the services sector The services sector is the largest component of GDP and comprises a broad range of activities, from retailing to financial services, logistics and healthcare. Many of the changes prompted by the pandemic-more remote working, less business travel, a rise in e-commerce at the expense of bricks-and-mortar retailers-will endure throughout our forecast period. The financial services sector is important in Germany, but at 3.2% of GDP in 2022 it is smaller relative to the size of the economy than in the US, the UK and Japan (and below the EU average of 3.8%). It coped well with the economic shocks from the pandemic and the Russia-Ukraine war, aided by extensive monetary and fiscal support, as well as reforms and restructuring over the past decade. Capital levels and liquidity coverage are well above regulatory minimums, but conditions will remain challenging in the coming years amid a sluggish economy, tighter financing conditions, firmer price pressures and a softer housing market.

We forecast that inflation will ease from an average of 8.7% in 2022 to 6% in 2023, owing to the combination of stabilising energy prices, depressed demand as economic growth slows and base effects as the rapid commodity price increases in 2022 move out of the year-earlier comparison period. However, prices will remain elevated in historical terms. Moreover, the end of zero-covid protocols in China may boost producer price inflation in Germany via additional global demand for commodities later this year. Greater stability in energy prices as new LNG supply infrastructure comes online, alongside tighter monetary policy and weaker consumer demand, will pull inflation down to an average of 2.5% in 2024. Price growth will stabilise at 2% per year on average in 2025-27.

After the euro depreciated sharply against the US dollar in 2022, the single currency appreciated again in early 2023, reaching a 14-month high in early May. This was the result of declining energy prices, an improving economic outlook and still-strong inflation data in the euro zone, which point to further tightening by the ECB (we expect the ECB to raise interest rates by 25 basis points in both June and July). We expect that the euro will appreciate slightly against the dollar in the remainder of 2023 as the interest-rate differential between the ECB and the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) narrows further. The euro:dollar exchange rate will reach US$1.14:EUR1 at year-end (a 6.5% appreciation from end-2022). Over the medium term, the value of the euro will continue to be supported by the euro zone's current-account surplus.

The higher cost of imported energy and a slowdown in industrial output reduced Germany's trade surplus to a multi-year low in 2022-at almost half its value in 2021. We expect that the current-account surplus will expand only slightly in 2023, to 4.4% of GDP, as energy prices decline, reducing import costs. We expect it to rebound further in 2024 as exports strengthen. Germany's current-account surpluses will still be supported by large primary income surpluses, owing to the country's substantial domestic savings, most of which are invested abroad. We forecast that the current-account surplus will stabilise in 2025-27 at an average of 5.5% of GDP.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Germany Stocks and flows Germany is an attractive destination for foreign investment, but the country's role as an exporter of long-term capital is more important: it is the fourth-largest investor in the world. The skills of its workforce, the availability of supplier companies, the quality of the research and innovation framework, and a reliable administrative and legal environment make Germany one of the most attractive global destinations for inward foreign direct investment (FDI). However, relative to GDP, the stock of such investment is lower than in some comparatively sized economies. Following a significant increase in inflows during the 1990s, the rate of growth of FDI slowed, falling below the world average, and outflows have exceeded inflows since 2004-with the exception of 2020, when the coronavirus pandemic disrupted the progress of investment deals. By 2022 FDI flows had normalised, albeit with outflows (at EUR178.9bn) much healthier than inflows (at EUR47.4bn). At end-2022 the inward FDI stock was EUR2.1trn, or 52.2% of GDP; the outward FDI stock was EUR3.2trn, or 79.6% of GDP.
Origin and distribution About two-thirds of Germany's inward FDI stock originates from other EU member states-although this sometimes includes investment from outside the EU that is transferred through countries such as the Netherlands and Luxembourg, often for tax reasons. The most important investor from outside the EU is the US, which accounts for 12% of the total stock. The US was responsible for the largest number of greenfield and expansion projects in 2022, at 279, and also for the largest single investment-a EUR17bn deal by Intel (US) to build a "mega fab" chip manufacturing plant in Magdeburg, which will benefit from subsidies under the EU's European Chips Act. Authorities and companies have become increasingly hesitant about increasing investment from China (which amounts to just over 1% of the FDI stock), which often targets mid-sized companies with significant technological know-how. This is likely to weigh on investment from China in the coming years, given new investment screening measures at the EU level. Most outward investment is to other EU countries, but investment in Switzerland, the US, Russia and China is also significant. However, exposure to Russia is now a vulnerability, and German firms have massively disinvested from the country since the invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.
Determinants Germany's attractiveness as an investment location stems from its robust institutional framework, stable legal code, strong research and innovation capacity, and an extensive network of global and regional supply chains. The country also has good infrastructure, a number of innovative high-tech clusters and a high-quality workforce. Labour costs are among the highest in the world, but compare strongly with European peers owing to a lengthy period of wage restraint. Germany Trade and Invest is the first point of contact for foreign investors, and provides details about recent trends and growing areas of demand-information and communication technology (ICT) and software was the most dynamic area of inward investment in 2022 (22% of total deals), followed by business and financial services (21%). Foreign investors, including private equity firms, are attracted by the large number of profitable medium-sized companies specialising in niche markets. Regulations such as the right of worker representatives to sit on company boards (up to half of board members) have deterred some foreign investors, but in practice the system of workforce representation in companies often helps company management bodies to communicate their strategies and, where necessary, explain the need for changes in working practice-or even reduced pay in difficult circumstances. The tax environment remains, on balance, a downside.
Impact Foreign-owned companies employ about 2.5m people in Germany. Many FDI inflows take the form of acquisitions rather than greenfield investment, and hence the immediate impact on employment is not clear (and in some cases is initially negative). In industry, especially manufacturing, the dominance of German firms means that FDI has had only a limited impact. Foreign investment in Germany's services has had a larger impact on the domestic economy, boosting productivity via the introduction of new technology and fewer hierarchical organisational structures. Investment by private equity groups has also helped to inject capital and managerial expertise into slow-growing family-owned businesses.
Potential Germany's skilled workforce and sound infrastructure make it a good location for specialised manufacturing. More generally, the structure of German industry is still relatively fragmented, providing foreign investors with the opportunity to participate in sectoral consolidation and to reap economies of scale through acquisitions. The generational changeover at the helm of several small and medium-sized companies provides opportunities for foreign investors, although in many cases foreign involvement is not appreciated. The still-moderate level of property prices-by west European standards-and increasing demand for housing, especially in urban areas, may attract investors into this sector. A poor demographic outlook, with population growth set to stagnate and then decline, will constrain Germany's potential as a consumer market. Government screening of inward investment has increased recently and will remain high, as political pressure to protect sensitive industries has increased in recent years. This is the case across Europe, and has led to delays in approving projects and more frequent rejections of takeovers.
