5.5 5.8 64 65 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's macroeconomic environment score improves in the forecast period, as we think that the Real will be less volatile than in 2018-22, when-like many emerging-market currencies-it was rocked by global shocks and swings in the US dollar's value amid the covid-19 pandemic. However, the overall score is constrained by an unbalanced policy mix-Brazil's heavy debt burden requires high interest rates to maintain price stability-and the situation is unlikely to improve. Fiscal and quasi-fiscal policies will be expansionary under Lula, particularly involving greater financing at subsidised rates through the Brazilian Development Bank (BNDES). We expect Congress to approve Lula's new fiscal framework by mid-year. His new rules are more flexible than the existing ones that cap federal spending to zero growth in real terms, but they will still limit spending growth to up to 70% of revenue growth. The government envisages a swing to a primary surplus of 1% of GDP by 2026, but we think that its underlying revenue projections are overly optimistic. We therefore expect that the government will miss its fiscal targets and that the public debt/GDP ratio will rise from 73% currently, exceeding 80% in 2026-27.
A new fiscal anchor is a positive, but inflation targets are under pressure Lula has recently attacked Roberto Campos Neto, governor of the Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank), for keeping the Selic policy rate high (it stands at 13.75% currently). Nevertheless, we do not expect Lula to undermine the BCB's independence or interfere with the existing floating exchange-rate regime. There is a risk, however, that the monetary council (comprising two government ministers and Mr Campos Neto) will raise Brazil's medium-term inflation targets, as Lula considers the 3% target for 2024-25 too low (it was 4.5% under his party's administrations in 2003-16). We expect the BCB to embark on a monetary-easing cycle in August, reducing the real rate to 4-5% over the next two years, with inflation fluctuating at around 4% from 2024-higher than in most Latin American countries. When Mr Campos Neto's term finishes at end-2024, there is a risk that Lula will nominate a more heterodox figure who could undermine investor confidence in the BCB's commitment to the inflation-targeting strategy.

- Lula's state-led growth model will keep GDP growth below 2% throughout the forecast period. However, Brazil's large market, which we expect to reach US$2.6trn by 2027, will still attract investors. The country's huge agricultural harvest will support the economy and the external sector. Although we expect the current-account deficit to widen in the medium term as imports pick up, it will be covered by sizeable foreign direct investment (FDI), especially if the government manages to advance its green transition agenda and joins the OECD.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
6.5 6.5 32 35 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Although Brazil performs relatively well in this area, policy towards private enterprise and competition will be less business-friendly and prospects for privatisation much weaker under Lula than under Mr Bolsonaro. For example, Lula is more likely than his predecessor to shift governance norms at regulatory agencies and state-owned enterprises (SOEs) towards increased political interference in some sectors, partly to favour political allies. He will also halt plans to privatise key sectors such as oil and the postal services. Even so, there will be opportunities for investors via public-private partnerships (PPPs), as well as in the environmental, social and governance (ESG) space, which Lula will promote as he trumpets his environmental credentials on the global stage.

- Lula's efforts to change regulations that govern the Agência Nacional de Águas e Saneamento Básico (ANA, the water and sanitation agency) could obstruct efforts to boost private participation in the expansion of sanitation services. Congress has pushed back on the legislation, but Lula will not be deterred. He has also tried to change Law 13,303/2016 to reduce the "quarantine" time required for politicians to take up high-ranking position at SOEs from three years to only 30 days. Following pushback from investors, the president of the upper house, Rodrigo Pacheco, suspended debates on the bill, but legislators will eventually return to it, so we will continue to monitor developments.
- Lula has halted plans to privatise big players in oil and gas, postal services and the media. He also wants to regain state control over Eletrobras, an electric power company; the state's participation in the firm was diluted to 40% in June 2022, and no single shareholder is allowed more than 10% of voting rights. Lula has sought an injunction against the privatisation, but the Supreme Federal Court (STF) is likely to block it. The current Congress is fairly market-oriented and will not want to make any changes, particularly given that many of the current legislators only recently voted to approve the privatisation.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
7.3 7.3 30 28 3 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's score in 2023-27 for policy towards foreign investment is unchanged, and the country remains one of the best performers in the region. Brazil received the third-largest haul of foreign direct investment (FDI) last year, behind the US and China, driven by reinvested earnings. Some European markets were hit by the fallout from Russia's invasion of Ukraine last year, meaning that Brazil is likely to slip down the global rankings over the medium term, but the country should still remain a top ten destination for FDI throughout 2023-27. Despite Lula's state-led economic model, Brazil still welcomes foreign investors, and opportunities will be plentiful, owing to its large market size, its diversified economy and its role in global climate and energy transition dynamics. Brazil also stands to benefit from nearshoring dynamics with the US (albeit less so than Mexico, which is geographically closer to the US) and from its reputation for being a safe location away from regions of the world where geopolitical tensions are high. Investment opportunities in infrastructure, agri-business, renewable energy and other sectors, combined with reasonable prospects for the approval of key reforms such as tax simplification, will make the country an attractive investment choice. Nevertheless, some geopolitical and fiscal risks will linger. Geopolitical risks relate to Lula's championing of a "non-aligned" foreign policy, which could cause a souring of Brazil's ties with the West. Meanwhile, despite Lula's new budget framework, public debt/GDP ratio will continue to rise, surpassing 80% within the forecast period, posing fiscal risks.
Brazil will remain in the top ten for FDI because of its policies and market size
- Over the last decade Brazilian governments have gradually improved conditions for international investment, opening up opportunities for foreign capital in important sectors such as infrastructure, transport and logistics, and energy, while simultaneously reducing taxes and streamlining bureaucracy. The law guarantees foreign investors the same treatment as domestic ones, although there are restrictions on some activities (such as nuclear energy, postal and telegraph services, the launch and deployment of satellites, the acquisition or rental of rural property, media and mining).
- Lula's efforts to make Brazil a bigger global player will be based on the country's long diplomatic tradition of neutrality on geopolitical issues, but he will be more active on this front than during his previous presidential terms (2003-10). This represents a shift away from Mr Bolsonaro's pursuit of personal alliances with a handful of right-leaning western leaders, such as the former US president, Donald Trump (2017-21). This approach, together with Mr Bolsonaro's lax stewardship of the Amazon rainforest, left Brazil isolated globally. Lula will pursue more sustainable environmental policies, broadening Brazil's appeal to more countries and helping him to advance an ESG agenda. However, walking the geopolitical tightrope in a polarised world carries risks, especially given tensions relating to the Russia-Ukraine war and deepening US-China rivalry. In particular, Lula's failure to condemn Russia and (separately) to let Iranian ships dock in Rio de Janeiro has sent mixed signals to the West regarding his positions on sensitive issues. This could weigh on trade and foreign investment ties with some countries, although the imposition of (explicit or implicit) sanctions appears unlikely. On the China issue, Lula's visit to the country in April resulted in promises of investment from Chinese companies in areas of strategic importance for the Brazilian government, not only in energy transition but also for Lula's re-industrialisation drive.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
7.8 7.8 48 52 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's score in this category remains unchanged in 2023-27, reflecting its solid trade prospects despite mixed signals about trade openness. Lula's finance minister, Fernando Haddad, is likely to reverse some of his predecessor's tax changes, including a reduction in the tax on industrial goods imports. Lula's preference for promoting trade and investment relations within the Global South, including by prioritising an inward-looking, protectionist Mercosul (the Southern Cone customs union that also includes Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay), may wipe out opportunities for more beneficial agreements with advanced economies. Brazil's accession to the OECD may suffer some delays; the Bolsonaro government began the entry process, but Lula is lukewarm about it from an ideological standpoint and will assess the requirements, meaning that it will be a slow process. Meanwhile, despite Lula's overtures regarding the EU-Mercosur free-trade agreement (FTA)-pending a review of the terms agreed by negotiators in 2019-ratification looks unlikely in 2023-27 because of political resistance in some EU countries. However, if Lula sets Brazil's export-oriented commodity sector on an ESG-friendly course, there could be a significant boost for trade.
The Lula administration will step up its efforts to strengthen Mercosul if two recent developments are anything to go by. The first is that Brazil and Argentina (the bloc's two largest players) have declared support for the creation of a common South American currency designed to facilitate the financial clearing of trade within the bloc. This is aimed at reducing vulnerability to global shocks and providing an alternative to traditional hard currencies, like the US dollar (Argentina has been suffering a dollar drought, crimping its ability to import goods from Brazil). However, even though this would not be a euro-style unification, foreign-exchange risks led to pushback from investors, making it unlikely that the initiative will advance much over the medium term. Secondly, Uruguay has been questioning the benefits of Mercosur membership more recently and has expressed a wish to sign FTAs independently of the bloc, for example with China, prompting Brazil and Argentina to review the bloc's strategies and objectives. The prospect of a China-Mercosul trade deal could encourage EU parliaments to approve the EU-Mercosur FTA and could make Lula more flexible on the terms in exchange for faster ratification. A ratified EU-Mercosul treaty could also help Brazil's OECD accession and could play well with the US, given its fears about China's growing influence in Latin America.
Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
4.7 4.7 75 77 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Because of its complexity and burden on companies, tax is one of Brazil's weakest categories, and although we expect tax reforms to pass this year, a long transition period will mean that the full benefits of simplification will only be felt beyond the 2023-27 forecast period. Meanwhile, Lula's proposals to change the income tax code will sustain uncertainty regarding tax. Brazil currently has one of the most time-consuming and complex tax systems in the world: according to World Bank data, companies in Brazil spend about 1,700 hours annually on paying their taxes-much longer than the average of 240 hours for 88 middle-income countries. At 33.7% of GDP in 2022 (according to the Treasury), Brazil's tax burden is on a par with the OECD average, but it is high by developing-country standards, and its public services and infrastructure are poor. Tax revenue comes largely from indirect taxation levied on goods and services (about 45% of the total burden; the OECD average is 32%), which pushes up production costs and weighs on Brazil's competitiveness. A huge array of sectoral benefits and tax exemptions contributes to inefficiency and hampers competition.
Tax simplification reforms are on the cards
- A tax reform agenda that Mr Bolsonaro initiated in 2021 was delayed by the 2022 general election, but the new government has taken up the issue, reflecting broad and long-standing political consensus over the need to simplify consumption taxes and make the income tax code more progressive. The tax reforms will comprise two phases. The first will focus on simplification by creating a unified value-added tax (VAT) to replace federal, state and local consumption taxes. The second will be aimed at redesigning income taxes to make them more progessive, pro-investment and levied more on individuals than on corporations. The second part may well face more resistance from legislators, especially if income tax reforms increase the burden on the middle classes or lift the overall tax burden. The VAT reform is not intended to increase the tax burden, although Lula's economic team believes that it will boost tax revenue by lifting economic growth; estimates suggest that it could increase potential GDP by 0.5% by the end of the transition period (set to last about eight years). Mr Haddad also wants to close some tax loopholes for firms, but he will encounter stiff resistance from lobby groups. One way or another, the government is banking on raising revenue to meet its target of a primary surplus of 1% of GDP by 2026 as part of its new fiscal framework-an aim that we consider overly optimistic.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
7.0 7.0 25 37 2 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's relatively good score for financing remains unchanged in 2023-27, but this lack of progress means that it is overtaken by other countries, both in the global and regional rankings. To Brazil's benefit, we expect a monetary-easing cycle to begin in August 2023, easing the tighter financing conditions that have been in place since 2022. We expect the Lula government to resume the provision of subsidised loans and credit by launching new credit lines at below-market rates through state-run banks, especially BNDES. However, fiscal constraints and high levels of indebtedness in Brazil's economy will limit the extent to which public lending can drive growth. This means that private capital markets, which have grown strongly since 2016 and had a spurt in 2020-21 owing to historically low pandemic-era interest rates, will still play an important role in Brazil's overall financing structure. In our view, increased public lending via subsidised interest rates will inject some inefficiencies and distortions, even though it will provide alternatives, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).
BCB will cut policy rates, but real rates are higher than in the past
- The BCB has taken the Selic policy rate from a record low of 2% in early 2021 to 13.75% in August 2022 to combat a surge in consumer prices that took inflation above 12%. Now that headline inflation is easing (it had fallen to 4.2% as at April, partly owing to tax cuts on fuels that were implemented in mid-2022), the government is putting pressure on the BCB to cut rates. For the time being the BCB is sticking to its hawkish stance, waiting for inflation expectations, which are still high-reflecting sticky core inflation of over 7% and lingering uncertainty over fiscal policy-to decline towards the inflation target in the relevant time horizon (12-18 months ahead). Once the upper house has joined the lower house in approving Lula's fiscal framework, uncertainty should ease, paving the way for an easing cycle that will take the Selic towards a neutral rate of 4-5% in real terms. This rate is higher than it was in 2017-22, reflecting Lula's expansionary fiscal and quasi-fiscal policies. The monetary council could raise the current inflation targets at its annual meeting in June, although we have not pencilled any changes into our forecasts yet. A higher inflation target would not necessarily open the door for lower nominal interest rates; this depends on the government's ability to restore investor confidence, which in turn depends on the progress of important reforms.
- State-run banks (especially BNDES)will once again become an important source of financing under Lula, offering new credit lines at below-market rates. Aloízio Mercadante, a PT stalwart, is the current BNDES president; he espouses a greater role for the state in the economy and intends to double the bank's lending portfolio from 1% of GDP currently to 2% by 2026-still below the unsustainable level of 4% of GDP under a former president, Dilma Rousseff (2003-11), also of the PT. Moreover, he aims to substitute the current long-term interest rate-based on long-term Treasury inflation-protected securities, which pay fixed real rates above inflation-with more flexible and less volatile rates, according to the type and duration of the investment. However, fiscal constraints, a recognition that lending from state banks under past PT governments was too high and too distortionary, and current high levels of indebtedness will all limit the use of public lending as a driver of growth.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
5.9 6.0 51 51 6 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The labour market has traditionally been one of the weakest areas of Brazil's business environment. The country's underlying score and rankings strengthen slightly in 2023-27 as participation and employment rates return to pre-pandemic levels and new legislation reduces the cost of labour. The availability of skilled labour (a long-standing weakness) will gradually improve, and levels of language skills among the workforce will rise. However, these improvements will come from a low base, and standards will remain weak by regional and global standards. Although wages are fairly low, the overall cost of labour for employers is high, as social security obligations and labour benefits add an extra third to salary costs. Moreover, unstable legislation is a risk to labour rules and contracts.
Past labour reforms will be maintained under Lula despite his misgivings
- After dipping below 8% in late 2022, unemployment has crept up, to 8.5% as at April (still substantially lower than the average unemployment rate of 12% in 2017-19). Although 1.9m jobs have been created in the past two years, the headline unemployment rate masks a drop in the workforce. However, prospects for growth in the industrial and infrastructure sectors will raise the supply of and demand for skilled labour and better-paid jobs, which will make the labour market more dynamic and vibrant over the forecast period.
- Lula and the PT have always criticised the 2017 labour reform, claiming that it caused workers' bargaining power to weaken disproportionately. Although his government has promised not to reverse the reform completely, parts of it will still come under review. For example, although the government will not try to reinstate mandatory transfers from formal workers' pay to labour unions, it may seek to strengthen contractual conditions for professionals in the gig economy to give them the same benefits that apply to formal sector workers (such as pension and health benefits, holiday leave and unemployment insurance). This would bolster worker protection in the more precarious parts of Brazil's labour market. Lula also recently announced a bill to guarantee that women are paid the same as men for the same type of job and occupation.
- The government may also seek to reduce the cost of labour in order to lessen the burden on some forms of formal labour. This could constitute part of the second phase of tax reform, which focuses on income tax and is due to reach Congress in 2023; the overall aim would be to reduce the burden levied on payroll and to increase taxation on income and profits. This would enhance the country's competitiveness and would particularly benefit labour-intensive sectors such as services, construction and retail.
- In the short term, the government will devise a rule that would resurrect one of the PT's trademark policies: to systematically ensure that minimum-wage rises outpace inflation. The rule that was in place under former PT governments involved adding the average real GDP growth rate of the past two years to the inflation rate. However, this caused wage rises to outstrip productivity gains and overall public spending to soar, given that the value of the minimum wage also serves as a reference for pensions and social benefits and therefore affects about half of the federal budget. We therefore think that the government will introduce an intermediate measure, which could involve using GDP per capita growth or introducing a real growth band in line with the new fiscal anchor to keep real growth in the minimum wage between 0.6% and 2.5% per year.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
4.8 4.8 61 70 7 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's difficulty in reversing long-standing deficiencies in infrastructure provision-partly due to fiscal constraints-keeps its score for this category very weak. Public and private infrastructure spending is low in Brazil, at about 1.9% of GDP in 2022, according to InterB (a local consultancy) and is only about half of the amount required to prevent infrastructure decay. Private concessions of infrastructure assets through the public-private partnership (PPP) programmes will probably gain momentum and will be a major driver of infrastructure upgrade efforts in 2023-27, given that the PT has generally favoured this strategy as a way of recovering investment capacity. Brazil's Investment Partnership Programme (PPI)-managed by Lula's influential chief of staff, Rui Costa, a moderate PT figure-has a portfolio of more than 200 projects and expected investments of US$180bn in various infrastructure sectors (including transport, mining and energy). Given that Lula considers infrastructure investment an important vehicle for generating jobs and raising employment, we expect him to make it a priority. His main challenge-as in many areas of the business environment-will be to resolve ideological differences between the PT and other leftist parties that support the government. We expect the moderate vice-president, Geraldo Alckmin, to play a constructive, facilitating role.
Infrastructure will suffer from fiscal constraints and ideological differences
- In particular, Lula will need to manage conflicts arising from different regional interests and views on the role of the private sector as opposed to SOEs in future concessions. This challenge became clear at the outset of his term, when investors grew concerned about setbacks to a recently approved sanitation framework (Law 14,026/2020), which paved the way for private companies to expand their participation in sanitation concessions and imposed stricter rules and targets on existing (mostly state) companies, as part of efforts to guarantee universal access to basic sanitation services by 2033. In setting out his government's organisational structure, Lula sought to transfer the ANA to the environment ministry (headed by Marina Silva, a high-profile environmentalist who held the job during Lula's first term) and strip it of its role in regulating sanitation services. Negative reactions from sectoral experts and private players prompted Lula to reverse the changes, meaning that the ANA and the sanitation framework will remain as they were (at least for now).
- Another example of the way in which ideological differences may delay the privatisation agenda relates to the Port of Santos, Brazil's biggest port, which is located in São Paulo state. The minister of ports and airports, Márcio França (a centre-left politician and former São Paulo governor), opposes privatisation, whereas the current São Paulo governor, Tarcísio de Freitas (who served as infrastructure minister under Mr Bolsonaro), favours that move. Mr Alckmin, who is also minister for development, industry, commerce and services, supports private participation in public concessions and could play a role in brokering consensus over investment projects of this kind.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
6.1 6.6 47 50 2 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's score improves in this category, but the country slips in the global and regional rankings as others improve faster. As in many countries, information and communication technology (ICT) is regarded as a strategic area, and a national Internet of Things (IoT) plan was launched in mid-2019. Global shortages of IT equipment and budget cuts have slowed the rollout, but digitalisation of government services has still advanced (particularly at the federal level), and the number of devices connected to the IoT has increased markedly, especially with the implementation of 5G network. Lula wants to develop digital markets in a more competitive environment, but also under tighter regulation.

- In 2022 the Agência Nacional de Telecomunicações (Anatel, the telecoms regulator) authorised 5G technology in Brasília (the capital). The original 5G auction (in November 2021) envisaged that all state capitals would be served by the new technology by end-July 2022, but global shortages of chips and electronic equipment have caused delays. Nevertheless, mobile and internet operators are expanding the 5G network relatively quickly, which will be crucial for IoT evolution, especially in education, medicine, agriculture and industrial automation. The government's plan is to provide 5G coverage to state capitals and cities of over 30,000 people by 2029. Currently 140 Brazilian cities have 5G access, representing 38.5% of the population. The number of active devices with an IoT connection reached 14.4bn in 2022, according IoT Analytics, a specialist consultancy. This figure is likely to double over the forecast period.
- Brazil is the region's largest market for internet users but lags Chile, Argentina and Mexico for penetration. About 81% of the population has access to the internet, although coverage is lower in rural areas (about 73%) and among the poorest Brazilians (61%), according to the government's internet steering committee. This has raised some regulatory risks for 5G auction winners, as they must meet universal coverage as determined and monitored by Anatel.

Lula wants to develop digital markets in a more competitive environment
- Lula will attempt to develop digital markets in Brazil in a more competitive environment, but also under tighter regulations. Legislation will be driven by the global debate on digital policies and will take inspiration from European law. The government will target three main areas: social media regulation (through Law 2,630/2020), which aims to curb the spread of fake news and hate speech on digital platforms; digital markets regulation (Law 2,768/2022), which seeks to create an antitrust framework for digital platforms operating in Brazil, make Anatel the oversight body and create a digital platform inspection tax; and new audiovisual regulations (Laws 8,889/2017 and 3,832/2019), which are intended to update paid TV legislation, address content quotas, enhance state control over streaming services and balance competition in the TV and streaming markets. Given that the social media legislation has the best chance of being approved out of these three areas, major online platforms are likely to be particularly affected by Lula's drive to tighten regulations in the digital space.

Online retail will come under greater oversight by the tax authorities
- Online retail surged amid covid-19, and nearly half of Brazilians now do some of their shopping online. The volume of postal remittances from abroad to Brazil (cross-border transactions) soared by nearly 40% in 2021-22, rising to about 176m, according to the tax office. Purchases from individuals to individuals up to US$50 are exempt from tax, but international e-commerce players have been using this benefit to subvert tax payments by transforming business-to-customer (B2C) sales into customer-to-customer (C2C) ones. Lula's efforts to close this loophole generated pushback from ordinary Brazilians who benefit from the current exemption, and the government has backed down. The tax authorities will increase their oversight, and red tape will become stricter, but we still expect double-digit growth in online sales (in local-currency terms) in the 2023-27 forecast period.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The new president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of the Partido dos Trabalhadores (PT), has positioned himself firmly on the left of the political spectrum since taking office in January 2023, but despite this, and although he is pursuing state-led development, he is also pursuing policies to secure fiscal sustainability and satisfy markets. Among Lula's economic priorities are to establish new fiscal rules that provide more flexibility while preserving a rules-based framework that satisfies markets, and to push through tax reforms to simplify the tax system and make it more progressive. He is seeking, too, to encourage state-led development-for example by doubling lending by the Brazilian Development Bank (BNDES) and by halting (and even trying to reverse) privatisations-and to pursue better environmental policies that facilitate more foreign investment (or at the very least reduce the risk of disinvestment).
EIU expects economic policy to be fiscally more expansionary and state-driven under Lula than under his predecessor, Jair Bolsonaro (2019-22). Although Lula recently unleashed strong verbal attacks on the governor of the Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) for keeping interest rates high, we do not expect him to try to change the bank's independent status. There is a risk, however, that Brazil's monetary council will lift the medium-term inflation targets, as Lula considers the 3% target for 2024-25 too low (it was 4.5% under PT administrations in 2003-16), although we have not pencilled in any changes to our forecasts for now. Along similar lines, the government will not pursue new privatisations and will instead interfere in state-owned enterprises (SOEs) to make them pursue its public policy goals. Political appointments to SOEs (in order to favour allies) could also weaken their governance structures.
The risk of fiscal policy becoming unsustainably expansionary has diminished, as Lula's fiscal framework envisages that spending will grow more slowly than revenue. We expect Congress to approve the legislation in June without loosening the rules (in fact, legislators are more likely to tighten them). Another priority for Lula's government in 2023 will be to pass a reform aimed at simplifying Brazil's burdensome tax system (prospects for which are reasonable) and at making it more progressive (which will be trickier). Tax simplification would buoy business sentiment, although the full benefits would not be felt immediately, as many of the changes would be introduced gradually. Although new privatisations are not on the horizon, we expect progress on infrastructure concessions to continue. Lula is unlikely to try to overhaul a 2017 reform that made labour legislation more flexible, although his government will seek targeted changes, such as expanding benefits for autonomous, remote and informal workers.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)

Public-sector revenue 39.3 39.0 39.6 39.6 39.6 39.6

Total public-sector debt 72.9 76.3 78.7 79.9 80.8 80.5
The government needs to revise the fiscal rules and enact tax reform this year to put the public finances on a sustainable path and satisfy markets while still making sure that it has enough resources to pursue some policy priorities. We think that Congress will approve the proposed new fiscal framework by mid-year. This would replace Brazil's rigid public-spending cap rules with a more flexible fiscal framework that would allow federal expenditure to rise in real terms by up to 70% of revenue growth.
The fiscal framework includes targets for reducing the primary balance to zero in 2024 and then generating surpluses of 0.5% and 1% of GDP in 2025 and 2026 respectively. The targets carry a tolerance range of 0.25% of GDP, which should improve budget management by avoiding disorderly year-end adjustments. However, we think that the government's revenue projections are overly optimistic. The finance minister, Fernando Haddad, has said that he will not increase taxes or introduce new ones, but will instead raise revenue (to the tune of 1.5% of GDP next year) by closing loopholes and enacting other measures. We are sceptical about his chances of success, and our fiscal forecasts assume that he will raise less than half of what he envisages.
We expect other tax reforms to pass this year. These are likely to involve simplifying the tax code by unifying several sales taxes into something resembling a single value-added tax (VAT), and making the tax regime more progressive by raising the personal income tax threshold. The government also wants to introduce a tax on dividends, and will possibly make other revenue-raising tweaks. The impact of these on the tax take is still unclear (not least because Congress is reluctant to back tax increases), but our assumption is that any revenue-raising measures will generate about half of the extra spending approved for 2023 (and for subsequent years). On that basis, we forecast that the government will miss its primary balance targets and that the public debt/GDP ratio will rise to 80% by 2027. Given Brazil's heavy debt burden, fiscal policy will remain the principal source of macroeconomic risk, although low public external indebtedness means that a debt crisis would evolve as an inflationary problem rather than an external debt default.

We expect the BCB to keep the Selic rate at 13.75% until it embarks on an easing cycle in August. There is a risk that the BCB will keep rates higher for longer, as investor concerns about possible changes to the medium-term inflation targets (which are currently set to fall from 3.25% in 2023 to 3% in 2024 and beyond) are keeping medium-term inflation expectations above target. Under pressure from Lula, the monetary council may well raise the targets to 3.5-4.5% at its annual target-setting meeting in June. If confidence weakens enough to trigger substantial currency depreciation, inflationary pressures will reassert themselves, probably prompting further monetary tightening. However, our baseline scenario is that policy normalisation will bring the real rate down to 4-5% over 2024-27, implying a Selic rate of 8-9%.

Brazil's real GDP growth will slow from 2.9% in 2022 to 1.7% in 2023 as an economic deceleration in the US and Europe, elevated domestic interest rates and still-high inflation outweigh stronger commodity demand from China. Brazil's economic data and labour dynamics so far this year have been more resilient than we had anticipated, although we still expect the economy to slow in an environment of tight credit conditions, until monetary easing begins later this year. These factors will limit household consumption and investment, and the deterioration in fiscal dynamics will constrain government spending.
Assuming that the global economy recovers from 2024, we expect Brazil's growth to average 1.8% annually in 2024-27, below the averages for Latin American and emerging markets. Higher social spending and minimum-wage rises will put a floor under private consumption and support GDP growth, but fiscal and debt dynamics will not be strong enough to bring down local financing costs substantially, weighing on investment. Although this will be partly offset by higher state-bank lending, if Lula's interventionist policies create more market distortions than we anticipate, growth will come in below these expectations.
On the supply side, agriculture and mining exports will rise in line with the increase in global demand over the 2023-27 forecast period. Manufacturing and services growth will slow in 2023, owing to high interest rates and weak consumption, before picking up thereafter. As the boost from Brazil's post-pandemic economic reopening is now over, services will expand more modestly, following consumption trends.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends The agriculture sector is more important than its small share of GDP (7.7% in 2022) suggests, owing to its significance as an employer in rural areas and the importance of agri-business industries for the domestic market and exports. Favourable weather and investments led to record grains harvests of about 273m tonnes in 2021/22. The sector will remain vulnerable to adverse weather (particularly the cyclical El Niño weather phenomenon in 2023/24) but will benefit from technological improvements and more intensive land use, as well as from good fundamentals for soft-commodity exports, owing to rising demand in the developing world.
El Niño poses risks to agricultural output for the 2023/24 harvest After drought conditions caused agricultural output to contract in 2020/21, the 2021/22 harvest broke records, even though the Russia-Ukraine war put pressure on global supply chains and raised fertiliser costs (Russia has traditionally been a major supplier for Brazil). Although war-related supply-chain constraints still exist, the initial shock has faded, and the government has been able to secure sufficient supplies of fertilisers. As a result, the Companhia Nacional de Abastecimento (Conab, the supply company) forecasts that the 2022/23 harvest will increase by 15%, to a new record of 314m tonnes, despite El Niño weather conditions. Our baseline assumption is that, although the El Niño phenomenon will develop, it will not curb agricultural output significantly in the 2023/24 harvest. However, we note the risk that El Niño's effects prove stronger than we expect, bringing drought to the North and Northeast regions and heavy rains to the South. Depending on their intensity, those conditions could subdue agricultural output 2023/24.
The Lula administration understands the importance of agriculture to the Brazilian economy and will support its growth. However, the government's ambitions to strengthen environmental policy will create some nodes of divergence with the agricultural sector. One of these relates to deforestation, which is practised legally and illegally as a way of preparing and expanding crop and pasture areas. According to MapBiomas, a local environmental non-governmental organisation, 96% of legal and illegal deforestation in Brazil in 2022 was directly or indirectly caused by agriculture. Lula's efforts to step up monitoring to prevent illegal deforestation will delay the authorisation process for legal deforestation and therefore pose a downside risk to agricultural output.
Land reform is another contentious area. In the first months of 2023 the Movimento dos Trabalhadores Rurais Sem Terra (MST, a group of rural workers who advocate for land redistribution) occupied several properties that it deemed unproductive. To appease the MST (a PT constituency), the Lula administration has announced a mini land-redistribution programme. Although details have not yet been announced, the government guarantees that it will respect private property, as it will only distribute land that has already been expropriated and has not yet been directed for land reform (Mr Bolsonaro halted all land redistributions). Lula's proximity to the MST is likely to revive the movement, but we expect him to remain pragmatic as he seeks to balance the group's interests with those of the agri-business sector.
Manufacturing will be constrained by competitiveness weaknesses The outlook for manufacturing is clouded by poor competitiveness-an issue that has plagued the sector for many years and has caused its share of total GDP to fall from 15% in 2000 to 11% currently. This decline is partly due to import competition-the Real was overvalued in 2005-12, during the commodity boom-and also reflects Brazil's high interest rates. Persistent weaknesses in the manufacturing industry include a heavy tax burden, poor infrastructure and high labour costs.
Light manufacturing in particular has lost market share in recent years, owing to a surge in Chinese imports. Capital goods industries have faced similar problems but will be buoyed by domestic demand. Higher investment will enable some labour-intensive manufacturing activities to move up the value chain, but many will struggle to cope with rising import competition. Brazil's manufacturing sector has been mostly inward-looking and most firms have failed to develop linkages with global production chains. Nearshoring in Brazil has been limited. The country's distance from developed markets makes it a less attractive nearshoring option than Mexico, for example, which has a similarly sophisticated industrial complex but benefits from geographical proximity to the US.
The vehicles and parts industry, which accounts for about one-fifth of manufacturing and provides employment for about 1.2m people, has been facing rough conditions amid global semiconductor shortages that began in 2021 and will keep production subdued this year. The Associação Nacional dos Fabricantes de Veículos Automotores (Anfavea, the automotive industry body) estimates that the shortage caused a loss in production of about 300,000 units last year, as global automakers allocated scarce supplies to their home markets and to markets with higher profit margins. We expect Brazil's annual vehicle output to recover to 2019 levels by 2024, but it will remain far below the 2012 peak of 3.4m units as the semiconductor shortage continues. The electric-vehicle (EV) subsector is still nascent in Brazil; production is limited to commercial vehicles, batteries and some parts. However, there is significant investment in the sector, including US$600m from China's BYD (the world's largest electric car-maker), which aims to establish a manufacturing plant for electric passenger and commercial vehicles in Brazil by end-2024.
Extractive industries will continue to perform reasonably well in the medium term. China's economic reopening (following the lifting of its zero-covid policy) will support mining activity (notably iron ore) in the short term, but that country's secular economic slowdown will dampen the long-term outlook for Brazil's export commodities. Reforms to the mining law in 2018 that increased royalties for the government and improved the regulatory framework will boost investment in other mining activities. In 2022 the government eased regulations on lithium (which was previously considered a strategic metal), making exports of lithium viable. Brazil currently accounts for about 1.5% of global lithium production, but the Serviço Geológico do Brasil (SGB, the geological service) projects that the country could raise its share to 5% over the next ten years.
Investment into oil and gas will continue to boost the sector's growth Huge oil and gas reserves could turn Brazil into one of the world's top ten oil exporters. According to BP's 2022 Statistical Review of World Energy, Brazil had the second-largest oil reserves in South America as at end-2020, with 11.9bn barrels, or 0.7% of the global total (after Venezuela, with 303.8bn barrels, or 17.5% of the total). We estimate that Brazil's output of crude oil and natural gas liquids (NGLs) increased by 4.4% year on year in 2022, to 3.8m barrels/day. Petrobras, the state-controlled oil firm, is the market leader; it accounted for more than 90% of Brazilian oil production in 2022. In 2022 Brazil had 19 refineries with a combined capacity of 2.4m b/d and actual refined oil output of 1.9m b/d. Under Mr Bolsonaro, Petrobras committed to divesting eight of its 13 refineries by end-2021, but by November 2022 the company had sold just one. Lula will halt these privatisation efforts, owing to his preference for statist economic policies. We expect oil and gas production to surge later in the forecast period, boosted by significant investments in Brazil's offshore pre-salt areas (where significant reserves are held beneath thick layers of salt under the seabed).
Services sector is unlikely to recover much dynamism The services sector is unlikely to recover much dynamism in the medium term, as it is impaired by low productivity and skills shortages. However, retail, financial services, ICT and trade will outperform the sector's average in the medium term.
Retail sales volume growth will be muted in 2023, owing to high interest rates and the lifting of tax breaks that were introduced in 2021-22. The picture will improve slightly in the second half of the year as interest rates and inflation ease, but more robust growth can only be expected after 2024 as economic conditions improve. Many consumers have traded down in recent years but will continue to shop across different channels, which poses challenges for retailers. Convenience stores will remain popular across income groups in urban areas, but young adults are increasingly making purchases using mobile internet devices.

Inflation has subsided in Brazil, but remains above target, and further disinflation is unlikely in the near term. Core inflation is still running at more than 7%, and future inflation expectations are adrift of targets. Moreover, some pre-election tax cuts in July-September 2022 will be reversed; as this decline in prices works its way out of the 12-month series, inflation will actually rise from 4.2% in April to 5.8% at end-2023, before dipping below 4% after end-2024. However, there are risks to this forecast, owing to investor concerns that the monetary council may raise its inflation targets, which would lift inflation expectations. In the event of an upward revision, we would promptly lift our inflation forecasts for the remaining years of the outlook period, to 4-5%.

The Real has been volatile in recent months, owing to various local and global developments, although it has strengthened since the government unveiled its fiscal framework proposals in March, as its intention to retain caps on spending growth calmed investor jitters about the risk of fiscal expansion. The bigger picture is that US dollar strength appears to have peaked as the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) pauses its tightening cycle, helping the value of other currencies. Support from the carry trade will fade as the Selic rate declines, which means that, having strengthened from R5.2:US$1 at end-2022 to R5:US$1 on May 18th, we expect the Real to weaken slightly in the second half of the year. If an upward revision to inflation targets raises expectations and outcomes considerably, the currency will weaken more than we envisage. If, however, any adjustments to the targets are marginal and the government delivers stronger primary balances than we expect, the Real could appreciate more markedly. Overall, we anticipate that the Real will strengthen modestly in the 2023-27 forecast period, albeit with bouts of volatility.

Lower commodity prices and higher imports will erode Brazil's trade surplus, which was inflated in 2022 by surging oil and soybean prices. This will cause the current-account deficit to expand from 2.6% of GDP in 2023 to an average of 3.1% of GDP in 2025-27. Firm foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will cover the shortfall, reflecting sizeable market opportunities. Brazil's structural trade surplus (stemming from its huge agricultural exports), modest external debt ratio and comfortable reserves cushion will limit risks to the external position. Public external debt is low, and most firms have some sort of currency hedge, despite moderate private external debt. Exports of agri-goods and minerals to China and other countries will keep the trade account in surplus throughout 2023-27.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Brazil Stocks and flows Brazil is one of the largest recipients of foreign direct investment (FDI) in Latin America and ranks among the top ten in the world. In 2022 total FDI inflows (including intercompany transfers and reinvested profits) jumped to an estimated US$91.5bn, or 4.8% of GDP. The 2022 figure is the highest since 2014 (the peak of the boom years), when inflows totalled US$96.9bn. Total FDI inflows fell to an average of US$74bn in 2015-19, before plummeting further in the 2020-21 pandemic years, to an average of US$42bn. By end-2022 the FDI stock had reached an estimated US$1trn (54% of GDP).
Origin and distribution US and European companies (together accounting for 78% of total FDI inflows in 2022) have traditionally been the biggest investors, but Chinese companies have entered the market in recent years, acquiring assets in electricity, infrastructure, oil and services, taking that country's share of total FDI inflows from 0.9% in 2012 to 2.6% in 2022. Other countries that invest significantly in Brazil are Singapore, Chile, Uruguay and Japan. Inward FDI is fairly well distributed across agriculture (1.3% of total FDI inflows in 2022), extractive industries (13%), manufacturing (42%) and services (44%), reflecting opportunities in Brazil's broad-based economy.
Determinants Brazil's attractiveness to foreign investors has generally rested on the combination of its market size, macroeconomic stability, richness of natural resources and diversified industrial base. The country is a major global player in agri-business, mineral commodities and bioenergy. However, its complex tax system, relatively unstable legal framework and high borrowing costs have precluded higher inflows of FDI.
Impact FDI has played an increasingly prominent role in recent infrastructure concessions and in pre-salt oil rounds. In this sense, FDI is an important success factor in the promotion of capital productivity and sustained long-term growth. From a balance-of-payments perspective, FDI has fully covered the current-account deficit in recent years, allowing a healthy and balanced exchange between Brazil and the rest of the world. Although it is hard to measure the direct effects of FDI on productivity, it is clear that there is a positive correlation between the presence of international companies operating in Brazil and research and development activity: patents for inventions filed by non-residents through Brazilian offices reached 19,566 in 2021, far exceeding the 4,666 patents filed by residents.
Potential Brazil will remain an attractive destination for foreign investors in EIU's 2023-27 forecast period owing to its large market, but the favourable external environment last year-a product of high commodity prices, which buoyed interest in the country's export-oriented extractive industries and agriculture-will turn less supportive as commodity prices soften. We expect the government to pass tax reform within the forecast period, combining separate federal, state and municipal taxes into a single value-added tax (VAT). This should dramatically simplify the country's complex tax system-considered one of the major barriers to investment. However, FDI inflows will remain below potential, as privatisation opportunities have evaporated now that Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has returned to the presidency. There is a risk that Lula could reverse some important privatisations (such as that of Eletrobras, a power firm), although this is not our baseline assumption.

An ageing population-the result of a declining birth rate and increasing life expectancy-will dampen Brazil's GDP growth potential. Preliminary results from the 2022 census (the scheduled 2020 census was delayed because of the covid-19 pandemic) show that adverse demographic trends have accelerated since the last census, which was taken in 2010. The census puts the population at 207.8m in 2022, much lower than the 214.8m previously estimated by the national statistics institute (IBGE). Final census results are due to be released at end-June; if the difference of 7m people is confirmed, there would be significant demographic implications that would affect EIU's long-term GDP growth forecasts.
A rising old-age dependency ratio will put pressure on Brazil's pension system Brazil's demographic dividend will end soon, which will oblige the government to tackle the fiscal burden of an ageing population. There were 49.1m people in the country aged 0-14 (25.2% of the population) in 2010. We estimate that the share of the population in that age bracket had fallen by 4.7 percentage points, to 44m (20.5% of the population), by 2022. Over the same period the share of elderly people (those aged over 65) rose from 6.8% to 9.6%. Based on our current projections, the share of the population in that bracket will increase by another 1.8 percentage points, to 12% by 2027. For comparison, the OECD average for the share of the population aged over 65 will rise from 18% in 2022 to 19.8% in 2027.
The ratio of the working-age population (15-64 years) to the total population is peaking; it has risen from 68% in 2010 to 69.9% in 2022, but we expect it to slip to 68.7% in 2027; as a result, we forecast that the old-age dependency ratio (the ratio of elderly people to working-age people) will reach 18% in 2027, from 15% in 2022. For comparison, the old-age dependency ratio for the average OECD country will rise from an estimated 32.4% in 2022 to 36.2% in 2027. This means that Brazilian workers will come under much stronger pressure to finance the increasing number of pension beneficiaries. Productivity gains in the labour market will be insufficient to make up for this extra burden, as the education and skills levels of the workforce are low, and are unlikely to improve significantly over the next decade.
Solving the pension system imbalance by raising taxes or through labour contributions would be costly and counterproductive. Brazil's tax burden is already heavy; additional tax increases would raise production costs, reduce the unemployment rate and ultimately limit consumption growth and revenue collection. In sum, Brazil's demographic transition will challenge the fiscal and financial sustainability of the country's current pay-as-you-go pension system, even after a landmark pension reform that was passed in 2019. Another attempt at reform-to either the raise retirement age, cut benefits or both-will be needed in the next five to ten years and will raise the risk of social unrest.
The growing share of older people will weigh on the public healthcare system Population ageing affects not only the social security system, but also the healthcare system, as it increases medical and hospital costs. Brazil has one of the largest public healthcare systems in the world. The 1988 constitution made healthcare universal and decentralised (basic care is the responsibility of municipalities, and more intensive and complex procedures fall under the purview of Brazil's states). However, even before covid-19, the system was overstretched owing to growing demand, particularly after the 2014-16 economic crisis, when many people migrated from private healthcare insurance (mostly through company schemes) to public health services. Population ageing will exacerbate the situation, stretching already-thin budgets.
Labour productivity needs to rise to compensate for demographic trends Given the speed of the demographic transition and the pressure that it will put on the pension and healthcare systems, labour productivity would have to rise significantly in the long term to compensate for the rising old-age dependency ratio. The education system remains precarious and is unable to produce enough skilled workers, even though Brazil spends 6% of its GDP on education (above the OECD average of 3.4% of GDP in 2019). Immigration could go some way towards offsetting population ageing, but the government has not laid out any policies to attract skilled labour and is unlikely to do so in the near future. Most recent immigrants to Brazil (primarily from South Korea, China, Bolivia, Haiti and Venezuela) have been absorbed into low-skilled roles in the retail sector, rather than into industry, where most demand for high-skilled labour is to be found.

Brazil fell out of the list of the world's top ten largest economies (at market exchange rates) in 2020 owing to the covid-19 pandemic; however, EIU expects it to return to this elite group in 2024. Brazil's GDP recovered to just under US$2.1trn in 2023, making it the world's eleventh-biggest economy, behind Canada. Based on a population of about 210m people (the seventh-largest population globally), we forecast that GDP per head will come in at US$9,890 (at market exchange rates) in 2023. We expect GDP per head measured by market rates to exceed US$10,000 by 2024, making Brazil an upper-middle-income country and the 60th-70th richest in the world (depending on the metrics used).
When measured in purchasing power parity (PPP) terms, per-head income is higher and will rise from US$19,580 in 2023 to US$22,430 by 2027. The divergence between GDP per head measured by market rates and by purchasing power parity reflects the fact that, in emerging economies such as Brazil, lower wages make prices of services and non-traded goods relatively cheap by comparison with richer countries. Given that services represent more than 70% of GDP, per-head income measured by the PPP exchange rate tends to be higher than at the market exchange rate.
Household consumption is high, but savings are low The relatively low median personal disposable income (forecast at US$1,453 in 2023) results in a high marginal propensity to spend more and save less. According to a 2023 study by the Associação Brasileira das Entidades dos Mercados Financeiro e de Capitais (Anbima, the financial and capital markets association), 63.8% of Brazilians do not have any financial investments, a rise from 56% in 2019, as the pandemic prompted households to liquidate investments. The high share of income diverted to consumption means that household consumption represents about 63% of the country's total GDP. Government consumption is fairly high for a developing country, at nearly 18% of GDP. Meanwhile, savings and investments are low, with gross fixed investments representing only 18% of GDP. Even in families who save some of their income, most allocate it in conservative instruments, primarily savings accounts with low or below-inflation interest rates (real savings interest rates are negative). A lack of knowledge about financial products also explains the low levels of savings; most families do not receive much extra income from financial returns.
Low savings rates stifle local investment resources Low levels of savings reduce the amount of financial guarantees and collateral that households can use to borrow from banks. This is partly why total domestic credit extended by banks to the private sector represents nearly 70% of GDP in Brazil. Consumption is concentrated on goods and services that are less dependent on credit, such as non-durable goods (food and beverages, and health and beauty products) and semi-durable goods (clothing, household goods and electronic equipment). Consumption of durable goods, such as automobiles and housing (which often rely on access to financing), have been dependent on government stimulus programmes, as illustrated in consumer and credit trends during the boom and bust cycle of 2003-14. These patterns are also reflected in e-commerce. Even though the covid-19 pandemic has propelled digital growth, consumer behaviour has changed little. The share of online retail sales in total retail sales has been increasing gradually, from 5.2% in 2019 to a forecast 6.5% in 2023. We expect this trend to continue, with online sales accounting for 7.3% the total by the end of our 2023-27 forecast period. Online purchases of groceries and staples will drive much of this growth.

Corporate and household balance sheets will suffer amid a tepid recovery The complete reopening of the economy and spending prior to the 2022 general election helped GDP to expand by 2.9% in 2022, but a global economic slowdown and fiscal constraints will cause growth to ease to 1.7% this year. Pronounced income disparities make for regional variation in growth dynamics. Brazil is made up of 26 states-plus the capital district of Brasília-divided into five regions. The wealthy southern states will do better than the rest, given that they specialise in agro-industry, which will hold up better than manufacturing and services. Similarly, the Centre-West-Brazil's agricultural belt-specialises in livestock, grains (soybean and corn) and cotton, which will be resilient in the long term. The Southeast region, home to Brazil's largest city, São Paulo, will benefit from its diversified industrial, agricultural and services base. Meanwhile, the poorer North and Northeast regions will suffer from a lack of skilled labour and weak infrastructure, although the industrial production of durable and semi-durable goods in the Manaus Free-Trade Zone (in the North) and agriculture and mining (in the Northeast) will support growth.

EIU expects Brazil's annual GDP growth to slip to 1.7% on average in the long-term forecast period (2031-50), largely owing to the end of the country's demographic dividend. Growth will therefore be much weaker than in 1991-2014, when a low base (following a recession and a period of hyperinflation in the 1980s) and the commodities boom of the 2000s and 2010s produced average growth of 3%. Our growth forecast for 2031-50 assumes that labour productivity growth will accelerate beyond recent historical levels but that it will be offset by worsening demographic factors. Our model also assumes that growth in the capital stock and in total factor productivity will accelerate amid improvements in innovation and technology. Faster growth could be achieved if policy improvements and structural reforms exceed expectations.
Initial conditions: Brazil has vast natural resource potential and a young labour force, but structural constraints-including weak political effectiveness, generally low levels of education and skills, income disparities, low savings rates, chronic underinvestment in infrastructure and heavy public debt-will erode these advantages. Other than in the agricultural sector, productivity growth has been disappointing in recent years, even though the manufacturing sector took advantage of exchange-rate appreciation during the boom years to increase imports of more advanced machinery and equipment. Gradual improvements in the quality and availability of primary and secondary education, as well as efforts to address infrastructure deficiencies, simplify the convoluted tax system and reduce red tape, will underpin stronger productivity growth in the long term. Our projections are based on the expectation that a commitment to macroeconomic discipline will prevail.
Demographic trends: Brazil's demographic dividend is close to ending, and policymakers will therefore have to address the fiscal burden of an ageing population. Brazil's demographic profile will become less supportive of growth prospects as the population ages, but the median age of the population will still be low compared with the US, western European countries and Japan. Population growth will begin to outpace working-age growth early in the 2020s, meaning that policymakers will need to revise the pension system in order to alleviate the burden on the public finances.
External conditions: Brazil's economy is exposed to changes in external financial market conditions owing to its low domestic savings rates, and the volume of external capital inflows is strongly correlated with risk aversion. Although the public sector has been cautious about external borrowing, corporates have borrowed overseas and can be affected by sudden stops in capital flows. Progress on increasing trade openness and diversifying export partners will allow the country to benefit from global trade growth. Brazil's strong competitive advantage in agricultural production and its large industrial export base provide some insulation from commodity price shocks. Global trade liberalisation is unlikely to make much headway; combined with rising international pressure to contain deforestation, this will prevent Brazil from realising its full export potential, particularly in the agricultural sector.
Institutions and policy trends: Brazil's democracy has strengthened since the reinstatement of civilian rule in 1985. However, many political institutions are still ineffective, and the political spectrum is fragmented into several relatively weak parties, producing a legislature that is dominated by vested interests. The situation will improve slightly, assuming that efforts to enhance party loyalty and electoral measures to reduce the number of political parties in Congress eventually materialise. Fiscal pressures will mount, despite efforts to pass reforms to cap the growth of spending related to benefits and entitlements enshrined in the 1988 constitution, especially as the population ages. Tax revenue is already high, at 25% of GDP, which means that adjusting the public finances to stabilise and reduce Brazil's high public debt/GDP ratio (estimated at 72.9% in 2022) will prove challenging. A heavy debt burden will keep interest payments high, crowding out the private sector. Our long-term growth forecasts assume slow improvements in the business environment through the gradual (albeit uneven) implementation of structural reforms, which will help to compensate for other constraints on GDP growth, including the convoluted tax system, infrastructure shortcomings and labour market weaknesses. We expect these measures to start to improve Brazil's relative attractiveness for investors only after 2030.
Long-term performance: Brazil will struggle to gain much ground on the US; its GDP per head (in US dollars at purchasing power parity) will amount to 25% of the US's figure in 2050. Although macroeconomic stability will reduce volatility in economic growth, our forecast for GDP expansion of a lacklustre 1.7% per year in the 2023-50 long-term forecast period will be weaker than the average in 1991-2014 (3%). Improvements in infrastructure, trade expansion, a broader presence of multinational businesses and a reduction in the debt-service burden will mitigate slower labour force growth and should help to lift labour productivity growth. However, this depends on progress in the politically difficult process of structural and institutional reforms.
Our outlook is based on the assumption that governments remain broadly committed to pushing through changes in the long term: otherwise, productivity growth and average GDP growth rates will fall short of our already-lacklustre forecasts. The country's political system makes it hard to advance structural reforms. Political reforms could improve the situation, although these appear intractable. Given that our forecasts already account for the commercial exploitation of the proceeds of Brazil's huge reserves of deepwater oil, major setbacks in this regard would pose a downside risk to our projections. Our forecasts now capture the impact of climate change; we believe that Brazil's GDP in 2050 will be 4% smaller than it would have been without this constraint on growth.
