Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Environmental protection is back on track, but risks remain Climate change will increase the frequency and severity of weather events, be they droughts or floods. For Brazil, adverse weather conditions will directly affect long-term growth in view of the importance of agriculture to the economy. Industry and services are also at risk; as seen in 2020-21, severe droughts can disrupt activity, given that hydroelectric power accounts for a large share (nearly 57%) of Brazil's energy matrix. In addition, more than a quarter of the Brazilian population lives on the coast, meaning that rising sea levels could cause mass migration and catastrophic infrastructure damage. As home to 60% of the Amazon (the world's largest rainforest), Brazil has a leading role in combating climate change-a mantle that it has taken up again with the return of the left-wing president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, to power in January 2023.
Lula is reversing the anti-environmental policies of his far-right predecessor, Jair Bolsonaro (2019-22), and has promised to eliminate illegal deforestation by 2030. To that end, Lula has reinforced monitoring and introduced punitive measures against those engaging in illegal deforestation. Early indications are that his efforts are paying off; according to the Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (INPE, the space research institute), illegal deforestation in the Amazon region had declined by 40% in January-April 2023 from the same period a year earlier.
Lula's other measures to reduce deforestation include re-establishing the Amazon Fund (suspended in 2019), through which some Western countries sponsor the preservation of the rainforest. He also has removed expenditure related to international donations for the environment from his new fiscal spending cap rules and is increasing the number of public servants in important environmental agencies.
The international community has welcomed Lula's efforts, and European countries now appear more interest in moving ahead with the long-delayed free-trade agreement between the EU and Mercosul (the Southern Cone customs bloc, of which Brazil is a leading member). Another boost for Lula's environmental credentials came with the selection of Belém, the capital of Pará state (in the Amazon region), as the host for the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP30) conference, which will take place in 2025. This will be Brazil's first opportunity to host a COP summit and symbolises the country's return to the international stage as an important actor in the fight against climate change.
EIU expects Lula to take a more pragmatic approach to Brazil's critical agricultural sector by promoting a more sustainable environmental agenda while still supporting agri-business. However, risks to Lula's support for the agricultural sector have risen following land invasions by the Movimento dos Trabalhadores Rurais Sem Terra (MST, a group of rural workers who advocate for land redistribution) in early 2023. Given that the MST is an important constituency for Lula's party, he may make further concessions to them, or their movement may gain momentum, raising risks to political stability. However, these invasions have antagonised the agriculture sector; if actions like this continue, Lula may come under pressure to loosen environmental regulations.
New innovations in fintech offer opportunities for growth and financial inclusion A technological revolution in Brazil's financial sector will support the country's long-term growth and open up new avenues for innovation in e-commerce. Open-banking reforms and the launch of Pix (an electronic payments system) in November 2020 by the Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) will provide opportunities for increased competition in Brazil's highly concentrated banking system and promote financial inclusion.
The BCB has made financial inclusion and competition central pillars of its agenda. There are now about 148m Pix user accounts-a sign of strong demand-and the daily average volume of transactions in April was about R40bn (US$7.8bn). Pix, which allows individuals to make instant digital payments and money transfers for free (companies pay a small fee), will dent traditional bank profits by almost eliminating fees from wire transfers, still widely used in Brazil.
Another important development since the pandemic has been a decrease in the unbanked population-from 22.7m at end-2019 to about 20m as at January 2023, according to the BCB-as more than 40m Brazilians received covid-19 assistance payments digitally, through their Caixa Econômica Federal bank accounts. The unbanked population will continue shrinking as the shift to digital payment and banking services facilitates access. Rather than stoking zero-sum competition between brick-and-mortar operations and digital start-ups, the implementation of open banking should drive synergies between the two as traditional banks share data and collaborate with third-party institutions. The star of the fintech scene in Brazil has been Nubank, a digital bank. Having started as a provider of no-fee credit cards, it is now a full bank offering current accounts, loans and investment products. Nubank had 80m customers across Brazil, Mexico and Colombia as at April 2023; Morgan Stanley (a US bank) projects a dramatic compound annual revenue growth rate of 68% through to 2025.
Looking ahead, open-banking regulations are likely to follow, and the BCB governor, Roberto Campos Neto, has gone so far as to suggest the creation of a digital currency. Nonetheless, there are some risks to that should be considered. Fintech firms, which have been allowed to provide direct credit services since 2018, may not have the risk management systems and practices in place that incumbent financial firms have, which could present risks to financial stability. Indeed, Nubank's non-performing loan (NPL) ratio reached 5.5% in March, whereas the national rate stood at 3.3%. Moreover, increased digitalisation and connectivity expose operators and consumers to cyber-security risk; active risk management is required so that cyber-security measures are commensurate with the underlying risk. In March 2022 the BCB issued a new set of fintech regulations covering payment firms-its first update to important rules for the sector in nine years to spur competition in the space and rein in riskier business structures.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; unless otherwise stated, EIU is the source for all forecast data
Global data Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Oil prices: Dated Brent import price
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
US consumer price inflation: OECD
US$ effective exchange rate: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments: IFS, various issues
Budget balance: refers to nominal public-sector borrowing requirement
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Demographic indicators: IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
Exchange rate: IFS, various issues; market rates expressed as Reals per US$1
GDP growth by demand component: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; 1995 prices
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: UNCTAD, World Investment Report; IFS
Inflation: Índice de Preços ao Consumidor Ampliado (IPCA, a national consumer price index based on surveys in ten cities, December 1993=100), calculated by the IBGE; IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Brazil to prices in the US
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average PPP for tradeable products to annual average exchange rate
Real GDP growth per head: growth in real GDP divided by population growth
Total external debt: sum of long-term and short-term debt, plus arrears; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS, various issues; local currency GDP, converted to US$ at the estimated annual average PPP for consumer products
US$ GDP: IFS, various issues; in current prices, converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rates
Abbreviations FGV: Fundação Getúlio Vargas
IBGE: Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística
IFS: IMF, International Financial Statistics
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows EIU to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by EIU for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2018-22) and from EIU assessments for the forecast period (2023-27). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by EIU for 2018-22. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2023-27 are based on EIU assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; EIU, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2018-22 ranges are then used to derive 2023-27 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2023-27, not to the likely situation in 2027 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2020 or 2025). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Ecuador&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Ecuador+2nd+Quarter+2023&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2023-04-06&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Ecuador&amp;rft.issn=09669515&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - EIU expects the president, Guillermo Lasso of the centre-right Creando Oportunidades (Creo) party, to govern as a lame duck until his term ends in 2025. However, the risk of him leaving office early is very high, given a hostile opposition in the unicameral National Assembly (in which Creo has a legislative minority) and strong social discontent. Mr Lasso could pre-empt a move to oust him by using a constitutional provision to dissolve the legislature, but that would trigger an early general election (and probably protests too). Even assuming that he remains in power, progress on his market-friendly policy agenda will slow to a crawl, given his weak political mandate. We expect his successor to encounter similar challenges-namely a weak, fragmented party system and social unrest-in advancing their agenda. Moreover, there is a high risk that the next administration will be less fiscally disciplined. These factors will keep political instability high in the 2023-27 forecast period.

- Ecuador's performance in our business environment rankings improves only modestly in 2023-27, reflecting the stagnation of progress on Mr Lasso's reform agenda amid political and social turmoil. Strident opposition from well-organised indigenous groups and the opposition-dominated Congress will severely constrain attempts to implement market-friendly reforms. Structural weaknesses, such as inadequate access to local finance and Ecuador's small market size, will also prove limiting factors and will be difficult for the government to tackle.

- Ecuador's real GDP growth will slow to 1.3% in 2023. Private consumption expansion will soften as higher domestic interest rates weigh on consumer credit and a global slowdown subdues remittances growth. The government's budgetary constraints will also limit public consumption and investment. The recovery in 2024-27 will be mild, with growth averaging 2% per year; policy uncertainty and stretched public finances will weigh on investment, limiting employment and private consumption growth. Dollarisation provides a basis for macroeconomic stability and will help to keep inflation low, but a more robust economic growth trajectory is unlikely without a significant increase in private-sector investment. The government will continue fiscal consolidation efforts, but public debt will remain burdensome, and political instability will sustain risks that fiscal prudence is abandoned, which could in turn make it difficult to secure external financing.

Labour force growth will still outstrip population growth, sustaining a demographic dividend throughout the forecast period. However, this trend will weaken over the next decade, complicating prospects for Ecuador's convergence with more developed economies in the region.

- Ecuador is one of the smaller markets in our business environment rankings. The slow recovery of the domestic market from the pandemic-induced recession is unlikely to pick up significantly, as there are signs of permanent damage to household incomes (they only surpassed 2019 levels in 2022). Significant mineral reserves will attract oil and mining investors, but opportunities outside these sectors will remain restricted by low purchasing power (in terms of GDP per head). Persistent income inequality and poverty will also hinder robust growth in household consumption.

- Low levels of productivity and a wealth of natural resources offer scope for Ecuador's GDP per head to catch up with more developed countries, provided that policies are implemented to transform its resource wealth into productive investment in other sectors. Ecuador will benefit from its dollarised system and from incremental improvements to the business environment. However, the prospects for strengthening institutions are meagre, which bodes poorly for a more stable economic policy direction. Assuming that structural weaknesses, obstacles to governability and inconsistent policymaking continue to present challenges, long-term investment will be low and incomes will remain below OECD levels.

Background: Ecuador restored its presidential democracy in 1979, but its institutions remain fragile. Three presidents have been ousted by popular protests amid economic shocks since 1997. Ecuador's longest-serving president, the left-wing Rafael Correa (2007-17), was succeeded by Lenín Moreno (2017-21), who introduced a series of constitutional reforms, including the reintroduction of a two-term limit for presidents. Although this was a step towards deeper democratisation, the current president, Guillermo Lasso, who took office in May 2021, has continued to face social and fiscal challenges.
Political structure: Ecuador has a presidential system. The president and the 137 members of the unicameral National Assembly are elected for four-year terms, with a two-term limit. The 2008 constitution increased executive power and allowed the president to fast-track economic legislation, but a fragmented political landscape and the latent threat of widespread protests severely hinder governability. Although it is formally independent, the judiciary is politicised.
Policy issues: Dollarisation has provided a degree of macroeconomic stability but has also exposed Ecuador's underlying lack of competitiveness and has not precluded fiscal imbalances. Indeed, Ecuador struggled when the commodity supercycle ended, triggering a sharp decline in government revenue just when spending was at a record high. Covid-19 raised the imperative to strengthen the public finances: in 2020 the Moreno government secured a US$6.5bn extended fund facility (EFF) agreement with the IMF that aimed to support fiscal consolidation and structural reform, and which the Lasso administration successfully completed. Recent consolidation efforts and a fresh rise in oil prices have shored up the fiscal accounts, but social spending pressures still pose a challenge to long-term sustainability. Fuel subsidies, which rose after the Russia-Ukraine war and domestic protests broke out last year, are a particularly heavy fiscal burden, but there is strong social and political opposition to removing them.
Taxation: Taxes have been subject to frequent changes. The main taxes in Ecuador are income tax, levied at rates of up to 35%, and value-added tax (VAT), levied at 12%. Private firms must distribute 15% of their profits among their employees.
Foreign trade: Ecuador recorded a trade surplus of US$2.5bn in 2022; petrol export earnings averaged 35% of total export revenue, compared with more than 50% during the commodity boom in the 2000s.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance The president, Guillermo Lasso of the centre-right Creando Oportunidades (Creo) party, took office in May 2021 for a four-year term, after winning a run-off election against Andrés Arauz of the leftist Unión por la Esperanza (UNES), which is the continuation of the political movement led by a former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17). The unicameral 137-seat National Assembly is fragmented and dominated by left-of-centre parties. Mr Lasso's party has just 12 seats as part of the Bancada del Acuerdo Nacional (BAN) bloc, which has made it difficult to forge a governing coalition. The largest party and main opposition force in Congress is UNES, followed by the indigenous Movimiento de Unidad Plurinacional Pachakutik (Pachakutik), which also opposes the government's pro-market reform agenda. The conservative Partido Social Cristiano (PSC) and centre-left Izquierda Democrática (ID) are next in terms of representation. Party loyalties are weak; legislators often vote against party lines, switch party allegiances or leave to become independents, which makes governability extremely difficult.

Political outlook: Political stability The risk of Mr Lasso being ousted has increased following a referendum and concurrent regional and local elections that were held in February. In a major blow to the president, voters rejected all of his reform proposals in a clear signal of their discontent with his administration. Moreover, correísmo (Mr Correa's hard-left political movement) emerged stronger from the referendum and elections. Although we still expect Mr Lasso to remain in power (albeit as a lame duck) until his term ends in 2025, there is a very high risk that the opposition-dominated Congress ousts him, or that he feels compelled to call early elections.
The opposition is leveraging a corruption and influence-peddling scandal allegedly involving Mr Lasso's brother-in-law, Danilo Carrera, to seek an impeachment vote against Mr Lasso (both Mr Carrera and the president deny wrongdoing). However, the independent Constitutional Court must first approve the procedure before a vote is held, and may block it, arguing that there is insufficient evidence implicating the president. Alternatively, Congress could seek to "dismiss" the president (a different procedure to impeachment). Although in principle the constitution permits lawmakers a single dismissal vote per presidential term (Mr Lasso narrowly survived one in 2022), the hardline opposition may push for an alternative interpretation of the regulations-a plausible scenario, given its control over the leadership positions in Congress and its strong representation there (it can generally count on support from 62 of the 137 lawmakers, whereas Mr Lasso can only rely on 12).
In parallel, there is now an increased risk that the president, should he face the threat of imminent removal, dissolves the legislature (which the constitution allows him to do in the event of a political crisis). However, he will be reluctant to use this mechanism, as it would also trigger a new general election, in which he would most likely perform poorly, considering the recent referendum result.
Social unrest-aggravated by high living costs, increased violent crime and the president's fragile standing-is exacerbating political instability. The government had to offer major concessions (including fuel subsidies and a moratorium on new oil and mining projects) to end a wave of protests in June 2022 led by the Confederación de Nacionalidades Indígenas del Ecuador (Conaie, the country's largest indigenous organisation). Conaie has publicly called on Congress to impeach Mr Lasso and is threatening a new strike to secure further concessions. We expect social tensions to remain high under Mr Lasso, to the detriment of governability. Unrest also poses risks to our growth and fiscal forecasts, as the beleaguered government may end up yielding once again to protesters' demands for increased subsidies and tighter restrictions on extractive industries.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Politicised institutions, corruption, an inefficient bureaucracy and a complex, archaic tax system have long undermined institutional effectiveness. Although constitutional amendments in 2008 and 2015 tilted discretional power in the executive's favour, they did little to improve political effectiveness and reduced accountability. The fragmented party system and the fact that various groups can in effect veto government policies have undermined political effectiveness since Ecuador became a presidential democracy in 1979.
In view of these persistent structural weaknesses in Ecuadorean politics, we expect governability to remain weak in 2023-27. Unlike the last two presidents, Mr Lasso lacks a single-party majority in Congress, which restricts progress on his reform agenda. Prospects for any fundamental improvement in political effectiveness under the next administration (due to sit in 2025-29) are weak, as the fragmented political landscape bodes ill for executive-legislative relations.
Reflecting the structural fragility of political coalitions and Mr Lasso's own limited political skills, two government-backed coalitions have fallen apart during his term. Amid the turmoil, a number of opposition parties-including UNES, the PSC and dissident members of Pachakutik and ID-have formed an ad hoc majority opposition coalition of their own, undermining the Lasso administration's efforts to formulate and execute policy.
The constitution grants the president significant powers-including vetoes and executive decrees-that he is leveraging increasingly to fend off legislative attacks. In the short run, the continued (and probably increased) use of executive decrees could enable Mr Lasso and his successors to push ahead with at least some of their agenda, despite lawmakers' objections. However, doing so could fuel opposition sentiment and, over the long term, result in policy deadlock, with each side constantly trying to overturn the other's initiatives.
In addition to a weak party system, there are other structural factors that pose serious challenges to political and institutional effectiveness: the bureaucracy is inefficient; policymaking is subject to the demands of an array of vested interests; and law enforcement is inadequate. These issues are compounded by bouts of social unrest, which are a threat not just to political stability but also to political effectiveness. Social groups are well organised and have sometimes succeeded in reversing or blocking the implementation of government policy. For example, indigenous groups managed to oust the three presidents who came before Mr Correa; there is a risk that Mr Lasso becomes the fourth. He has already been forced to backtrack on his market-friendly reform agenda after protests broke out in June 2022, for example by increasing fuel subsidies and adopting a moratorium on new oil and mining licences. A similar episode occurred in October 2019, under his predecessor, Lenín Moreno (2017-21). These groups will continue to undermine Mr Lasso's policy agenda and that of the next president.
Corruption is another factor that will weigh on political effectiveness. Progress on tackling this issue has been marginal at best under Mr Lasso. He has reinstated the cabinet-level anti-corruption secretariat (following its dissolution in 2020) and the body has now developed a national anti-corruption strategy, but its implementation activities have been limited. On a positive note, anti-money-laundering reforms will tighten financial reporting requirements for legislators and political parties, which could help to uncover cases of embezzlement. This measure will build on reforms that the Moreno administration adopted to reduce political interference by the judiciary and curb graft. However, we expect overall progress on reducing corruption to be limited by weaknesses in policymaking and implementation capacity. Previous initiatives have yielded few tangible results, and Mr Lasso's fragile legislative position will get in the way of efforts to advance anti-corruption legislation that the opposition deems controversial (as also occurred under Mr Moreno). The misuse of funds in public institutions and networks of corruption within the state, including the judicial system, will be exceedingly difficult to root out.
Political outlook: Election watch The next national elections (presidential and legislative) are not due until 2025. There is a high risk that political instability will force them to be brought forward, although this is not our baseline forecast. Regardless of whether they are held in 2025 or earlier, there is now a stronger likelihood that widespread disapproval of the Lasso administration will precipitate a shift back towards leftist politics. Against this backdrop, the correísta opposition, which lost in the second round of the 2021 presidential election, has a solid basis from which to mount a bid for the presidency, particularly following significant regional and provincial victories in February. A candidate from the indigenous Pachakutik party, which functions as the political arm of Conaie, could well be a strong contender. Pachakutik won the most mayoral races of any single party in February, and its presidential candidate came third in 2021, missing out on the second round by just 0.35%.
Political outlook: International relations Promoting international trade and increasing foreign investment will remain a foreign policy priority for Mr Lasso. Having already reduced some important tariffs, the government will seek to sign new free-trade agreements (FTAs) and ease bureaucratic procedures for exporters. Earlier this year Mr Lasso signed an FTA with Costa Rica and concluded negotiations for another one with China; we expect these to be ratified by end-2023. The administration is also actively seeking deals with South Korea, Canada, Panama and Dominican Republic, and has petitioned to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP).
Relations with the US, which sees Ecuador as an important ally in a region that has ideologically shifted towards the left, will remain strong. However, owing to US politics, which is highly polarised, Mr Lasso has been unable to persuade the administration led by Joe Biden to begin negotiations on an FTA. We consider this to be a long-term goal at best. Simultaneously, Mr Lasso is strengthening ties with China, which last year displaced the US as Ecuador's largest trade partner. In addition to the prospective FTA, Ecuador has endorsed the "One China" principle. We expect that the US will attempt to counter China's growing influence by offering Ecuador economic incentives that fall short of an FTA. In December 2022 the US Senate (the upper house) passed a partnership bill that promotes bilateral trade and investment. US legislators have also introduced a bill that, if enacted, would reduce US tariffs on nearly 50% of Ecuador's exports.

Ecuador's score and placement in EIU's business environment rankings improve only modestly in the 2023-27 forecast period, reflecting the stagnation of the reform agenda of the president, Guillermo Lasso, amid political and social turmoil. Although reforms implemented under Mr Lasso and his predecessor, Lenin Moreno (2017-21), have fostered major improvements in categories such as policy towards private enterprise and competition, and policy towards foreign investment, there has been little progress in other categories such as macroeconomic environment, labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. The strength of the opposition in the unicameral National Assembly limits the scope for reform and explains Ecuador's relatively poor position in the rankings.
The country's highest score is for its macroeconomic environment, reflecting relatively low inflation engendered by dollarisation and an improving fiscal position amid consolidation efforts and higher oil prices in 2023-27 compared with the 2018-22 historical period. Ecuador's fiscal position is now more stable following a 27-month, US$6.5bn extended fund facility (EFF) programme with the IMF that ended in December 2022, marking the first time in two decades that Ecuador had successfully completed a programme with the Fund.
Weak political effectiveness hinders progress on structural reforms Ecuador's weakest score is for political effectiveness. A weak and fragmented party system, an ineffective bureacracy, corruption, and the existence of de facto veto players all hinder the adoption of structural reforms. This is the main reason for the slow pace of progress on Mr Lasso's reform agenda, and for the stagnation in Ecuador's score and ranking. Moreover, weak political effectiveness fuels voter discontent and political instability. There is a risk that this triggers a return to a less business-friendly administration later on in the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Ecuador's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2023-24: Policies to promote private-sector investment stall owing to political instability.
2025-27: Next government halts efforts to scale back state's role in development. Regulation and licensing continue to favour state-run companies over private-sector ones. Price controls on fuels remain in place.
Policy towards foreign investment 2023-24: Political instability and continued government interventionism undermine efforts to court foreign firms. Major government tenders generate only limited interest.
2025-27: Inadequate property rights protection and questions surrounding access to foreign arbitration deter investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2023-24: Capital outflows tax is reduced to 2%. Government ratifies free-trade agreement (FTA) with China and seeks FTAs with South Korea, Canada and Panama.
2025-27: Accession to Pacific Alliance and the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) trade blocs is likely, but FTA with US proves elusive.
Taxes 2023-24: High global oil prices reduce likelihood of tax increases.
2025-27: Government efforts to raise tax collection and tackle evasion continue, supporting revenue growth, but tax system remains complex.
Financing 2023-24: Lower liquidity in the financial system causes lending rates to rise, limiting access to financing for riskier firms.
2025-27: Financing remains below potential, as public-sector financing needs curb long-term lending to private sector.
The labour market 2023-24: Government approves additional minimum-wage increases in order to bolster public support.
2025-27: Quality of workforce is poor. Labour reforms are slow to take effect. Educational outcomes remain weak.
Infrastructure 2023-24: Efforts to drum up large-scale foreign investment have only limited success.
2025-27: Public-private partnerships (PPPs) increase, particularly in road and airport development, but political uncertainty keeps take-up weak.
Technological readiness 2023-24: Public and private investments help to expand 4G broadband availability.
2025-27: Adoption of e-government services increases. 5G technology remains in its infancy.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
7.5 7.8 23 25 1 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score for the macroeconomic environment-the strongest area of its business environment-stagnates in the forecast period, causing the country to fall by two places in the global rankings, to 25th, and from first place regionally in the 2018-22 rankings, to third place now. Despite the stagnation in the overall score, there has been movement in the underlying variables-some for better, others for worse-which has, on balance, kept the score unchanged.

- Dollarisation keeps inflation low, reduces the risk of sharp currency volatility and reduces (but does not eliminate) the risk of a balance-of-payments crisis. It also contains risks to the fiscal accounts, as deficits must be financed rather than monetised. In an environment of higher oil prices than in 2018-22 and fiscal restraint (necessary to secure new multilateral financing), we believe that the public finances will maintain a small surplus throughout 2023-27. Although public debt has risen in recent years, an improvement in the budget balance will help to ease the public debt burden over the medium term. We think that the risk of de-dollarisation is low, as public support for the measure has been strong since its introduction in 1999.

High oil prices and new mineral exports will keep the current account in surplus
- In December 2022 Ecuador concluded its US$6.5bn 27-month EFF with the IMF (it was the first time in two decades that the country had successfully completed a programme with the Fund). The programme has placed the public finances on more stable footing and increased the independence of the Banco Central del Ecuador (BCE, the central bank), but the Fund has emphasised the need for greater structural reform and fiscal transparency. We believe that the government is likely to seek another agreement for 2023-25, which could unlock up to US$1.1bn in new financing, easing financing concerns and helping to maintain the government's fiscal probity. However, keeping up momentum on structural reforms will be much more difficult going forward.
- Higher oil prices have kept the current account in surplus since 2020, following an average deficit of 0.7% of GDP in 2010-19. We expect this to remain the case, even though a post-pandemic pick-up in private consumption and investment will drive import growth, as oil export prices remain higher than in the historical period, and because mineral exports will support the trade surplus, even as oil prices ease. Current-account surpluses have helped with foreign-reserves accumulation: in January reserves reached US$9.4bn-their highest point since the introduction of dollarisation. We forecast that reserves accumulation will continue, producing average import cover of 3.3 months in the forecast period. Although this is not particularly large, it will help to reduce external vulnerabilities and guard against balance-of-payments risks.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
4.0 5.5 66 50 10 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score and rankings for policy towards private enterprise and competition improve significantly in the 2023-27 forecast period; the country jumps 16 places up the global rankings, to 50th, and by five in the regional rankings, to fifth. Despite opposition to public-private partnerships (PPPs) in the legislature, reforms enacted by Mr Lasso and Mr Moreno have improved competition policy, reduced state subsidies and created more space for private enterprises in industries that were once dominated by the state, including mining and oil. However, further liberalisation will be difficult, given opposition from Congress and from civil society (particularly indigenous) groups, particularly to projects in the extractive industries. Nonetheless, the small size of the economy will limit the scope for competition, and monopolies and oligopolies will remain features of Ecuador's business environment, particularly in the energy, cement, financial, supermarket and steel industries. Some improvements in efficiency are likely, but high levels of bureaucracy will constrain private investment and competition in 2023-27.
Price controls for fuels are likely to remain in place
- Price controls for fuels are a point of political contention in Ecuador, and efforts to remove them have been met with large and sometimes destabilising protests. This means that the government must carefully balance fiscal savings (as price liberalisation reduces the need to subsidise firms) with the political cost incurred in rolling subsidies back. Certain goods and services-including fuel, electricity, agricultural chemicals, pharmaceuticals and telephone tariffs-are subject to government price controls, and there are also some limited price controls for some basic foodstuffs. Price controls for fuel have traditionally put substantial strain on the budget (the subsidies that they entail account for about 3% of GDP), but efforts to roll them back have led to huge protests, and we do not expect the Lasso government or its successors to attempt further cuts.

Despite some progress, the competition regulator will remain weak
- The Superintendencia de Control del Poder de Mercado (SCPM, the competition watchdog) has made significant progress in meeting international standards, although Ecuador was one of the last countries in Latin America to introduce a competition law (in 2012). The SPCM has adopted several reforms to improve efficiency and increase co-operation with international competition bodies, including its regional counterparts and the OECD. Ecuador's EFF included provisions to increase market competition and promote liberalisation across economic sectors. For example, the creation of a fast-track review procedure in late 2020 has shortened the approvals process for smaller mergers. However, the government's austerity drive has resulted in SCPM budget cuts every year since 2014, limiting its institutional effectiveness, and despite the body's increased professionalism, it is likely to remain relatively weak in 2023-27. According to the latest available data, for 2021, the SCPM investigated 25 cases of alleged unfair conduct and/or competition; substantiated 20 investigation files on agreements and restrictive practices, and 25 on abuse of market power; and resolved 15 cases of economic concentration. It levied almost US$6m in fines in the same year.
- The Moreno and Lasso administrations have made progress in reducing the state's role in the economy by promoting the use of PPPs and by opening up state companies to private involvement. However, uptake of PPPs has been weak, partly because of shaky investor confidence related to legal insecurity, and partly because of a lack of personnel with the necessary resources to promote and support PPP development. The current PPP legislative framework is based on the Regulations for the Public-Private Partnership Regime, the Law of Incentives for PPPs and Foreign Investment, and the General Regulations for the Application of the Framework Law of Incentives for PPPs and Foreign Investment. These were all introduced in 2015-16 and essentially consist of tax breaks-including breaks from import tariffs and value-added tax (VAT) during project construction, as well as a ten-year reprieve from income tax and a reprieve from tax on the repatriation of profits. In 2023 the executive will publish new regulations aimed at increasing investment security for PPPs, but they will fall short of the overhaul that a 2022 investment bill (that was rejected by Congress) would have engendered.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
4.2 6.4 72 50 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score for policy towards foreign investment improves substantially in the 2023-27 period, and the country rises from 72nd to 50th position globally, and from tenth to eighth in the regional rankings. Mr Lasso and Mr Moreno have shown greater willingness to engage with foreign investors in what is a substantial improvement compared with the hostility towards foreign investors that was displayed by another former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17). Broadly speaking, the government's commitment to crafting policy that gives foreign investors transparency, clarity and predictability will be stronger in 2023-27 than in 2018-22. For instance, the Lasso administration's attempts (with limited success) to court private investors to fill gaps in the economy created by fiscal austerity will make for stronger judicial protection for investors, as well as much lower expropriation risk. In view of these developments, policy towards foreign investment will remain one of the stronger aspects of Ecuador's business environment. However, investors are still likely to be apprehensive, given uncertainty over who will succeed Mr Lasso and what the next administration's policies may bring. Powerful domestic vested interests will also continue to resist some of the government's reform efforts.

- Mr Lasso has made it a policy priority to accelerate a trend towards ensuring a more stable foreign investment environment that began under his predecessor. To that end, he brought about Ecuador's return to the World Bank's International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) in September 2021, 12 years after Mr Correa withdrew the country. The return signalled a shift in the government's willingness to improve the investment environment. The ICSID has now concluded all of the legal disputes between foreign companies and the Ecuadorean government relating to Mr Correa's tenure; some of the proceedings had dragged on for many years and have only recently been settled. In 2018 legislation came into force that stipulated that disputes over investment agreements be resolved through arbitration. Even international arbitral decisions are now deemed immediately enforceable in Ecuador, without the need for further approval by domestic courts. The aim of this legislation was to allay investors' concerns about judicial security, but concerns about policy reversals under the next government will sustain risks relating to investment protection.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
6.4 7.3 61 57 9 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's underlying score for foreign trade and exchange controls improves slightly in the forecast period, as does its global ranking, and it climbs by one place in the regional rankings, to eighth. This improvement mainly reflects efforts by the Lasso administration to liberalise trade by adopting tariff reductions. However, the country's openness to trade is still only moderate (relative to its theoretical potential), which explains why Ecuador remains in the bottom half of the rankings. Assuming that Mr Lasso stays in office, trade liberalisation will continue over the forecast period; we do not expect the authorities to implement import or capital-account restrictions.

- Mr Lasso has ramped up negotiations on free-trade agreements (FTAs), including with China, Costa Rica, South Korea, Canada, Panama and the Dominican Republic. We expect legislators to ratify the deal with China by end-2023, which would improve firms' access to Ecuador's largest trade partner. Mr Lasso has also petitioned to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) and the Pacific Alliance (a trade bloc comprising Chile, Peru, Colombia and Mexico); accession to both is likely within the forecast period.

Relations with the US will continue to improve under Mr Lasso
- Ecuador's trade relationship with the US (its second-biggest export partner) has improved under Mr Lasso, following efforts by the Moreno administration to restore ties that suffered from Mr Correa's decision to withdraw from the Andean Trade Promotion and Drug Eradication Act (ATPDEA), which granted tariff-free access to the US market for about 6,000 goods. Mr Lasso has been striving to open negotiations into an FTA, but the highly polarised political environment in the US has hindered progress, and we consider an FTA a long-term goal at best. We expect the US to offer partial trade incentives in order to counter Chinese influence in Ecuador, but these could be withdrawn if Mr Lasso's successor is more hostile to the US.

Government will work to stabilise customs framework
- Some progress has been made in recent years in terms of streamlining customs procedures to improve efficiency; for example, the increased use of electronic procedures and automation has sped up the delivery of goods. However, corruption and drug-smuggling via overseas shipments will continue and could well be fuelled by a substantial increase in drug-trafficking operations. Given that tackling corruption is a priority for both the IMF and the US, Ecuador's government is likely to continue trying to crack down on corruption, particularly relating to public procurement processes and trade-related embezzlement. Frequent changes to customs duties have in the past acted as a major disincentive for legitimate businesses and have fuelled contraband trade; the Lasso government and the next one are likely to focus more keenly on stabilising the customs framework in 2023-27.
- The current government has worked to gradually reduce the capital outflows tax, as it deters foreign investment. The tax applies to all non-cash, hard-currency transactions of repatriated capital and transfers from banks to external accounts exceeding US$5,000. Mr Lasso presented a presidential decree in December 2021 that involved reducing the tax by 0.25 percentage points every three months, from 5% at end-2021; it stood at 3.75% as at February 2023. Mr Lasso has expressed an intention to phase out the tax completely, but this will depend on him remaining in office, and on trends in the public finances (the tax is an important source of government revenue).

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
5.3 6.1 63 48 7 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score for taxes improves in the forecast period, resulting in a notable rise in its global ranking, from 63rd to 48th, and in its regional ranking, from seventh to third. Official tax policy was volatile for part of the historical period and was vulnerable to abrupt changes in legislation aimed at meeting short-term financing needs. However, the situation has improved markedly following the start of the EFF in 2020, and Mr Lasso's November 2021 tax reform spurred further progress by providing incentives for investment (despite a temporary increase in firms' tax rates). Companies making new investments can have their corporate taxes reduced by up to 5 percentage points and are exempt from foreign trade and capital outflows taxes. Although the tax reform will increase fiscal incentives for investment, concerns about regulatory issues and political stability will remain serious deterrents for businesses that are considering committing to long-term projects. There been progress under Mr Moreno and Mr Lasso in simplifying the tax system-in part by digitalising reporting and payment requirements-although it remains complex overall.

- The tax burden on larger companies will ease from 2024. As part of the IMF agreement and Mr Lasso's tax reforms, they will have to pay temporary post-pandemic contributions until end-2023, as a way of bolstering government revenue. The government also introduced an income tax on dividends distributed by resident companies to non-resident businesses or individuals.
- Aside from making changes to tax rates, Mr Lasso has sought to strengthen the tax system, for example by increasing the powers of the Servicio de Rentas Internas (SRI, the tax authority) to combat widespread evasion and abuse of tax avoidance schemes; in May 2022 a reform allowed taxes to be filed electronically and invoices to be digitalised as part of these efforts. Over time the SRI is likely to improve its reputation for efficiency and will also step up its efforts to combat tax evasion.

The government will resist IMF calls to increase the VAT rate
- At 12%, Ecuador's VAT rate is almost 3 percentage points below the regional average. The Fund has recommended increasing the rate, but Mr Lasso will resist this, preferring to raise tax collection by clamping down on evasion and widening the tax base. The government's 2021 tax bill, which increased contributions for some businesses and high-income earners, encountered significant political backlash. If the government's efforts to increase tax inflows through increased collection fail, the Fund could press for increases in tax rates. However, we believe that the government is unlikely to do this willingly, given its precarious political standing. There may be other changes to personal income taxes and consumption taxes (including reductions in personal allowances and deductions) in order to lift the tax take later in the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
3.6 5.1 73 66 9 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score for financing strengthens considerably in the forecast period, but its rise up the rankings is less pronounced owing to improvements in other similarly ranked countries. State intervention in the banking sector used to be a feature of the business environment but is unlikely to be a particularly big risk in 2023-27. Mr Lasso-a former banker-has engendered greater confidence among commercial banks and their customers, which has spurred deposit and credit growth, albeit from a low level; total credit to the private sector stood at 54% of estimated GDP in 2022, having grown by an average of 13.7% per year in 2021-22. However, numerous long-standing structural issues will complicate corporate access to finance. The banking sector remains underdeveloped relative to the size of the economy, accounting for just 3.6% of GDP in 2022, according to the Banco Central del Ecuador (BCE, the central bank). Financial services are relatively rudimentary, with a small secondary market and two stock exchanges (in Quito, the capital, and Guayaquil) vying for a limited pool of bond and equity issuances. In this context, financing is-and will remain-dominated by bank loans, with only large companies able to secure the lowest rates. The Asociación de Bancos del Ecuador (Asobanca) reported that the average lending rate stood at 9% in January 2023. Smaller companies often face higher interest rates and have loan maturities capped at three years. Long-term bank finance and capital market finance remain underdeveloped and difficult to secure.

- The financial system is weathering the gradual winding-down of pandemic-era support measures and higher financing costs well, and the risk that companies will be unable to service loans or access credit appears to be contained. Financial sounds indicators remain reasonable: provisioning for bad loans stood at 223% in January, and the non-performing loan (NPL) ratio was at 3.1%, according to Asobanca. Profitability has also has returned to its pre-pandemic level.
- Confidence in the banking system is tied to the management of reserve requirements at the BCE, which is central to sustaining dollarisation but has been the target of regulatory changes in the past. However, recent legislation to strengthen the central bank's authority-in line with Fund reforms-will reduce the risk of more aggressive executive controls on bank deposits (which would weaken commercial bank lending and undermine market confidence more broadly).

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
4.5 4.9 80 78 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's underlying score for the labour market improves slightly, but this area is still the weakest area of the business environment in ranking terms; the country improves just two places in the global rankings, to 78th, and it remains in last place regionally in 2023-27. This poor performance reflects a low-quality and relatively high-cost workforce, along with restrictive labour regulation. Mr Lasso's efforts to increase labour flexibility have been put on ice in view of his precarious political standing.
US dollar appreciation will compound competitiveness problems
- Within the formal sector, labour market competitiveness will be hampered by restrictive labour laws and the strength of the US dollar (Ecuador's minimum wage is the highest in Latin America in dollar terms, although the country lags most of its neighbours in terms of productivity). Seeking to bolster popular support, Mr Lasso has continually lifted the minimum wage, which now stands at US$450 per month. The president's difficult political position has forced him to shelve his plans to liberalise restrictive labour in a bid to spur formal job creation, and we do not expect him to revive them in the 2023-27 forecast period.

Raising educational outcomes will be a slow and difficult process
- The country's modest educational outcomes hamper the quality of its workforce. Even assuming that the quality of educational policymaking improves, student results are unlikely to pick up until the end of our 2023-27 forecast period. Skills shortages and mismatches will therefore remain a problem, compounded by a lack of effective training programmes in both the public and private sectors and by the fact that students often leave schooling prematurely so that they can supplement family incomes.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
4.8 5.0 61 65 7 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Infrastructure was one of the stronger areas of Ecuador's business environment in the historical period. Although we expect to see some improvements that lift the score in 2023-27, fiscal constraints and investor uncertainty mean that major advances are unlikely. As a result, Ecuador falls by four places in the global rankings, to 65th, although it remains at seventh regionally. The state of infrastructure in Ecuador has benefited from a large public investment programme that Mr Correa put in place and which brought its transport, energy and road infrastructure into line with Latin American standards, following decades of underinvestment (and frequent electricity shortages). Telecoms development (measured by mobile and internet penetration) is also above the regional average. However, the government will be unable to sustain this pace of progress owing to fiscal austerity. Difficulties in attracting private investment for infrastructure projects will also be a limiting factor; Ecuador has a weak track record on fostering successful PPPs, and in 2022 Congress rejected the executive's investment bill, which aimed to fast-track and provide greater investment certainty to PPP contracts. Companies will also be wary of committing to PPPs, given their long timeframes and the risk of speedy policy reversals under future governments.

- A major focus of infrastructure investment has been the development of new hydroelectric power plants to avoid importing costly energy for gas-fired and thermoelectric plants. According to the Operador Nacional de Electricidad (CENACE, the electricity control centre), hydropower now accounts for 92% of the country's energy production. However, there are (valid) concerns that generation from hydroelectric plants will fall short of expected levels, as has been the case with the US$3.2bn Coca Codo Sinclair dam (completed in 2018), owing to design issues and potentially misleading estimates about capacity. The risk is that lower than anticipated production causes supply bottlenecks and raises the need for electricity and fossil fuel imports. Moreover, there is a risk that hydroelectric projects have knock-on effects on the environment, including infrastructure damage caused by erosion or flooding.
- Recently auctioned PPPs have targeted road infrastructure improvements and the creation of new road networks. Mr Lasso's government has set a goal of 40% private participation in the road network by 2025, but we are sceptical about the prospects for success, as most major bids are only due to be held in 2024. Particular priorities are new highways connecting Guayaquil to Quito (the capital), and Guayaquil to Cuenca. The government has also sought private partners to upgrade the port of Esmeraldas and several airport concessions. This should help to boost domestic and regional trade, but it will also create challenges including congestion, as advances in traffic management have been more limited. Moreover, seasonal heavy rains that are costly and difficult to mitigate cause seasonal disruption in some areas. Mass transit systems have been slow to develop; a tram system in Cuenca became operational in 2020, and Quito's metro launched in late 2022, following ten years of construction and several delays.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
3.5 4.1 74 74 10 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score for technological readiness improves in 2023-27, but faster progress elsewhere keeps its global ranking unchanged, and it falls to eleventh place regionally, from tenth. This makes technological readiness one of the weakest aspects of Ecuador's business environment; the poor result reflects low smartphone penetration and a lack of spending on research and innovation, which undermine the overall score. These weaknesses are apparent, too, in Ecuador's position of 98th (out of 132 countries) in the 2022 Global Innovation Index developed by the UN World Intellectual Property Organisation-a poor performance for the country's level of development. A low number of patent applications reflects limited overall dynamism in research and development (R&D). On a brighter note, Ecuador scores relatively well for e-commerce preparedness and for cyber-security.
Internet access and penetration will improve over the forecast period
- Despite efforts by the Lasso administration to ease operating conditions for mobile operators by reducing the tax burden on companies and on customer contracts, coverage remains inadequate and costs are high, limiting access. Ecuador has one of the lowest mobile penetration rates in the region, at 94% in 2022, compared with a regional average in excess of 100%. A complicated regulatory environment for foreign companies impedes greater competition in the mobile market. The expansion of 4G technology has been relatively slow, even by regional standards, although subscriptions have been increasing rapidly since the pandemic. Despite the announcement in 2021 of a 5G rollout, we do not expect it to become operational before the end of the forecast period.
- Broadband access is low by regional and global comparison; there were about 2.5m connections in 2021. However, the internet is increasingly accessed via mobile phones, and we expect this means of access to continue to grow as data tariffs become more affordable and mobile phones are used increasingly in place of personal computers (PCs). Rising internet penetration and smartphone usage will foster growth in online retail, albeit from a low base. The Cámara Ecuatoriana de Comercio Electrónico (CECE, the e-commerce chamber) estimates that e-commerce sales increased by 25% in 2022, to US$4bn, from US$646m in 2016.
- E-government has developed relatively slowly; the 2022 iteration of the UN's two-yearly E-Government Survey put Ecuador 84th out of 193 countries for e-government development (down ten positions from 2020), owing to a lower level of online services. The same study ranked Ecuador 41st for e-participation (a separate index that evaluates governments' digital efforts to promote civic engagement), up by eight spots from 2020. There is no single central government information portal, but most major departments have dedicated websites.

Internet banking will continue to rise rapidly, albeit from a low base
- A dramatic rise in internet banking has aided the growth of e-commerce. Digital transactions increased by 161% between 2019 and 2021 (latest available data), to US$135.9bn, according to Asobanca. This is larger than the country's GDP and greater than the volume of transactions in physical banks. Although it is rising rapidly, the number of people who make digital transactions remains low, at just 4.3m, and is skewed heavily in favour of younger users. Growth in digital transactions was driven primarily by the pandemic, when the use of cash and physical transactions was perceived to be more difficult and risky, but it is a trend that we expect to continue.

Economic forecast: Policy trends EIU expects progress on the government's economic reform agenda to slow to a crawl, given that the president, Guillermo Lasso, has been reduced to a lame duck, particularly after voters rejected all of his proposals in a referendum in February. Rather than advancing new economic reforms, we expect the government to focus on protecting its key achievement-fiscal discipline-in order to reduce default risk. In December 2022 Ecuador concluded a US$6.5bn extended fund facility (EFF) agreement with the IMF that was signed in 2020. This marked the first time in two decades that Ecuador had completed an IMF-backed programme-a significant milestone. Although the Fund has commended the government for putting the public finances on a more stable trajectory and for strengthening the independence of the Banco Central del Ecuador (BCE, the central bank), it has emphasised that more action is needed to implement structural reforms and improve fiscal transparency. Given that Ecuador's high risk premium and tight financing conditions will keep it out of international capital markets, we expect the Lasso administration to seek a new agreement with the IMF for 2023-25. Our baseline forecast assumes that the Fund will extend a further US$1.1bn over the next three years as part of a new deal. Under this scenario, we would expect the government to maintain fiscal restraint and adopt additional public financial management reforms, as it did under the recently completed EFF.
Another priority will be to address social unrest, which is being aggravated by higher inflation and crime, and is weighing on Mr Lasso's political standing. To that end, we expect the administration to continue a programme of minimum-wage increments that began in December 2021 with a 6.2% rise-the largest since 2014. A new 5.9% increase came into effect at the start of 2023, and we expect the minimum wage to carry on rising gradually over the rest of Mr Lasso's term. The government may also step up monthly cash transfers to poor families and provide further tax and credit benefits to farmers. There is a risk that social unrest will force Mr Lasso to make more concessions; in this context, balancing voters' demands with the Fund's conditions on fiscal policy will be tricky.
The government's more ambitious market-friendly reforms will be paused, given the hostility of the legislature. This was laid bare in November 2022, when lawmakers sought to abolish Mr Lasso's tax reform (although it was stymied by the Constitutional Court). Moreover, in March of that year Congress rejected an investment-promotion bill that sought to boost public-private partnerships and create free-trade zones. Major reforms that require legislative approval-for example to make the labour market more flexible and modify financial regulations-are now on hold. We therefore expect the Lasso administration to attempt only minimal progress on its agenda via less ambitious (and less politically sensitive) bills. As a case in point, in December the legislature approved an executive bill to increase investment in the audiovisual industry via tax incentives and to cut red tape by digitalising government procedures; the narrow scope of this reform-plus months of negotiations-made its legislative approval possible. The government will also continue to reduce capital outflows tax and to leverage the 2021 tax reform to offer tax incentives to encourage new private investment contracts. Beyond changes to the tax system, efforts to improve the business environment will include pursuing free-trade agreements (FTAs), reducing trade barriers and easing bureaucratic hurdles to doing business. Although these efforts should make the business environment slightly more attractive, we believe that high levels of political instability will offset these improvements.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators
