Mr Lasso will remain committed to shoring up the public finances, although political and social spending pressures will curb the pace of fiscal improvement. Even though the referendum defeat and calls by the left-leaning Congress to increase spending have put him in a precarious position, his fiscal consolidation efforts will benefit from a constitution that makes approving new spending measures the prerogative of the executive, rather than the legislature. Mr Lasso's 2021 tax reform raised revenue by increasing contributions for high-income individuals and large firms, and by restricting the scope of tax deductions. However, expenditure is also set to rise given the government's concessions to calm last year's protests. These concessions include increased fuel subsidies and budget rigidities, which encompass mandated increases to the health and education budgets, and automatic pay rises for public officials.
We forecast that the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) account will remain around balance in 2023. Fiscal consolidation efforts will benefit from a second year of high oil prices; although prices will ease later in the forecast period, we expect them to remain above their long-term average, which will relieve some pressure on the public finances but will not preclude the need for spending restraint. Assuming that these factors help to generate overall budget surpluses from 2024, we expect the public debt/GDP ratio to decline from a peak of 63.6% in 2020 to 53.4% in 2027. The recent banking sector stress in the US and Europe, which has caused global market jitters, poses a downside risk-a fall in global growth could trigger a fall in oil demand and hence a collapse in oil prices. Other than that, risks to these assumptions are all political; for example, there is a tangible risk that the next government, which is due to take office in 2025 but could begin earlier given the political turmoil, will not be as fiscally disciplined as the Lasso administration.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2022 2023 2024 2025 2026 2027
Lending rate (av) 7.7 9.1 8.5 8.4 8.1 8.1
Deposit rate (av) 5.9 7.5 6.0 5.5 6.7 6.6
As a dollarised economy, Ecuador lacks independent monetary policy and is therefore unable to use certain levers to support growth. In this context, monetary conditions will be determined largely by external factors, particularly by the stance taken by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank), which we expect will continue monetary tightening until June and then hold rates steady, before embarking on a mild easing cycle in mid-2024. However, Ecuador's high risk premium and political dysfunction will keep real local rates elevated. Crucially, the BCE will not use international reserves to finance public spending-a policy that would threaten monetary and financial stability, as it would increase the country's liquidity risks and could ultimately jeopardise the dollarisation regime.

We expect the economy to finally return to its pre-pandemic size in 2023, but the pace of growth will decelerate from last year. There will be tailwinds from high global oil prices, but other developments will be less helpful. Still-elevated consumer price inflation and higher interest rates (largely imported from the US) will hit real incomes and cause businesses to halt investment plans. Political instability, aggravated by growing efforts to oust Mr Lasso following his referendum defeat, will also weigh on private investment. Export growth will recover as oil output picks up and shrimp shipments soar, but a challenging global environment will hit overall GDP as the US and European economies decelerate. We expect Ecuador's GDP growth to slow to 1.3% in 2023, from an estimated 2.7% in 2022.
In 2024-27 the economy will struggle to regain momentum, growing by an annual average of 2%. Although real wage growth will accelerate in 2025, it will remain weak, putting a lid on private consumption. Government consumption and investment will not drive growth significantly, given efforts to contain public spending. A combination of strong exports and high demand for the imported materials needed for capital investment will mean that the external account will make just a small (albeit growing) positive contribution to growth in 2024-27.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Oil is Ecuador's most important economic sector, accounting for about 10% of GDP and more than a third of total government revenue. It is also a leading source of investment. The sector has been the main driver behind the huge reduction in the country's long-standing fiscal deficit. Oil-related earnings-(including sales of crude oil and refined fuels such as petrol), boosted by soaring oil prices, particularly since the start of the Russia-Ukraine war-represented 37% of government revenue in 2022 (the highest share since 2013). Given that average global oil prices will be higher in the forecast period than in our 2018-22 historical period, oil sales are likely to continue to support state coffers, but their positive contribution will be lower than in 2022.
Elevated fiscal and export earnings from high oil prices will mask bleaker prospects for production. Mr Lasso's promising reform agenda-he was seeking to double oil output to 1m barrels/day (b/d) by 2025-has mostly stalled. In fact, production has continued its gradual decline since Mr Lasso took office, averaging 470,000 b/d (7% below the 2011-21 average), owing to consistent underinvestment and supply disruptions caused by natural disasters and social unrest. A statist-leaning bureaucracy, judicial setbacks, and environmental and social opposition have hindered the administration's efforts to boost production by attracting private capital. Tenders for oilfields and refineries have progressed slowly and have received a fairly limited response from private operators who, despite high oil prices, remain wary given Ecuador's poor record on contract protection. Development of Ecuador's most promising oil project, the 1.6bn-barrel, heavy crude Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini (ITT) area, has been held back by environmental concerns and by protests by indigenous groups. Moreover, new explorations have been on hold since the government gave in to protesters' demands for a moratorium on new oil concessions in order to end large-scale protests that broke out in 2022.
Consequently, we now expect production to rise only modestly over the forecast period, to 510,000 b/d by 2027. Given the ongoing moratorium (which could be extended), we expect the government to focus on improving extraction in mature fields and on developing nearby areas. To this end, in October 2022 the administration launched the Intracampos II tender, which aims to attract about US$2bn of private investment in exploration, development and exploitation. Some long-term projects constitute an upside risk to our forecasts. For example, the government plans to tender the operation of the Sacha oilfield, which is one of Ecuador's largest and is currently managed by Petroecuador, the state-owned oil and gas company. Its goal is to increase production by 70%, to 120,000 b/d, via investments of US$4.5bn. This would lift national production by 10%, but we view this as a long-term initiative that will take time to materialise in full. The expansion of ITT, an oilfield with vast reserves that could in principle increase current national output by a third (150,000 b/d), faced a major setback in 2022, when the Constitutional Court effectively blocked the development of key parts of the oilfield on the basis of their proximity to a national park. Amid these issues, as well as social and environmental opposition, we remain sceptical about prospects for substantial increases in oil production. With regard to the downstream business, the Lasso administration has launched a concession to modernise Ecuador's main refinery, Esmeraldas, which would boost efficiency and reduce demand for imported fuel derivatives.

We forecast that 12-month consumer price inflation will slow from an estimated 3.7% in December 2022 to 1.1% by the end of this year. Supply-side pressures that accumulated during 2022 are easing as global demand cools and supply chains are repaired. However, international commodity markets will remain especially sensitive to one-off climate-related shocks in major producers, which could include drought, flooding and natural disasters, the effects of which could pass through to the domestic economy quickly. We expect global commodity prices to continue to ease and dollarisation to remain in place. In view of these factors, we expect inflation to moderate to an average of 1.2% per year in 2024-27.

We expect dollarisation to be maintained in 2023-27. De-dollarisation remains highly unlikely, given strong support for the exchange-rate regime on the basis that it promotes macroeconomic stability. We expect the Lasso government to remain committed to restoring the public finances, accumulating reserves and working to strengthen the BCE's independence. Multilateral and bilateral financing, notably from the IMF and China, will help to assuage concerns about financing and liquidity amid limited access to international capital markets.

Assuming that IMF financial support continues, we are cautiously optimistic about the external accounts in 2023-27 and expect a series of small current-account surpluses. Export growth, high oil prices and a slowdown in import growth should all support the trade balance in 2023, contributing to an overall current-account surplus of 1.3% of GDP. Thereafter, mining exports will gain momentum, helping to maintain a trade surplus, even though revenue from oil exports will fall as global prices ease. Current-account surpluses and multilateral financing will bolster the BCE's foreign-exchange reserves, providing a cushion against fiscal and financial shocks. We expect reserves to rise to 3.4 months of import cover by end-2027, from an average of 1.8 months in 2010-20. Although Mr Lasso wants to increase private investment, strong legislative opposition and social instability will weigh on these efforts; foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will remain weak in 2023-27, averaging just 0.6% of GDP, and will be concentrated in extractive industries. The outlook for FDI could improve if Mr Lasso makes more progress on his policy agenda than we currently expect.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Ecuador Stocks and flows Ecuador has historically attracted little foreign direct investment (FDI). Annual inflows averaged of US$774m (0.8% of GDP) in 2011-17, during the presidency of Rafael Correa (2007-17), although his policies caused investor confidence to weaken. FDI inflows rose at the margin under Lenín Moreno (2017-21), reflecting a more conciliatory approach to the private sector, but they remained low, averaging just US$947m (0.9% of GDP) per year. EIU estimates that inflows averaged 0.6% of GDP per year in 2021-22, probably reflecting investor wariness, despite the market-friendly stance of the current administration, led by Guillermo Lasso. We estimate the total stock of inward FDI at US$22bn in 2022. This is one of the smallest stocks among major Latin American economies, equating to 20.2% of GDP.
Origin and distribution Sources of FDI to Ecuador have changed significantly in recent years. As total FDI figures are low, a single major investment has a huge influence on the overall make-up of FDI at any one time. For example, Canada was the biggest investor in 2018-21, owing to the development of Fruta del Norte (Ecuador's first large-scale gold mine) by a Canadian firm. US firms used to be Ecuador's main source of FDI but disinvested in the country in 2008-10 amid uncertainty over oil contract renegotiations and the global financial crisis. FDI levels from the US have never fully recovered and have since stabilised at a lower level than previously, accounting for of about 7% of inflows in 2018-22. Chinese FDI rose rapidly in 2011-21 as bilateral trade and diplomatic ties strengthened, but inflows moderated to an average of 6% in 2018-22. The extractive sectors attract most of the inflows; almost half of FDI in 2017-21 went to mining and hydrocarbons. The manufacturing, agri- and aqua-culture, and retail sectors also attract foreign investment.
Determinants Historically, FDI into Ecuador has been primarily resource-seeking, given the country's natural resource endowment, particularly in the hydrocarbons industry. However, policy uncertainty, weak institutions and an unreliable business environment have constrained investment. On top of this, the small domestic market, a relatively high cost of labour and low income levels still deter market-seeking or efficiency-seeking investments. The Lasso administration has stepped up efforts to attract private foreign investment by providing tax incentives and increasing legal certainty. This trend started under Mr Moreno, whose government focused on promoting investment in the extractive sectors and eliminating a 70% "windfall tax" on profits in mining. However, this has not yet translated into a major increase in inflows of FDI.
Impact The impact of inward FDI on productivity and export competitiveness has been limited because most investment has been directed towards capital-intensive natural resource sectors, which have weak links to the rest of the economy. However, FDI has helped to boost export earnings in the energy sector and to create indirect employment. Although technology transfer has been limited, oil revenue has supported the country's balance-of-payments position.
Potential The country's strong endowments of natural resources will be attractive to foreign investors, and FDI will continue to be concentrated in this area, although recent free-trade agreements (FTAs) could prompt some modest diversification. A more pragmatic approach to attracting private foreign capital and a shift away from the unorthodox policies of Mr Correa's government have increased the country's macroeconomic stability, and new FTAs (particularly one with China) will create another incentive to invest. However, policy uncertainty, infrastructure deficiencies and low labour productivity will continue to pose challenges. Political instability and social opposition to the extractive sectors (predominantly from powerful indigenous groups) constitute the biggest obstacles to attracting FDI, as investors will remain wary of policy shifts that undo recent improvements in the business environment. Powerful domestic interest groups will hinder efforts to open up investment opportunities in the oil sector. Sluggishness in consumption and relatively slow growth will also deter investment. On that basis, we expect FDI inflows to remain stable in the 2023-27 forecast period, at an annual average of 0.6% of GDP.

Population growth is slowing but is still high relative to developed countries Population growth has been slowing for decades, and EIU expects this trend to continue in the 2023-27 forecast period, owing to a falling birth rate and continued-albeit lower-emigration. We expect the population to grow by an annual average of 1% per year, which is similar to the regional average but high compared with developed-country standards. The population reached an estimated 18m in 2022 and should rise to 18.9m by 2027.
A falling birth rate is acting as a brake on population growth, which we expect to come in at an annual average rate of 1% in 2023-27-similar to the regional average. Labour force growth will still outstrip population growth, sustaining a demographic dividend throughout the forecast period. However, this trend will fade in the next decade, complicating prospects for Ecuador's convergence with more developed economies in the region.
At about 65% Ecuador has a lower urbanisaton rate than its regional peers, although it has fallen from the rate of 55% recorded in 1990. We expect this percentage to rise only slightly by 2027. Almost half of city dwellers reside either in the capital, Quito, or in the largest city and main business centre, Guayaquil. Urbanisation over the past 50 years has increased the level of informality, as the creation of full-time jobs has risen much more slowly.
Unemployment stood at 3.8% in the fourth quarter of 2022-similar to the same period of 2019. Although this points to a recovery from the covid-19 shock, the quality of jobs has deteriorated, and the rate of adequate employment is still below pre-pandemic standards. We expect the labour force to continue to expand faster than the overall population during the forecast period. Efforts by the current president, Guillermo Lasso, to boost formal job creation by liberalising the labour market have lost steam owing to strong political opposition. As a result, the formal economy will struggle to absorb new entrants, and informal employment, which the government estimated at 54.3% of the labour force as at February 2023, is likely to stay high. The large size of the informal sector constrains productivity and consumer purchasing power, as well as the government's revenue-raising (and public investment) capacity.
Government will struggle to integrate Venezuelan migrants The Lasso government's efforts to step up the regularisation of Venezuelan migrants should increase the size of the labour force marginally, although it will also increase competition for low-skilled jobs, putting downward pressure on job quality and wages, particularly for young Ecuadoreans who have only primary education. Ecuador has taken in more than 450,000 migrants from Venezuela, and successive governments have struggled to integrate them into the formal job market, especially given the economic shock from the pandemic. The country's slow economic recovery may well deter Venezuelan migration in the 2023-27 forecast period, as Venezuelans will be more attracted to stronger neighbouring economies.
Progress in improving healthcare and education standards will be slow The vulnerable state of the public finances will hinder improvements in education and healthcare. Strong oil revenue during the 2000s commodity boom helped to reduce poverty levels and improve social indicators following decades of underinvestment. However, even though education and healthcare now account for a much larger share of public spending than they did in the past, standards are still fairly low. For example, the government has only partly reversed a long-standing medicine shortage in hospitals. Moreover, according to (latest available) World Bank data from 2018, 61% of ten-year-olds were unable to read and understand a simple text-a slightly worse result than for Ecuador's regional peers (59%) but significantly better than other upper-middle-income countries (40%). Regular labour conflicts with public healthcare and education workers-often resulting in industrial action-have hampered efforts to improve service quality. The 2008 constitution promised free universal healthcare and education, but the government will struggle to deliver on this, given its straitened fiscal circumstances and the large informal economy. Improvements in education and healthcare will be only gradual in 2023-27, with progress crippled by narrow scope for raising spending.

Ecuador is one of the smaller markets in EIU's business environment rankings, accounting for about 0.1% of global GDP and a similar share of global exports. It is in theory attractive as a location for resource-seeking investment, given its large endowment of natural resources, and we do expect the country's oil and mineral reserves to continue to attract interest from foreign investors. Although market-friendly reforms enacted by the current administration, led by Guillermo Lasso, have improved the business environment and made the country more attractive to investors, concerns about long-term policy predictability-particularly a return to the left-wing policies implemented by a former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17)-and difficulties inherent in making material improvements to the business environment are likely to preclude a sharp increase in investment in natural resources.
Ecuador's market will expand, but only modestly Ecuador's attractiveness as a location for market-seeking investment is constrained by low incomes, high poverty rates, high income inequality and a large informal economy. Boosted by a rising population but hindered by slow economic growth, GDP per head will expand modestly in the forecast period, to US$14,963 in 2027, which is just two-thirds of the Latin American average. Moreover, Ecuador's per-head income figures will disguise wide inequalities: we expect reductions in income inequality to be marginal at best in 2023-27. Households appear to have suffered long-lasting damage from the covid-19 shock, as the rate of adequate employment is still more than 3 percentage points below pre-pandemic levels. Similarly, although the poverty rate is in line with its pre-pandemic level, at 25.2%, it is still significantly above the 21.5% recorded in December 2017. These factors will constrain overall market growth throughout the forecast period. On a more positive note, changes in consumer behavior-namely higher demand for modern retail shopping-will create attractive market opportunities for businesses. Moreover, low growth in per-head income has increased dynamism in the the low-cost segment, such as discount stores.
Ecuador is not a major destination of efficiency-seeking investment. As a result of dollarisation and successive years of guaranteeing a "living wage" (essentially a minimum wage), Ecuador is no longer a cheap-labour investment location. In US dollar terms, the country has one of the highest minimum wages in Latin America. Also weighing on the country's competitiveness are low skills levels. On a brighter note, dollarisation provides investors with greater overall macroeconomic stability, particularly by reducing inflation and exchange-rate risks. We assume that investment in most areas outside the oil sector will be slow to arrive, as improvements in the business environment will be only incremental and are at risk of reversal, given political turmoil. Moreover, we do not expect significant progress on improving the transparency and efficiency of the judicial system. A positive outlier is the booming shrimp export industry, where Ecuador has gained technical sophistication and is becoming a global leader. We expect this sector to continue to attract investment as demand from Asia and new free-trade agreements (FTAs) increase export opportunities.

Business opportunities will be limited by low levels of development Although inflation has started to ease from its 2022 levels, real disposable incomes will rise only gradually amid sluggish growth, meaning that the shift in consumer attitudes towards cheaper brands and lower-cost, high-volume outlets will continue. Over the medium to long term, we expect purchasing power to pick up as labour market conditions improve. Rising incomes will mean that a smaller proportion of real disposable income is spent on food and housing, and that consumer durables and other high-ticket items account for a larger share of spending. The proportion of income spent on leisure and education, hotels and restaurants, and other high-end goods will remain low. However, Ecuador's market will remain relatively small, hindered by slow economic development.

Low levels of productivity and a wealth of natural resources give Ecuador scope to catch up with more developed countries, provided that policies are implemented to transform its resource wealth into productive investment in other sectors. Although EIU expects Ecuador to benefit from dollarisation and incremental improvements to the business environment, poor prospects for significant improvements to institutions bode ill for stability in the direction of economic policy. Assuming that structural deficiencies, governability obstacles and inconsistent policymaking endure, long-term investment is likely to be lacking and income levels will continue to trail developed-country levels. On this basis, EIU expects Ecuador's per-head GDP to be only 17% of that of the US (in purchasing power parity terms) in 2050-unchanged from 2022.
Initial conditions: Ecuador's GDP per head is one of the lowest in South America, at an estimated US$6,069, which equates to US$12,766 in purchasing power parity (PPP) terms. For comparison, Ecuador's per-head GDP is less than a tenth of the US figure (and less than a fifth at PPP). A series of boom-bust cycles has prevented sustained growth; GDP grew at an average of 3% per year between 1990 and 2019 (a modest pace, given Ecuador's stage of development). Political instability, weak institutions and high levels of poverty and inequality-combined with an overdependence on oil-have led to a rent-seeking and unproductive economy that is plagued by low education levels and productivity, and by high labour informality. Ecuador's human capital and infrastructure standards significantly lag those in developed economies.
Although dollarisation, which was adopted in 2000, has shielded the public finances from both inflation and devaluation risk, it has also made Ecuador less competitive and has not prevented fiscal mismanagement, as occurred during the government of Rafael Correa (2007-17). The large fiscal deficit has narrowed significantly since 2020, owing to consolidation efforts and high oil prices. Moreover, full dollarisation means that Ecuador has no monetary independence and has lost the ability to use policy interest rates or currency devaluation as macroeconomic policy levers.
Demographic trends: Population growth is set to fall gradually over the long term, from an average of 1% in 2023-30, to 0.7% in 2031-50. The main driver of this trend will be lower fertility, in addition to some net migration. Ecuador's demographic dividend will be over by the end of the decade, as the working-age population will no longer be growing faster than the overall population. Still, both demographic groups will grow at similar levels through 2040, keeping the dependency ratio low. The main challenge facing the country will be to create enough formal jobs for entrants to the labour market, so as to reduce informality. There has been some progress in expanding education to improve labour quality, but the lack of dynamism in the private sector means that there is a substantial risk of labour informality remaining high in the long term, particularly as the covid-19 pandemic appears to have done lasting damage to the labour market. Efforts will also be required to address the pension needs of an ageing population, which could increase strains on the country's already-vulnerable social security system.
External conditions: As a small, open economy, Ecuador has benefited from rising global trade, although it remains vulnerable to changes in commodity prices. This causes significant external and fiscal volatility, as demonstrated by frequent booms and busts depending on prices of oil (the country's biggest export). Inconsistent trade policies and the country's geographical distance from its biggest trade partners (particularly the US and the EU) have dampened possibilities for stronger integration with industrialised nations. Recently negotiated free-trade agreements (FTAs), particularly with China, will bolster trade and diversify the export basket, but oil will remain the dominant source of receipts. There is scope for increased trade integration with neighbouring countries, but a lack of supply-chain strategies and infrastructure constraints will hinder progress. There has been some success in export diversification towards the Middle East, Russia and Asia, but Ecuador's small and distant market will weigh on its competitiveness profile, particularly compared with Asian emerging markets. As the economy is likely to remain heavily reliant on hydrocarbons and some mineral and agricultural products, the health of the external sector and GDP growth will hinge on the direction of terms of trade.
Future governments will struggle with a weak institutional framework Institutions and policy trends: Ecuador's institutions have long suffered from periods of instability. Military coups, protests and opposition from the legislature have forced three presidents from office, and the incumbent, Guillermo Lasso, is at risk of suffering a similar fate. Inconsistency in conceiving and implementing new legislation remains a major problem. Successive governments have changed the policy direction. Although power is concentrated in the executive, a highly fragmented political and social landscape complicates governability. We expect these deficiencies to remain over the long term, as a weak and personalistic party system will complicate governments' efforts to adopt structural institutional reforms. Regardless of their ideological inclination, administrations will continue to struggle with a weak legal framework, corruption and distorted policy priorities that either favour special interest groups or undermine the public finances.
Long-term performance: Unattractive investment conditions and the lack of a competitive, skilled labour force will make Ecuador a relatively unappealing destination for foreign investment in labour-intensive or manufacturing activities. However, sustained improvements in education levels, added to productive investment in non-oil sectors and technology transfer, could make Ecuador more competitive and boost long-term growth. For this to occur, the country would need to strengthen its institutional framework and improve its business environment. Our forecast suggests that progress on introducing structural reforms will be slow and insufficient for Ecuador to make progress on catching up (income-wise) with OECD countries in the long term. In 2050, at the end of our long-term forecast period, we expect Ecuador's GDP per head at PPP to be just 15% of the US level.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability Ecuador suffers from natural disaster risk via its exposure to multiple hazards, especially earthquakes, floods, volcanic activity and landslides; climate change is likely to exacerbate the frequency and magnitude of some of these events. In 2016 a 7.8-magnitude earthquake-the worst since 1979-caused US$3.3bn in damage and exacerbated fiscal strains stemming from low oil prices. Although disaster resilience has improved following the earthquake, climate change preparedness is lacking. Ecuador's geographical location and diversity render it particularly vulnerable: according to the UN's 2022 Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report, a temperature rise of 1.5 degrees would increase the population affected by floods in Ecuador by 300%. The country's consistent temperature year-round has hindered the development of glaciers, as they are not able to replenish lost density during colder seasons. Indeed, there has been a significant reduction in the size of Ecuador's glaciers in the two main mountain ranges-the Cordillera Oriental and the Cordillera Occidental-which in aggregate have been reduced by about a third over the past 50 years. By 2050 this trajectory will jeopardise the water sources for the country's major urban centres, including the capital, Quito. Rising temperatures will also affect agricultural production, as warmer winters will cause crops to sprout prematurely, and greater volatility in precipitation rates will disrupt production. Moreover, climate change could intensify weather effects relating to the El Niño phenomenon, which tends to bring higher temperatures and heavy rainfall that affect crops and fisheries.
Ecuador's dependence on the oil industry will accentuate energy transition risks in the medium to long term. Moving away from oil would have serious negative implications for growth prospects and would remove the state's biggest source of revenue (oil accounts for about a third of the total). On that basis, EIU expects a very slow transition away from oil as demand for the fuel declines gradually. In terms of electricity generation, hydroelectric power accounts for about 90%. Although this high share keeps emissions down, hydroelectric infrastructure can suffer from climate-related damage; for example, soil erosion can force costly repairs. We expect the government to promote the transition towards other renewable sources in the long term, which will diversify the energy mix and should present business opportunities.
Migration and urbanisation Urbanisation in Ecuador is a relatively recent phenomenon and comparatively low for Latin America. The majority of the population has traditionally lived in rural communities in the mountainous sierra region. Since crossing the 50% threshold in 1990, the proportion of people living in cities has grown slowly, from about 62% in 2006 to 65% in 2022. The establishment of a middle class under a social spending and consumption-driven economic policy in the 2000s, particularly under a former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17), will sustain an increasing urban population. Meanwhile, security concerns in the north and environmental degradation in the sierra are likely to accelerate the pace of migration from rural areas to cities over the medium term. The country's infrastructure and natural resources will come under greater strain in that process, necessitating greater investment. There will be opportunities for public-private partnerships (PPPs) for infrastructure investment, but internal migration will also invite limited bouts of social unrest.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is EIU
Global data Commodity prices: IMF, IFS; non-oil
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: Brent average import prices
US and European GDP growth: OECD
US effective exchange-rate index: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
World trade growth: EIU aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
General government debt: includes debt of the non-financial and financial public sectors
Inflation: IMF, IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI), 2006=100Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
Lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on non-preferential loans. The rate is weighted by loan amounts
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Population and growth: Celade
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Costa Rica to prices in the US
Real exchange rate: EIU; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
US$ GDP at PPP: IMF, IFS; EIU; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
US$ GDP: IMF, IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
Abbreviations Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows EIU to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by EIU for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2018-22) and from EIU assessments for the forecast period (2023-27). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by EIU for 2018-22. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2023-27 are based on EIU assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; the EIU, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2018-22 ranges are then used to derive 2023-27 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2023-27, not to the likely situation in 2027 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2020 or 2025). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - EIU expects the president, Joko Widodo (known as Jokowi) to step down in February 2024, when his constitutionally stipulated final term ends. Given the high approval ratings enjoyed by Jokowi and his party, the Indonesian Democratic Party-Struggle (PDI-P), the party is well placed to retain its position as the largest party in parliament while its endorsed candidate is likely to secure the presidency. The next administration will maintain Jokowi's "big tent" approach to governance, ensuring policy continuity and political stability. Indonesia will further foster its ties with Association of South-East Asian Nation (ASEAN) countries. Ties with China will remain cordial but cautious.

- We expect Indonesia's business environment to improve in 2023-27 and this will lead to its global ranking improving. However, quicker improvements in the region mean that its regional rank will fall by one place to 14th. There will be significant progress in the taxes, infrastructure and labour market categories. The Government Regulation in Lieu of Law on Job Creation (known as the Job Creation Perppu) will lead to an improvement to the business environment on various fronts. However, legal uncertainty, corruption and bureaucracy will weigh on the overall score.

Exchange rate Rp:US$ (av) 14,850 15,266 15,098 15,594 16,213 16,579

- We forecast that Indonesia's economy will grow by an annual average of 5.2% in 2023-27; this is largely on a par with rates of growth before the pandemic. The government will continue to focus on improving the business environment to boost investment (domestic and foreign), particularly in infrastructure development. Investment into the mineral and extractive sectors will stay robust, despite the high interest-rate environment. Private consumption will remain the primary driver of GDP growth in 2023-27, expanding by an average of 5.2% per year. The growth of merchandise exports (particularly for commodities) in 2023 will be slower than that of 2022 but will be sufficient to keep the goods trade account in the black. The country's current account will remain in surplus in 2023-24, but will return to deficit from 2025 as domestic demand and, specifically, capital imports rise.

- With a population of 272m in 2022, Indonesia is home to close to 40% of the population in ASEAN. We forecast that population growth will continue to decelerate in 2023-27. The working-age population will grow at a slightly faster rate than the overall population, but will decelerate owing to falling birth rates. There are considerable differences in growth rates and density among Indonesia's various provinces.

- Indonesia's consumer market is one of the largest in South-east Asia, with a favourable demographic profile for consumer-oriented sectors in the medium to long term. GDP per head will remain modest, however, ensuring that demand will be greatest for lower-cost goods. Personal disposable income will grow substantially over 2023-27. The proportion of income spent on food is likely to fall, with a bigger proportion spent on clothing, footwear, transport and communication, among other discretionary purchases. A growing urban high-net-worth population in cities means that there will also be an expanding market for high-end consumer goods.

- Indonesia will maintain a healthy economic expansion during the long-term forecast period. The average age of the population will increase slowly, which will temper growth momentum towards 2050. Steady progress in improving the business environment, notably in easing regulations, will boost investment and increase productivity. As the largest economy in ASEAN, Indonesia will become an important player on the global stage and is likely to play a leading role in the functioning of ASEAN.

Background: Republican forces led by Sukarno (Indonesia's first president) declared independence from the Netherlands in 1945. Sukarno was ousted in a coup led by General Suharto in 1967, following a near-collapse of the economy. Suharto presided over three decades of authoritarian government before being forced to resign in 1998 amid an economic and social crisis. Indonesia then experienced far-reaching political reform, known as the reformasi period, which ushered in more democratic government, including direct presidential elections. In 2014 Joko Widodo (known as Jokowi) became Indonesia's seventh president. Jokowi is the first president to come from outside the traditional political establishment.
Political structure: In 2004 the president and vice-president were elected directly for the first time. Since then, the directly elected People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) comprises the 575-member House of People's Representatives (DPR, the legislature) and the 136-member Regional Representatives' Council (DPD). Since the fall of Suharto in 1998, the role of the DPR has been expanded and its power increased. Presidential and legislative elections were held concurrently since 2019.
Policy issues: In the short term, the government will focus on encouraging investment, primarily to create jobs and stimulate economic growth. This will be spearheaded by the Government Regulation in Lieu of Law on Job Creation (known as Job Creation Perppu), which has been in effect since end-2022. Its ratification by parliament in March 2023 will ensure its legal certainty. The authorities will seek to improve standards of governance and reduce corruption. The administration has also moved to remove barriers impeding foreign investment, including the dominance of state-owned enterprises in some industries, but economic nationalism overshadows policymaking.
Taxation: Marginal tax rates range from 5% to 35%. An 11% VAT is levied on most goods and services, and will rise to 12% in 2025. A special sales tax of 10-12.5% is imposed on most luxury items. The corporate tax rate is 22%.
Foreign trade: Data from Statistics Indonesia show that merchandise imports totalled US$229.9bn in 2022, up from US$189bn in 2021, while goods exports surged to US$292.5bn, from US$232.8bn in 2021. This yielded a substantial merchandise trade surplus of US$62.7bn, up from US$43.8bn in 2021.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Indonesia is a presidential democracy with a 575-seat legislature, the House of People's Representatives (DPR). The president, who is the head of government as well as head of state, is allowed to serve up to two terms in office. The current president, Joko Widodo (known as Jokowi), took office in October 2014 and will serve his second and final term, until the next election in February 2024. He governs with the backing of seven parties (out of nine in the DPR), which currently hold 471 out of 575 parliamentary seats. Jokowi's most significant backers are the Indonesian Democratic Party-Struggle (PDI-P) and Golkar, Indonesia's oldest political party.

The PDI-P-led coalition will dominate parliament even after the next election
Two major Islamic parties, the National Awakening Party (PKB) and National Mandate Party (PAN), are in Jokowi's coalition, ensuring support from Indonesia's conservative, right-leaning bodies. Indonesia's third-largest party, the Great Indonesia Movement Party (Gerindra), fielded its head, Prabowo Subianto, as a rival to Jokowi in the 2019 election. However, after his defeat, Mr Subianto joined Jokowi's cabinet as defence minister, with Gerindra joining the governing coalition. Against this broad coalition, the opposition parties-the Democratic Party (PD) and the Prosperous Justice Party (PKS)-will have only weak influence.

EIU expects Jokowi, who has a good track record of consensus building, to enjoy reasonably strong support from parliament during his remaining term in office. However, some component parties within the ruling Onward Indonesia Coalition (KIM) will endorse their preferred candidate for the upcoming presidential election, which may differ from the candidate preferred by the dominant Indonesian Democratic Party-Struggle (PDI-P). This will strain relations within the KIM. Periodic cabinet reshuffles to strengthen political consolidation of power have been a mainstay in Jokowi's tenure; he has reshuffled his cabinet seven times over his nine-year tenure. Further reshuffles are highly likely ahead of the next election in 2024, amid fraying ties between the PDI-P and its allies within the coalition. However, these parties will remain in the coalition until its dissolution before the next election.

Political outlook: Political stability The president, Joko Widodo (known as Jokowi), will maintain stability within government during his second and final term (which ends in mid-2024) through a broad parliamentary coalition and cabinet. His cabinet includes members of various parties, including former military personnel and religious leaders.
With this "big tent" approach, Jokowi has neutralised prominent critics in the opposition and managed to push through controversial policies. One drawback has been occasional policy missteps and reversals made to shore up internal support, but these have not swayed his public support enough to endanger his remaining time in office. The president's popularity among the electorate has remained resilient throughout the current period of high consumer price inflation and slowing economic growth.
Jokowi's perennial popularity owes much to the image that he has cultivated of a pragmatic leader from a humble background; this contrasts with elite figures who often hail from political dynasties. EIU expects his successor to maintain the big tent strategy, which will probably involve the losing candidates being included in the new administration. This will help to maintain political stability within the government, although these tactics will constrain the efficiency of policymaking. The Constitutional Court's decision in November 2022 to allow ministers to remain in office after declaring themselves as presidential nominees raises the risk of more instances of legislative deadlock ahead of the next general election, in February 2024.
Jokowi's anti-corruption drive will claim more high-level officials and prove popular with the public. Graft is rife in Indonesia, and the lack of robust institutional mechanisms to combat malpractice means that it will remain a risk to political stability in 2023-27. Major scandals, including those within the KPK, and rising concerns about corruption further undermine already low public trust in law enforcement agencies and the KPK. Nonetheless, we expect the next administration to ensure the continuity of the KPK.
Despite the passage of legislation to partition West Papua province into three new provinces in mid-2022, instability will persist in that region amid regular cycles of unrest followed by crackdowns. However, without major external economic or political support, separatist movements will be unable to mount a threat to Indonesia's sovereignty. Strict limits on access by international observers will remain the norm. The government's approach will combine tough near-term political and military tactics with a focus on long-term economic development. This approach will not reduce violence in 2023-27.
Easing consumer price inflation and stable economic growth will limit the likelihood of protests in 2023-24. A possible impetus could be the Government Regulation in Lieu of Law on Job Creation (also known as the Job Creation Perppu), which was ratified by parliament in March 2023. This replaces the Omnibus Law on Job Creation that was ruled unconstitutional in 2021, which was subjected to heavy criticism from student and labour unions. Changes included in the new law were relatively minor. Although the new law has been in effect since December 30th 2022, critics are likely to demand for more public consultations on it, as well as for it to be retracted. However, we do not expect the government accede to any of these demands.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness The country will make slow progress on political reforms in 2023-27. In 2014 the Constitutional Court ruled that the 2019 legislative and presidential elections must be held on the same day, which would increase the likelihood of the DPR being politically aligned with the presidency, reducing horse-trading between parties on the outcome of the presidential poll. However, the ruling did not remove the requirement that presidential candidates may be nominated only by parties or coalitions of parties. This means that presidential contenders will need to make compromises on their policy agendas either with the main political parties or a group of smaller parties. This might lead to narrow and populist influences on policymaking.
Improving the efficiency of the bureaucracy will remain a priority Corruption remains rife and extends to most levels of government and throughout the judiciary. Pervasive graft means that the legal system is unpredictable and frequently prioritises local interests. The Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) enjoys significant public support. However, its independence and power has been weakened; the KPK is now a regular civil service body regulated by an oversight board from the government. Some prominent investigators were disqualified from the organisation in the process. Although the KPK still demonstrates its commitment and capacity to prosecute senior officials (in early 2023 the incumbent governor of Papua was arrested on graft charges), its room for operation is curtailed by political factors. The KPK is likely to continue investigating senior officials without fear or favour, but its action will be subjected to more political pressure.
Appointments to public-sector posts are not always based on merit. At lower levels, cronyism and nepotism remains a significant problem, resulting in a lack of competence among many public officials. At higher levels, favouritism to keep the support of coalition partners is also a problem. Political dynasties remain deeply embedded within regional- and national-level governance structures; for instance, Jokowi's son and son-in-law occupied regional-level positions in 2021. Skill shortages in the civil service are also likely to remain a problem throughout 2023-27.
Political outlook: Election watch The next parliamentary and presidential elections are scheduled to be held concurrently on 14th February 2024. We expect the centre-left Indonesian Democratic Party-Struggle (PDI-P), which holds 128 seats in the 575-seat House of People's Representatives (DPR, the legislature), to maintain its position as the largest single party in the chamber. Public surveys give the PDI-P a consistent lead over its nearest rivals, Golkar (currently holding 85 seats) and the Great Indonesia Movement Party (Gerindra; 78), both of which are more right wing. An anticipated easing of consumer price inflation and accelerating economic growth from mid-2023 will augur well for the prospects of the incumbent PDI-P and its endorsed presidential candidate. Strong patronage networks in Indonesia prevent large swings in party support, although presidential voting preference is less partisan.
Presidential nominations will not be finalised until mid-2023, but we believe that the election will be won by Ganjar Pranowo (the governor of Central Java). Although the PDI-P, the party that Mr Pranowo belongs to, has yet to endorse a candidate, we expect it ultimately to support Mr Pranowo. This will reflect his popularity and status as a non-establishment candidate. Furthermore, Jokowi has also hinted his preference for Mr Pranowo as the party's presidential nominee, lending credence to his bid.
Two other candidates who have announced their bid for the presidency are Anies Baswedan (the former governor of Jakarta) and Prabowo Subianto (the incumbent defence minister and a previous presidential contender). Mr Baswedan is endorsed by the National Democratic Party (NasDem), while Mr Subianto is endorsed by Gerindra. In March the Central Jakarta court ordered the General Elections Commission to halt preparations for two years, following a lawsuit filed by a newly formed party. We expect the commission's appeal to overturn the decision to be successful.
Political outlook: International relations Indonesia will continue to strive for an omnidirectional foreign policy in 2023-27, aiming for no significant alignment towards one specific country or bloc at the expense of another. Nonetheless, there will be minor frictions stemming from territorial tensions between the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) and China.
Although Indonesia's insistence on neutrality-as seen recently in its dealings with Russia and Ukraine-will slow the development of relations with many Western countries, it will also offer benefits, including sustained investment and trade flows with its partners (particularly China and Russia). China is Indonesia's largest trade partner and a major investor in infrastructure, manufacturing and mining. Indonesia's reluctance to confront China directly over its persecution of its Muslim minorities will allow bilateral economic ties to remain close. However, Indonesia's ongoing development of a gasfield in an area of its maritime territory that is claimed by China will be a source of friction between the two countries. Another flashpoint that could escalate tensions is the planned code of conduct in the South China Sea, which is intended to prevent potential conflict and accidental incursions in the disputed area. Indonesia-as the chair for the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) in 2023-has made the code of conduct a priority in its policy agenda.
The government's attempt to portray Indonesia as a moderate Muslim country will be undermined by a new criminal code (Kitab Undang-undang Hukum Pidana, or KUHP) that raises the risk of political suppression. The code replaces an antecedent that was carried over from the colonial period. Coming into full effect in late 2025, the new code includes prohibitions on insulting the government, holding unauthorised demonstrations and disseminating fake news, which will be a cause for concern among international organisations and Western governments.

Indonesia's score in the EIU's business environment ranking is set to improve from 5.39 in 2018-22 to 5.96 in 2023-27. Consequently, its global position rises by two places, from 60th to 58th, but improvements in Indonesia's neighbours mean its regional ranking falls from 13th to 14th out of 17 economies. The increase in the overall score is driven by improvements in the scores for the political environment, policy towards private enterprise & competition, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. However, the scores for the macroeconomic environment category will deteriorate.
The country's large and growing consumer market ensures that it scores highly in the market opportunities category. This is complemented by its vast reserves of strategic commodities including nickel and bauxite. Indonesia's ratification of the Regional Comprehensive Economist Partnership (RCEP) in early 2023 and its membership in the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) will deepen regional integration and market access for its commodities exports. The score for macroeconomic environment, nevertheless, deteriorates in 2023-27 as the authorities grapple with significant volatility in the value of its currency and elevated inflation in the early part of the forecast period
Jokowi's "big tent" approach will be a mainstay in Indonesian politics The Ministry of Finance will continue to reform and simplify the tax burden, and retrieve unpaid revenue in 2023-27. The government will also introduce tax holidays to incentivise foreign and domestic investments into the new capital city and select industries in other provinces. These measures underpin Indonesia's improvement in the scores for taxes and policy towards foreign investment. Indonesia's score in the political environment category is expected to improve in the forecast period. The "big tent" approach adopted by the incumbent president is likely to be a mainstay in Indonesian politics, even after he steps down at the end of his term in February 2024.
