Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is EIU
Global data US and OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: EIU aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 1997=100
Domestic data GDP data: at constant 2010 prices
GDP growth by demand component: BPS, Indikator Ekonomi
US$ GDP: BPS, Indikator Ekonomi; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rates
Population and growth: BPS, Indikator Ekonomi
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Real GDP growth per head: growth in real GDP deflated by population growth
Inflation: BI; 2018=100
Exchange rates: IMF, IFS; market rates expressed as rupiah per US dollar
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
External debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Debt-service ratio: total debt service as a proportion of earnings from exports of goods and services
Abbreviations BI: Bank Indonesia
BPS: Statistics Indonesia
IFS: International Financial Statistics
Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows the EIU to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by the EIU for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2018-22) and from EIU assessments for the forecast period (2023-27). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by the EIU for 2018-22. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2023-27 are based on EIU assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; the EIU, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2018-22 ranges are then used to derive 2023-27 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2023-27, not to the likely situation in 2027 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2020 or 2025). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - The centre-right New Democracy (ND) government, led by the prime minister, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, is in the last three months of its four-year mandate. A deadly train crash in February 2023 has ignited public anger, upended the government's election plans and changed all calculations about the probable outcome of the next election. EIU assumes that it will be impossible to form a government after the election, which is likely to be in May, necessitating a second poll. We expect that support for ND will suffer as a result of the train collision and that it may also prove difficult to form a government after a second election. Greece is entering a period of heightened political uncertainty, which may have damaging consequences for the government's reform agenda. The outcome of the coming polls will depend in part on how the government responds to the deadly accident in coming months. The opposition parties will not necessarily benefit from the backlash against the state and the government, which may lead to abstention at the polls.

Greece--highlights: Business environment outlook

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.

- Economic reforms undertaken since 2015, and especially since the election in July 2019 of a pro-business centre-right government, have improved the outlook for the business environment in Greece. Owing to progress across many categories, Greece's score rises from 5.77 in the historical period (2018-22) to 6.99 in the forecast period (2023-27), pushing up its global ranking by 19 places, to 36th. However, Greece remains near the bottom of the regional ranking, at 15th.

Exchange rate €:US$ (av) 0.9 0.9 0.9 0.9 0.9 0.8

- The Greek economy rebounded strongly from the pandemic-induced recession of 2020, with real GDP growing by a cumulative 14% in 2021-22, despite the negative impact of Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. However, the sustained negative impact of high energy prices and inflation will weigh on household consumption and external demand in 2023, when growth is set to slow sharply. EU recovery funds and a continued recovery in tourism will support growth, but these will be offset by high interest rates and inflation, potential short-term energy shortages and a slowdown in euro zone markets. We forecast a pick-up in real GDP growth to 2.6% in 2024 and 3.4% per year in 2025-27 as the energy crisis eases and the impact of the war in Ukraine recedes.

- According to UN projections, the population will decline by an average of 0.4% per year in 2023-27 (the forecast period). At the same time, life expectancy is increasing, and in 2021 it was estimated to average 81.8 years-broadly in line with the EU27 average. The population structure by age already bears all the hallmarks of the demographic ageing process, with the decline in the working-age population and rise in the elderly population (65 years and older) projected to continue. The proportion of people aged over 65 is forecast to rise from an estimated 22.7% in 2021 to 24.7% in 2027. Population ageing will prove to be a burden on already heavily indebted social services, particularly the pension and healthcare systems.

- During the covid-19 pandemic GDP per head (at market exchange rates) slumped to US$18,010 in 2020-well below the EU average. This is forecast to rise to US$28,170 by 2027. This primarily reflects a relatively robust recovery in GDP, from a low base, but also a shrinking population. The pandemic and the war in Ukraine have had negative spillovers, but have also spurred positive changes, for example by accelerating digitalisation and the energy transition. The recovery of the tourism industry and the associated real estate sector will also revive market opportunities.

Greece--highlights: Long-term outlook   2023-30 2031-50 2023-50

Growth of real GDP 2.6 2.2 2.3

- We expect real GDP to grow at 2.6% per year on average in 2023-30 (3.1% per head). Over 2031-50 average annual GDP growth is forecast to be 2.2% (2.7% per head). Labour productivity growth is expected to average 2.9% per year over the entire long-term forecast period (2023-50). These impressive growth rates reflect catch-up growth in Greece, after the previous decade-long period of crisis and negative growth after 2010. However, the working-age population and labour force will shrink and will be a constraint, preventing faster catch-up growth rates.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule, Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign-debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's elevated public debt put the country's EMU membership into question, but that risk has receded.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. The 2010 crisis shook the traditional party system. Voters blamed the parties that ruled Greece after its return to democracy in the mid-1970s-namely New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which was in power in 2015-19, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA). However, in July 2019 ND returned to power and XA failed to win enough votes to enter parliament.
Policy issues: Greece exited its third economic-adjustment programme in August 2018, but will be subject to monitoring by its euro zone creditors for decades. The covid-related public-health crisis led to agreed fiscal targets and some structural reforms being put on hold. In the short term the government's main focus will be to implement its reform programme to maximise the use of grants and loans under the EU recovery fund, and responding to the economic challenges created by the war in Ukraine. In the medium to long term, the main challenges will be putting Greece's public finances on a sustainable footing, diversifying economic activity to reduce overdependence on tourism, improving the business environment, reviving the privatisation programme and reducing still-high levels of non-performing loans.
Taxation: The tax rate is 22% on corporate profits and 5% on distributed dividends. The top personal income-tax rate is 45%. The standard value-added tax (VAT) rate is 24%, but temporary cuts and payment deferrals have applied since the pandemic.
Foreign trade: In 2022 goods exports (fob) totalled US$56.4bn and imports (fob) amounted to US$97.5bn. The current account registered a deficit of US$21.2bn, equivalent to 9.9% of GDP.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Following the July 2019 general election the centre-right New Democracy (ND) party, led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, was returned to office with a majority of 158 seats in the 300-seat parliament. The ND government replaced a coalition comprising the dominant left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left-Progressive Alliance (Syriza), led by Alexis Tsipras, and the smaller, hardline nationalist Independent Greeks (ANEL). Several parties represented in the previous parliament, such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA), failed to reach the 3% vote threshold for parliamentary representation. In 2020, after a trial that had lasted five and a half years, an Athens court sentenced 57 leaders, members and associates of XA to a total of more than 500 years in prison on charges ranging from murder and assault to running or participating in a criminal organisation. In February 2023 parliament approved a motion that effectively banned the National Party-Greeks, founded by a convicted former member of Golden Dawn, Ilias Kasidiaris, from participating in the forthcoming election. The motion amended the electoral law to prohibit the participation in elections of parties led by convicted members of a criminal or terrorist organisation. Even before the political fallout from a deadly train crash on February 28th 2023, opinion polls showed that ND and Syriza had lost ground since the 2019 election, while the centre-left alliance Movement for Change (Kinal), which was rebranded as Pasok-Kinal in May 2022, had improved its standing.

Political outlook: Political stability A disastrous head-on collision between a passenger and a freight train on February 28th has changed all calculations about the timing and outcome of elections in 2023. The accident, which claimed at least 57 lives, including those of many students and young people, has led to an outpouring of grief and anger against the authorities. The ND government is under great pressure and has put aside plans to dissolve parliament and hold an election on April 9th. EIU expects that an election will be held in mid to late May, with a second poll being likely in late June or early July. Meanwhile, the government is in damage control mode and is prioritising dealing with the urgent rail safety and other issues arising from the crash.
The next election will be run on a proportional representation system and is unlikely to yield a viable government. The allocation of a bonus of up to 50 seats (in the 300-member parliament) to the highest-polling party will be reinstated in the election immediately following the next one. However, it is questionable whether a second election will be able to deliver a single-party government. Even if the initial anger subsides in the coming months, voters are unlikely to be forgiving at the polls whenever they are held.
Opposition parties have sought to ride the wave of public anger and unleashed a barrage of criticism against ND. However, losses for ND will not necessarily result in gains for the opposition, which cannot claim to have a good track record of managing the country's infrastructure or addressing the problems of the rail system. Instead, the tragedy is likely to encourage a higher abstention rate and a bigger protest vote, especially among the young. Syriza stands to lose the most in such an event, as the highest percentage of 18-24-year-old voters back the party.
The political blame game that is now unfolding over the fatal train crash will make for an ugly political atmosphere in the country and will preclude any chance of party co-operation and the formation of a coalition government. The chances of a coalition between ND and the centre-left Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok) had already dwindled following a spyware scandal in 2022, and intemperate attacks on the government by Pasok leaders after the train crash have further soured relations. A poor showing for Syriza at the next election would make it impossible for its leader, Alexis Tsipras, to form a coalition government with Pasok and MeRA25, a smaller left-wing party. Until a new government is formed, Greece will have an interim government led by ND, so political instability will be contained. However, a long period of election uncertainty would nevertheless hamper Greece's efforts to leave the instability of the 2010s behind it.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Greece scores poorly in relation to other developed economies on political and institutional effectiveness, as a result of the high levels of corruption, patronage and inefficiency affecting the government and the legal system. However, we expect a gradual improvement during the forecast period, driven by reforms carried out since the 2019 general election. Under the terms of Greece's financial assistance package, which expired in August 2018, the authorities committed to implementing a far-reaching reform of the public administration, judiciary and society more broadly. The ND government of 2019-23 has provided fresh momentum to the reform process, enacting reforms intended to improve government effectiveness, including one containing measures to address major shortcomings in the public administration. The outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic in March 2020 spurred efforts to implement digitalisation of many aspects of the public administration.
The establishment of a modern state and public administration was one of the four pillars of the reform agenda under the bail-out programme and the post-bail-out enhanced surveillance regime overseen by Greece's euro zone creditors in 2015-22. The main priorities have been to control the size and cost of the public sector and at the same time increase the efficiency of the public administration in the delivery of essential public goods and services. Reforms have been designed aimed at strengthening the institutional and operational independence of major institutions, such as revenue administration and the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT, the national statistics office), as well as improving the efficiency of the judicial system and tackling corruption.
Action to strengthen the public-sector recruitment system is continuing Efforts to reduce the size of the public administration have borne fruit, with the total number of civil servants having fallen from 900,000 in December 2018 to 820,000 at the end of 2021 (600,000 permanent and 220,000 temporary staff). There has also been some success in converting temporary positions into permanent positions. To increase its control over the hiring of temporary staff, the ND government reduced the number of exceptions used to bypass temporary staff hiring procedures. At the same time, the government strengthened the efficiency of the civil service recruitment system and reduced political interference by increasing the capacity of the Supreme Council for Civil Personnel Selection (ASEP), the authority responsible for civil service recruitment, by the end of 2022. The measures include stronger competition procedures, scoring classification procedures, temporary staff hiring procedures and the reorganisation of ASEP.
The European Commission's quarterly enhanced surveillance reviews have highlighted that there has been uneven progress in the depoliticisation of the public administration. This was supposed to be accomplished through renewal of the top management and the implementation of new selection procedures for all levels of senior management, including the replacement of political appointees. The Commission has also noted mixed progress in efforts to increase the efficiency of the judicial system, which is needed to enhance the business environment and revive investment. Greece's judicial system remains burdened by an excessive backlog of cases, especially tax cases (appealing tax decisions can take up to 12 years). The sector is subject to frequent strikes by the courts and the Bar Association.
In terms of the anti-corruption agenda, the ND government has made progress in implementing the relevant action plan, including through the adoption of recommendations by the Group of States against Corruption (GRECO). The authorities have repeatedly amended the legal framework for the financing of political parties to bring it into line with European best practice.
Following the end of the enhanced surveillance regime in August 2022, the Commission reported favourably about the results in November 2022. The government has accelerated digitalisation and technological adoption across many sectors, including the public administration, education and training, health, tourism, justice, employment, and culture. An end-to-end IT tax collection system is now fully operational, and there is enhanced functionality of the e-filing platform in administrative courts. Some 70% of cadastral mapping has now been completed, and 100% should be completed by the end of 2023.
We expect Greece to continue to lag most of its peers in the EU in institutional capacity and reform of the public administration and judiciary. There is a risk that over the medium term reforms could be rolled back or, more likely, diluted. However, the need to improve government effectiveness to meet the governance requirements for access to EU recovery funds, and the salutary impact of the February 2023 train accident, which exposed the deficiencies of state management of the rail system, could spur a more rapid improvement.
Political outlook: Election watch Opinion polls in mid-February 2023 showed that support for ND was at about 36%, with the second-largest party in parliament, the left-wing Syriza, at about 28%. Support for the centre-left alliance Pasok-Movement for Change (Pasok-Kinal) was at about 11%. The first polls to be released after the train crash will show the extent of the damage to the reputation of the incumbent and opposition parties. There is now a significant risk that no party will be able to form a stable government after a second election, despite the return of the bonus seat rule, given the political acrimony and likely voter dynamics. The risk of a third election has risen.
Political outlook: International relations Greece has strengthened its commitment to Euro-Atlantic organisations. The US sees Greece as a linchpin of stability in the Balkans, Black Sea and eastern Mediterranean regions, and the two countries are developing a strategic partnership encompassing energy and security. Greece has strongly supported the EU response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which involves the imposition of far-reaching sanctions.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey had ratcheted up in early 2023. However, a devastating earthquake in Turkey led to a recalibration of relations after Greece was one of the first countries to respond with humanitarian aid. The two countries remain at loggerheads over long-standing territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea and hydrocarbons exploration in the eastern Mediterranean. Other sources of tension include the refugee crisis in Turkey (stemming from the conflict in Syria), which exposes Greece to waves of migrants seeking to enter the EU. Both countries are members of NATO, which will reduce the chance of tensions escalating into military hostilities.

Economic reforms undertaken since the election in July 2019 of a pro-business government have improved the outlook for the business environment. Owing to progress in several categories, EIU's overall business environment score for Greece rises from 5.77 in the historical period (2018-22) to 6.99 in the forecast period (2023-27), pushing up its global ranking by 19 places, to 36th. Greece remains near the bottom of the regional ranking, at 15th. Greece's heavy reliance on tourism meant that the economy was hard hit by the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, but it rebounded strongly in 2021-22 despite the fallout from Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The economic recovery has proved resilient, but high energy prices and inflationary pressures prevented even stronger growth in 2022 and will result in a sharp growth slowdown in 2023.
The improvements are broad-based, but the biggest ones are in foreign trade and exchange controls, policy towards foreign investment, financing, policy towards private enterprise and competition, and market opportunities. Many of these improvements reflect the impact of the government's overhaul of the public administration since 2019 and a new momentum in digitalisation; generous state support for households and business during the pandemic and the war in Ukraine; reforms in the banking system to reduce the high level of non-performing loans; and consistent efforts to attract foreign investment.
Digitalisation and the green transition will spur improvements Greece exited the EU's enhanced surveillance mechanism in August 2022, but the economy will remain under EU scrutiny. Greece's creditors have adopted a more positive attitude towards the country's economic prospects, reflecting the ND government's pro-business legislative agenda. Yet addressing Greece's entrenched structural problems will be challenging. There remains a risk over the medium term that governmental changes could result in reforms being rolled back or diluted.


Enlarge this image.
Business environment outlook: Greece's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2023-24: There will most probably be two elections in the first half of 2023, which could disrupt the pro-business New Democracy government's effort to revive privatisation. A newly created "project readiness" unit will start to deliver results.
2025-27: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment 2023-24: Cutting bureaucracy will be a focus. Adoption of new incentives, including tax incentives, to encourage foreign investment. A further boost could come from EU recovery fund-related reforms.
2025-27: "Fast-track" legislation, together with inflows of EU funds, could help to drive an investment recovery in strategic sectors such as energy, tourism, transport, communications and healthcare.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2023-24: The removal of China's zero-covid policies could bolster the continued recovery in the tourism sector after the pandemic.
2025-27: The risk of Greece leaving the euro zone subsides further as the country's public debt profile improves.
Taxes 2023-24: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base while lowering rates. The government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Efforts are under way to simplify both tax structure and tax filing.
2025-27: Slow progress in cutting corporate tax and value-added tax (VAT) rates. Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up.
Financing 2023-24: Non-performing loans (NPLs) increase modestly. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for most debtors. Liquidity is likely to remain tight as interest rates remain high.
2025-27: Still-high NPL levels continue to hamper lending. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market 2023-24: Unemployment picks up again in 2023, before easing back, but remains high by international standards. Some sectors such as shipping and tech may suffer shortages.
2025-27: EU-funded job-creation schemes, particularly for young people, raise employment but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure 2023-24: Energy infrastructure becomes increasingly important as part of the green transition and as Greece aims to become a supply hub for the Balkans. The start of operations at a floating storage and regasification unit in 2023 may spur further investment in infrastructure.
2025-27: Technical assistance from the EU helps absorption of European funds to revive infrastructure investment.
Technological readiness 2023-24: High-speed internet rollout proceeds at slow pace. Use of electronic payments widens. Digitalisation of the public administration continues.
2025-27: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
5.2 6.1 68 60 17 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Greece's score and global ranking for the macroeconomic environment are relatively low, but both improve modestly in the forecast period. The country's large public debt, a legacy of the bailout era of 2010-19, and its significant current-account deficit will continue to hold back improvement in 2023-27. However, Greece has made good progress in many areas in recent years, including in improving the quality of policymaking and the institutional underpinnings for sound macroeconomic policies. Greece's external creditors have praised the government's efforts to keep reform implementation on track, despite the difficult circumstances of the coronavirus pandemic and the war in Ukraine.
The country exited from an enhanced surveillance regime in mid-2022, but will remain under routine surveillance by its euro zone creditors for many decades to come. Greece will be required to operate tight control of the public finances and undertake structural economic reforms to enhance growth, with the aim of drastically reducing the public debt in coming decades. The stock of public debt was the highest in the euro zone (as a share of GDP) at 195% in 2021, but this is estimated to have fallen by about 20 percentage points in 2022 as a result of strong nominal GDP growth. Waivers introduced after the coronavirus pandemic allowed the government to put in place hefty support packages consisting of deferring tax payments, moratoriums on foreclosures and subsidies. However, Greece is expected to return to a primary surplus of 1.1% in 2023, rising to 2.2% in 2024, to be followed by more gradual increases thereafter until 2060. Meeting these demanding primary surplus targets consistently over a long time horizon will be extremely challenging.
"Grexit" is not an appreciable risk in the medium term The improvement in Greece's macroeconomic and financial position over the past five years or so means that a Greek exit from the euro zone is no longer an appreciable risk in the medium term. Another debt write-down is unlikely, given that most of it is owed to Greece's official creditors, but financial markets have been more positive about Greek sovereign debt. The structure and maturity profile of the country's debt reduce the risks arising from external shocks and increased investor risk aversion, and Greece has a large cash buffer and a manageable short-term repayment schedule.
The main macroeconomic challenge will be adopting and sustaining the policies and reforms that will spur growth and reduce the debt over the medium and long term. The economy presents a mixed picture at the start of 2023, after two years of rapid growth which were in part an automatic rebound from the pandemic-related collapse of 2020. The public sector is still inefficient and the private sector hampered by red tape; demographic trends are not conducive to growth; the labour market requires further reform and unemployment is still in double digits; despite progress, the banking system is still burdened with bad loans; households are indebted, but debtors' primary residences have long been protected from foreclosure (though in a landmark ruling in February 2023 the country's supreme court cleared the legal ground for most foreclosures). If the incoming government in 2023 can maintain the reform momentum of recent years and make good use of large potential EU funds, the prospects for faster catch-up growth and a steady reduction in the public debt will improve.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
6.0 7.3 39 23 15 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Privatisation plans are moving ahead after disruption during the pandemic Progress towards liberalisation, enhancing competition and privatising state-owned companies has been uneven, largely because of weak implementation, but we expect improvement during the forecast period. State asset sales brought in only EUR2.9bn in 2011-15, but, according to the Hellenic Republic Asset Development Fund (HRADF), which is responsible for the country's privatisation programme, the total had increased to EUR9bn in 2011-20. There were a total of 48 privatisations over the course of the decade, bringing in an additional EUR20bn in spillover effects on top of the direct privatisation proceeds.

- The centre-right government that took office following the 2019 election made privatisation a policy priority, but the onset of the coronavirus pandemic in early 2020 set this process back. Privatisation revenue amounted to a mere EUR54m in 2020, against a target of EUR2.4bn. The government estimates that revenue reached about EUR600m in 2021 and 2022, well below the respective EUR1.8bn and EUR2.2bn targets. The target for 2023 stands at EUR2bn, the bulk of which (75%) pertains to the privatisation of the Egnatia highway, for which a binding offer has been received.

Efforts to promote competition are under way, but face headwinds
- Initial delays in launching the Hellenic Corporation of Assets and Participations (HCAP)-a sovereign wealth fund whose sole shareholder is the Greek state, of which the HRADF is a subsidiary-have been overcome. Under its strategic plan for the development, restructuring and sale of its assets, HCAP is working to improve corporate governance at the companies it manages. The profits will be used to pay down public debt and boost investment in the economy, but implementation is likely to be protracted.
- In August 2021 a concession to operate the Egnatia highway was awarded to a local construction firm, GEK Terna, and Egis of France. In May 2022 the port of Kavala was awarded to a consortium comprising BlackSummit Financial Group (US) and two local partners for a consideration of EUR33.9m and a further EUR36m of investments. In October 2022 the Igoumenitsa port was awarded to a consortium of Grimaldi (Italy) and a local partner for a consideration of EUR84m. Both transactions are to be concluded following regulatory approval. The northern port of Alexandroupolis attracted two binding bids for a 67% stake in September 2022, but in November the government cancelled the tender, saying that the port was geopolitically and strategically too important to relinquish. It will now remain in state hands. A fourth port, in Heraklion, tendered in 2021 attracted eight expressions of interest. A tender for a fifth port, in Volos, was launched in October 2022. The development of Hellinikon, the site of the former international airport, is progressing; a casino licence, which was a prerequisite, has now been awarded, and the breakdown of development land and assets that will remain public property has been agreed. Shares were transferred in June 2021. Subcontracts were awarded throughout 2022.
- The long-delayed sale of a 66% stake in the Hellenic Gas Transmission System Operator (DESFA, which is 31% owned by HRADF and 35% by Hellenic Petroleum, HELPE) to an international consortium comprising Snam (an Italian infrastructure company; 60%), Enagás (a Spanish energy company; 20%) and Fluxys (a Belgian natural gas transmission operator; 20%) was completed at the end of 2018. The conclusion of the DESFA process unlocked the process for the privatisation of the commercial division of the Public Gas Corporation (DEPA). DEPA has been split into DEPA Infrastructure and DEPA Retail, and Italgas of Italy acquired DEPA Infrastructure for EUR733m in September 2022.
- Laws put in place in 2011 and 2012 abolished restrictive practices in more than 150 professions, but they have not been fully applied. Implementation of the law has in many cases been left to professional groups, which have used their influence to maintain restrictive practices. Legislation has been passed to open network industries, but it is ponderous, and implementation will be slow.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
5.1 6.9 65 37 18 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Attracting foreign direct investment is high on the ND government's agenda The ND government has adopted a foreign direct investment (FDI) policy aimed at reversing a process of disinvestment that had been ongoing since 2010. Improving Greece's attractiveness as a location for FDI will be challenging. Persistent deterrents include complex and unevenly enforced legislation, frequent changes in tax laws, and obstructive bureaucracy. The government is scaling up efforts to mitigate these through the digitalisation of procedures, funded in part through the EU's post-pandemic Recovery and Resilience Fund.

- The third Economic Adjustment Programme (EAP) in 2015-18 included policies to speed up company registration, "fast-track" investment (by facilitating approvals and relaxing regulation) and simplify export rules. The fast-track legislation covers investments that are deemed to be strategic. Priorities include industry, energy, tourism, transport, communication, health and waste management. The fast-track process provides for approval in one month by the Interministerial Committee for Strategic Investments (DESE) and facilitation of licensing and permitting applications (against payment of fees) within two months by the Ministry of Development's Enterprise Greece agency. The process did not start out smoothly. By February 2020 only 15 investments had been approved, but a combination of the ND government's pro-business attitude and growing investor appetite resulted in this rising to 50 by February 2023.

Investors will be offered more tax breaks and fewer cash subsidies
- The investment incentives law (which provides for tax breaks and grants to promote regional development) involves the National Fund for Entrepreneurship and Development (ETEAN), which has now been recast as the Hellenic Development Bank (HDB). HDB operates in conjunction with commercial banks to provide financing for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). However, given Greek banks' high levels of non-performing loans (NPLs) and the difficulty facing banks in foreclosure cases, available funding is limited. HDB is supplemented by the development ministry with EU-led community support framework funding, as well as by Information Society, the government's technological consultancy arm. The result has often been confusing for SMEs, which have to invest a substantial amount of time in chasing up funding. The structure of the HDB was leveraged well during the pandemic, however; of the EUR15.3bn it has disbursed in its 20-year history, EUR6.2bn was pandemic-related support funding.
- In October 2019 the ND government passed Law 4635/2019 aimed at alleviating some of the bureaucratic burden in targeted sectors (for example, by simplifying the licensing of 5G mobile telephony antennas). Some of the highlights include speeding up litigation via the introduction of an electronic filing system, the introduction of private-sector auditors for the evaluation of investment plans and curtailing administrative delays in land use approval. In December 2020 5G licences were awarded for EUR372m. In March 2021 the government also mended fences with Eldorado Gold, a Canadian mining company, by signing an amended agreement covering many of the disputes that led to several lawsuits, which the government lost. The move was followed in April 2021 with additional licences and a EUR680m project finance facility from Greek banks in September 2022. Important investments were also announced in 2020 by Microsoft and Pfizer, followed since then by Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Google, among others. In 2022 the acquisition of a minority stake in a Greek fintech start-up, Viva Wallet, by JP Morgan set a new record with a US$2bn valuation. This was followed by a smaller acquisition of an audio software group, Accusonos, by Facebook's parent, Meta.

The "golden visa" scheme is likely to come under closer scrutiny by the EU
- In April 2013 an "investor ombudsman" service was set up to examine deadlocked investments and remove stumbling blocks. The ombudsman, which is part of Enterprise Greece, is available for investments in excess of EUR2m. Enterprise Greece also runs a "golden visa" programme, which grants investors residence permits when investing in the country. Close to 10,000 of these had been granted at the end of 2022. The bulk of these (63%) were for Chinese nationals, and 600 had been granted to Russian nationals. Following the invasion of Ukraine and the ensuing EU sanctions, Russian applications have been put on hold, and the EU has called for a common European framework for such schemes, especially as regards background vetting.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
6.9 9.6 56 7 18 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Greece's foreign trade and exchange regime has improved In September 2019 the newly elected ND government abolished the remaining exchange and capital controls that had been put in place in June 2015 to prevent a mass withdrawal of cash from the banking system at the height of the debt crisis. The restrictions contravened the rules of the common currency, but the European Commission deemed them justifiable to maintain the stability of the Greek financial system. Their abolition is one of the main factors behind the significant score improvement for Greece in this category in 2023-27.

- As an EU member, Greece is subject to a common EU foreign trade and exchange policy. Within the EU no tariffs or quotas are permitted, and the bloc has abolished most other non-tariff trade restrictions, such as health regulation that favours domestically produced goods. The EU has a customs union with Turkey; includes Norway and Iceland in the European Economic Area; and has a range of bilateral agreements enabling free trade and other economic exchange with Switzerland. Agriculture is excluded from all of these arrangements. Outside agriculture, trade with non-EU countries is mostly subject to moderate customs duties. The EU takes a liberal approach to trade in industrial goods. Average unweighted tariffs on these goods from "most-favoured nations" are 4%.
- The EU remains committed to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and its dispute arbitration procedures. Despite the change of administration in the US in 2021, efforts to resolve a long-standing appointment crisis at the WTO's Appellate Body have so far failed. This has undermined the effectiveness of the body's arbitration procedures, but Greece has so far been largely unaffected (directly) by the global pick-up in tariffs in recent years.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
5.1 6.2 70 48 18 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Efforts to reduce tax evasion will remain a government priority The government has made efforts to improve tax collection by reducing tax evasion and widening the tax base so that high tax rates can be reduced. The ND government, seeking to reverse the upward trend in tax rates over the previous decade, enacted a series of consecutive corporate and real estate tax cuts. After a delay caused by the pandemic, plans to widen the base for property tax by aligning property tax values with market prices resumed in 2022, causing furore at a number of local authorities.

- Further reform of the tax administration will remain a priority but has been painfully slow so far. The Independent Authority for Public Revenue (IAPR) began operating only in 2017 as an autonomous agency, following a series of ineffective reforms. However, with significant technical support from the Commission and the IMF, the IAPR has begun to shift from building its institutional capacity to enhancing its operational capacity and efficiency by adopting modern collection and audit tools, as well as increasing staffing levels. A new salary grid aimed at attracting high-calibre staff was passed in February 2021. Tax collection rose marginally (by 0.3%) in 2019, despite a reduction in rates, but in 2020 and 2021 the government adopted a series of deferrals, waivers and other measures to prevent business failures. This was reversed in 2022, when tax revenue increased by 14.7% compared with 2021 and by 7.4% compared with 2019. More widespread use of electronic payments has also helped to curb tax evasion.

Some tax cuts are under way, but high public debt will limit room for more
- Given the size of the public debt, the overall tax burden is unlikely to be reduced substantially during the forecast period. The corporate income tax (CIT) rate is one of the highest in the EU, at 22% in 2022 (down from 28% in 2019). The system is complex, adding to the administrative burden of compliance, and the burden of taxation on labour remains higher than the EU average.
- Efforts to improve the efficiency of the justice system have had mixed results, which suggests that progress towards reducing the backlog of tax appeal cases is also likely to be slow. Debt management units are being establised in all larger tax offices to concentrate on tax arrears that can be paid through the negotiation of instalment plans. All tax obligations must be settled through bank transfers coupled with tax identification measures; the use of cheques and cash has been abolished to reduce the scope for corruption of inspectors.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
5.9 7.4 45 29 18 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The banking sector is focused on NPL reduction Since 2015 Greek banks have made remarkable progress in strengthening their balance sheets by reducing exposure to non-performing assets. Outstanding NPLs in the banking sector fell from EUR118bn in June 2015 to EUR16bn in June 2022. NPLs as a percentage of the total loan portfolio declined from 43.2% to 9.5% over the same period. They fell further to 9.1% in September 2022. Nonetheless, the ratio is still the highest in the EU and far above the euro area average of 2%. The reduction in the NPL stock was achieved through both direct sales of NPL portfolios and securitisations. The latter was used by the four domestic systemically important banks. According to the Bank of Greece (the central bank), by May 2022 they had securitised approximately EUR50bn worth of NPL exposure: Piraeus Bank securitised close to EUR16bn of NPLs, Alpha Bank EUR14bn, Eurobank EUR12bn and National Bank of Greece EUR6bn. The Greek government facilitated the process through a scheme called Hercules, under which it guaranteed securitisation senior tranches. The Hercules scheme was initially approved by the Commission for December 2019 until April 2021, but was later extended until October 2022.

- Greek banks are due to be stress-tested again in 2023, with adverse scenario assumptions including a 1.9% GDP contraction in 2023 followed by a further 4.5% contraction in 2024 and only a marginal recovery of 0.9% in 2025. The results are to be published in July.
- The state's stakes in the systemic banks of the Hellenic Financial Stability Fund (HFSF), which is also a subsidiary of HCAP, were as follows in early 2023: Eurobank Ergasias, 1.4%; National Bank of Greece, 40.39%; Alpha Bank, 9%; Piraeus Bank, 27%. In late 2022 Saudi Arabia's crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman al-Saud, formally expressed interest in acquiring a 20% stake in National Bank of Greece, while European investors were reported to be interested in HFSF's stake in Piraeus Bank.
- There has been considerable improvement in credit and deposit growth in recent years. Aggregate retail deposits increased from EUR116bn in January 2020 to EUR139bn in September 2022. Growth in household deposits is primarily due to increased social spending during the pandemic and a robust economic recovery in 2021-22. Meanwhile, higher retail funding, combined with the release of previously unavailable capital following the balance sheet clean-up, allowed banks to ramp up lending to corporates. Credit activity was also supported by government policies during the pandemic; these included state subsidies and guarantees on corporate loans. The aggregate corporate loan portfolio, adjusted for loan write-offs, revaluations and reclassifications, grew by EUR6.6bn in 2020, EUR1.9bn in 2021 and EUR5.1bn in January-September 2022. However, over the past two years lending to households, which have been reluctant to take on extra risk, has declined. Credit to households shrank by approximately EUR4bn between January 2020 and September 2022, with the bulk of the decline attributable to falling mortgage issuance.
- We expect lending to the private sector to continue to be constrained owing to NPLs during most of the forecast period. Despite the Hercules plan, progress is held back by weak bank profitability, moratoriums on repossessions (although these have started to ease) and a likely new bout of bad loans. A new insolvency framework, intended to address many of the issues that have hindered banks' ability to clean up their balance sheets, may finally become operational in 2023.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
5.9 6.4 52 42 17 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Labour market is gradually becoming more flexible, but progress is slow Greece's labour market had long been one of the least flexible in the euro area, but this has been improving gradually, and it is likely to become more flexible in the coming years. Labour market liberalisation, economic recovery, emigration and government support during the coronavirus pandemic have helped to reduce the unemployment rate, which was 11.6% in December 2022, down from a peak of 27.9% in July 2013. Government measures prevented a sharp rise in unemployment during the pandemic-induced lockdowns, and, despite the measures being gradually withdrawn, unemployment has remained on a downward trajectory.

- High youth unemployment has led more than 400,000 young, educated Greeks to seek work abroad. With a labour force of about 4.7m, the negative effect on the labour market is huge. Government efforts to reverse the trend have focused mostly on temporary tax reprieves for those returning, and are neither alleviating the underlying structural deficiencies nor having much traction.
- In February 2019 the government restored a single rate minimum wage and increased the rate to EUR650 per month (14 annual payments). This was increased twice in 2022, by 2% in January and then by an additional 7.7% in May, in response to inflationary pressures. The minimum wage stood, as a result, at EUR713. A further increase is as being considered by the government, reportedly of a similar magnitude to that in May 2022, in advance of the 2023 election.

Statutory pension age has increased, and is likely to rise further
- Primary (pillar one) pensions in the public and private sectors were reformed in 2011, 2015, 2016 and 2017. The private sector is now almost exclusively served by a single fund that came about from the merger of eight smaller ones in 2017. The statutory pension age is 67, with 40 years of contributions necessary to secure a full pension. The minimum pension eligibility age is 62. In 2020 further reforms gave the self-employed greater flexibility in their choice of pension plan and digitised parts of the social-security process. The mounting complexity and specificity of consecutive reforms however, resulted in a backlog of pension applications that was only successfully tackled in 2022. The Ministry of Labour is considering plans for further digitalisation, but this is likely to happen only after elections in 2023.
- The statutory pension age and the minimum pension eligibility ages, of 67 and 62, will be revised every three years, with the next increase being in 2024, in line with life expectancy. In the future pensions will be based on full earnings history, and accrual rates will be reduced so that the replacement ratio will drop from about 80% to 64%.
- According to the OECD's Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) 2018 test scores (latest available data), 31% of Greek 15-year-olds were "low achievers" in reading and 36% in mathematics, compared with OECD averages of 23% and 24% respectively. Greece participated in the 2022 PISA assessment, but the results, which will also reflect the relative impact of the pandemic on education, have yet to be released. A series of reforms have been passed on the education front, covering vocational training (December 2020), higher education (February 2021) and primary and secondary education (August 2021). A further reform of higher education was undertaken in July 2022, with the aim of improving the skills base.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
6.8 7.3 33 29 15 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Major deficiencies in infrastructure will remain The poor quality of Greece's transport and communications networks is holding back the country's international trade and investment potential. Delays to plans to improve infrastructure arise for a variety of reasons, including scarcity of funds; administrative complexity; and political opposition at local and national level. The main gaps include the need to upgrade the rail network; improve interconnections between domestic and international transport links; overhaul the coastal shipping network to improve the accessibility of islands and reduce overreliance on the port of Piraeus; and promote multi-modal freight transport by improving rail connections to Trans-European Transport Network ports such as Thessaloniki.

- A high-profile train crash at a politically sensitive pre-election time in early 2023 may engender the political will to address dysfunction and delay and catalyse change. We expect the government to finalise the modernisation of the signalling and safety system on the railways in 2023.
- A lack of investment means that Greece has lagged well behind most of the rest of the EU in the move to fast broadband, in terms of both the availability of higher speeds and coverage.
- A motorway (Pathe) runs between Athens, the capital, and Thessaloniki, on the east coast of the mainland, and a highway-standard link (Egnatia) runs across the north from the port of Igoumenitsa to the Turkish border. However, nine uplinks from Egnatia to the Balkans remain uncompleted. The tendering of a long-term concession for Egnatia and three of its uplinks received repeated extensions until it was awarded in August 2021 to a local construction firm, GEK Terna, and Egis of France. The financial closing of the privatisation is expected in 2023.
- After long delays and re-routing, the southern portion of the Central Greece motorway is set to be completed in 2023. A northern portion costing EUR442m was agreed in early 2021 and is scheduled to be completed within three years. Auxiliary roadworks connecting central Greece to the Peloponnese without going through Athens were awarded in February 2023.
- In 2017 Germany's Fraport entered a 40-year concession to manage 14 regional airports. It paid EUR1.2bn upfront and will pay an annual flat fee of EUR23m and a portion of operating profits. In 2019 an agreement to extend the concession for Athens International Airport (AIA) for 20 years (from 2026 onwards) to the concessionaire was signed for EUR1.4bn. The state subsequently started a tender to sell HRADF's 30% stake in the airport, but the process stalled during the pandemic. Both companies were compensated by the state to mitigate the impact of the pandemic, and HRADF is reported to be considering a listing of AIA through a public offering of its stake.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27 2018-22 2023-27
6.3 7.2 46 41 18 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Greece scores poorly on technological readiness, which measures how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption. The country has risen up the ranks owing in part to the ND government's push towards digitalisation.
Greece scores poorly on technological readiness, but has risen up the ranks
- The Inclusive Internet Index (published by Economist Impact, an EIU sister company) ranks Greece 18th out of 100 countries in 2022, up from 38th in 2021. The index ranks countries on four axes: availability, readiness, affordability and relevance. The improvement in 2022 came mainly in the relevance axis, which ranks Greece second globally. It still scores poorly on readiness (48th). The EU's Digital Economy and Society Index (DESI) ranked Greece 25th out of 27 in 2022. In the UN's E-Government Survey 2022 Greece was ranked 33rd out of 193 countries for e-government development-up from 42nd in 2020. In the World Digital Competitiveness Ranking produced by the International Institute for Management Development (IMD), Greece ranked 50th out of 63 countries in 2022.
- In 2017 Greece's telecoms regulator approved a two-year roll-out plan for very-high-bitrate digital subscriber line (VDSL) vectoring technology to improve high-speed internet availability. The plan has faced delays, and the government now hopes to provide internet access of more than 100 Mbps to at least 70% of households by 2023, up from a target of 50% by 2020. Take-up was less than 3% in 2022 but had tripled in two years, spurred by the pandemic. In terms of broadband price, Greece still ranked third from last in the EU.

Economic forecast: Policy trends In the medium term, the main economic policy challenges for the next government will be diversifying economic activity to reduce overdependence on tourism, improving competitiveness and putting the public finances on a stronger footing. In the short term, the government is addressing risks to the economy from surging international energy prices, which the war in Ukraine has exacerbated.
The recent train crash will also demand government attention and resources in the coming months. The government has sought the help of the European Commission in planning its response. The accident will result in more scrutiny of forthcoming privatisations, including the listing of Athens International Airport and the disposal of the state's stake in the Attica Tollway, which could face delays.
The government is implementing a series of structural measures, including making permanent a temporary 3% reduction in social-security payments, the abolition of certain surcharge taxes, an increase in pensions (especially low-end pensions), a pay increase for doctors and a pay review for the public sector.
Greece is eligible for a total of EUR30.5bn (about 18% of GDP) from the EU recovery fund, comprising EUR17.8bn in grants and EUR12.7bn in loans, which is designed to support the member states worst affected by the pandemic. Added to the EU's multiannual financial framework, this means that Greece potentially has access to a total of EUR72bn in EU funds in 2021-27. The impact of this could boost real GDP growth by 2-4 percentage points over the medium term. The government's reform plan focuses on the green and digital transformation and on measures to boost employment, social cohesion and private investment. In late November the EU approved the release of Greece's second tranche of funding from the Recovery and Resilience Facility, amounting to EUR3.5bn.
To support investor confidence, the government maintains a substantial cash buffer, currently worth about EUR35bn, enough to cover the government's financing needs for almost two years. In 2022 the Public Debt Management Agency issued EUR8.3bn in medium- and long-term debt (below a planned issuance of EUR12bn as a result of market volatility). It targets a more modest EUR7bn in borrowing in 2023, though it may additionally issue its first green bond, which was originally planned for 2022. In 2022 the agency completed the early repayment of the remaining EUR1.8bn of Greece's IMF loans and also pre-paid EUR2.7bn in loans from the Greek Loan Facility, due in 2023, with the aim of lowering borrowing costs and improving the country's debt maturity profile.
Financial assistance from the EU recovery fund and support from the European Central Bank (ECB) have helped to contain government borrowing costs in recent years. However, ECB monetary policy tightening has put upward pressure on Greek government borrowing costs, reflecting higher euro zone bond yields more generally. The yield on Greece's ten-year benchmark bond was 4.1% on February 3rd, compared with 1.9% a year earlier. A further increase in risk aversion in global financial markets could cause Greek yields to rise more sharply.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators

EIU estimates that the budget deficit narrowed sharply to 4% of GDP in 2022, reflecting strong nominal GDP growth. We forecast that the deficit will shrink gradually to 0.9% of GDP in 2027, with the primary balance returning to surplus from 2024. Greece's fragile public finances deteriorated sharply in 2020-21 as a result of the economic slump in the first year of the pandemic and huge fiscal stimulus over both years. Some pandemic-relief measures were extended into 2022, and additional support was introduced to mitigate the impact of surging prices on households and businesses. The government will delay tightening fiscal policy until later in 2023, and it will probably do so more gradually than previously assumed because of the increased risks from the war in Ukraine. Nevertheless, we expect the public finances to improve during the forecast period, owing to sustained economic growth and the disbursement of grants and loans under the EU recovery fund. Economic recovery, a narrowing deficit and strong nominal GDP growth will help to reduce the public debt/GDP ratio, which we expect to fall to about 153% by end-2027.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2022 2023 2024 2025 2026 2027
Commercial banks' prime rate (av) 4.8 8.0 8.0 7.2 6.2 6.0
Long-term interest rate (av) 3.5 4.4 4.5 4.3 3.9 3.9
The ECB raised its interest rates by another 50 basis points at its most recent monetary policy meeting, on February 2nd. Underlying inflationary pressures in the euro zone underpinned the ECB's decision. Average inflation in the euro zone slowed to 8.5% in January, but core inflation was unchanged at 5.2%-a record high. The bank said that it would continue its tightening cycle at a steady pace, keeping interest rates at levels that were "sufficiently restrictive to ensure a timely return of inflation to its 2% medium-term target". Following a cumulative 300-basis-point increase in policy rates since July 2022, we expect another 100 basis points of increases in 2023 (50 basis points in March and 25 basis points in both May and June), with short-term interest rates settling between 3.5% and 4% by mid-2023. We expect interest rates to remain at this peak level for at least a year (longer than markets are currently expecting), with the first rate cut coming in the third quarter of 2024.
The ECB also confirmed that it would start reducing its balance sheet by EUR15bn a month from March until end-June. In recent years the ECB has absorbed the bulk of new public debt issuance, which has helped to insulate governments from market pressures. The combination of higher interest rates and quantitative tightening will increase sovereign risk premiums, raising financing risks for peripheral economies. The ECB has announced the creation of a new anti-fragmentation tool, the Transmission Protection Instrument, which aims to avoid the widening of yield spreads within the euro zone. The instrument can be used only in cases of acute bond market volatility that are not driven by country-specific fundamentals. Nevertheless, we believe that the ECB would intervene in response to a crisis that endangered the bloc's financial stability (not our core forecast).

Just-released preliminary real GDP data for the fourth quarter of 2022, and revised data for all previous quarters, show real GDP growth at 5.9% in 2022 (the full revised data are not available in our tables). Growth in 2022 was mainly driven by robust private consumption despite higher price inflation, strong fixed investment and stockbuilding, and a continued recovery in the important tourism sector.
We expect annual real GDP growth to slow sharply to 1% in 2023. Disbursements from the EU recovery fund will support growth in 2023, but these will be offset by still-high inflation, potential short-term energy shortages and a slowdown in major euro zone markets. We forecast a pick-up in real GDP growth to 2.6% in 2024 and 3.4% per year in 2025-27 as the energy crisis eases and the broader impact of the war in Ukraine recedes.
A combination of high unemployment, rising prices, high direct and indirect tax rates, heavy household debt relative to disposable income, fiscal tightening, and tight credit conditions will put pressure on private consumption in 2023-27. Following a rebound in 2021-22, driven largely by the release of pent-up demand after the first pandemic-related lockdown in 2020, we expect a slowdown in 2023, reflecting the erosion of households' purchasing power by inflation. We expect growth in private consumption to average 2.6% per year in 2024-27.
Government consumption increased sharply in response to the pandemic and the energy crisis, but contracted by 1.6% in 2022, and we expect more modest rates of negative growth in 2023-25, with spending falling by an annual average of 0.5%. Thereafter, we forecast average annual growth of 1% in 2026-27. Pressure on Greece to tighten fiscal policy will be partly offset by a boost to government spending from the EU recovery fund.
We expect the disbursement of EU recovery funds to continue to support real fixed investment growth in Greece, which we forecast will average about 11% over our forecast period. However, there are downside risks from the energy crisis and monetary tightening, and the recovery will only partly offset the severe depletion of Greece's capital stock during the previous economic crisis.
Tourism, which before the pandemic accounted for about 25% of GDP (including indirect effects) and about half of overall economic growth, was badly affected by pandemic lockdowns and travel restrictions in 2020-21. Tourism revenue in 2022 surpassed the record of 2019, at EUR15.7bn according to the balance of travel services on the current account. We forecast that annual growth of exports of goods and services will average 6.4% in 2023-27, following lacklustre growth of 4.9% in 2022.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Greece's economy is driven by services, particularly tourism and shipping, and also by the real estate sector (closely related to tourism) and financial services. All of these sectors were badly affected by the coronavirus pandemic and the restrictions put in place to contain it. However, in 2021-22 all of these sectors recovered and performed strongly. Prospects for the next five years are positive, despite some headwinds in 2023. The government is seeking to diversify the economy further to reduce overdependence on tourism by focusing on the development of green and digital industries. Greece's strategic location as a potential energy hub for south-east Europe and its access to significant EU structural and recovery and resilience funds will create opportunities to diversify the country's economic mix, but this will require political commitment and a business environment conducive to investment.
Tourism will be a key driver of growth in services The tourism sector plays a major role in the Greek economy, accounting directly and indirectly for about 25% of GDP. Employment in the sector is about 11.5% of total employment directly and 22% including related sectors. The sector was badly affected by the coronavirus pandemic, with arrivals slumping to 7.4m in 2020 from 31.3m in 2019. Tourism earnings on the balance of services shrank to EUR4.3bn, or just 2.6% of GDP. A solid, but only partial, recovery was recorded in 2021 as arrivals jumped to 14.7m and earnings to EUR10.5bn, or 5.8% of GDP. Travel receipts increased by 67.9% year on year in 2022, to EUR15.7bn, beating the previous record year of 2019, when receipts totalled EUR15.4bn. The number of visitors remained below 2019 levels in 2022, but receipts were boosted by higher prices. We expect the sector to continue to recover steadily during the forecast period, supported by competitive pricing compared with other destinations in Europe; the release of continued pent-up demand for tourism services after the pandemic, including from China after the ending of zero covid policies; the further extension of the tourism year beyond the summer season; and positive global perceptions of Greece as a leading tourism destination.
Greece's shipping industry employs about 200,000 people and accounts for about 7% of the country's GDP, and has played an important role in driving economic growth in recent years. Earnings from shipping averaged about EUR13bn per year in 2015-21. Greece remains the leading shipping nation in the world, with a total fleet approaching 5,000, representing almost 20% of global deadweight tonnage and almost 60% of the EU's total fleet. Greece accounts for about 30% of the world's tankers, 20% of its bulk tankers, 17% of its chemical and product tankers, 16% of its liquefied natural gas (LNG)/liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) carriers and 10% of its container ships. Greek ship owners are expanding and modernising their fleet, with a total of about 200 tankers, carriers, container and cargo ships and other vessels on order for construction in China, Japan and South Korea. The war in Ukraine and the disruption of Russian hydrocarbons supply to Europe has underlined the importance of shipping in the transport of natural gas and has helped to mitigate the impact of the energy crisis. Greek shipping has benefited enormously from the expansion of Piraeus port under Chinese ownership, which has resulted in a major increase in capacity and connectivity, making it the fifth biggest port in Europe. The privatisation of Thessaloniki port has also resulted in an expansion of its capacity, to a lesser degree. Greece is focused on upgrading other ports at Alexandropouli and elsewhere as it seeks to expand its role as a transport and energy hub in southern Europe. One challenge will be to invest in training a future generation of workers for the shipping industry, especially as Greece seeks to lead the green transition in shipping.
The health of the real estate market is closely tied to the tourism sector Real estate activities contracted sharply in real terms in 2020 and recovered modestly in 2021, before rebounding in 2022. Net foreign direct investment (FDI) into Greek real estate rose from EUR875m in 2020 to EUR1.18bn in 2021, according to the Bank of Greece (the central bank). Cross-border investment into real estate remained strong in January-June 2022, totalling EUR788m, up from EUR462m in the corresponding period of 2021. The recovery in the property market was driven by an improved macroeconomic environment and a strong rebound in Greek tourism. However, rising property prices, high inflation and deteriorating real disposable incomes could undermine demand for real estate in 2023. A growth slowdown in the major European economies could also have a negative impact on the tourism sector and depress investment demand for Greek properties. Overall, the real estate sector will face strong headwinds in 2023, but we expect the recovery to continue, albeit at a more moderate pace.
The financial services sector went through a difficult period in the ten years to 2019, suffering from weak profitability, a huge depletion of assets, deleveraging and a major asset quality problem. A rapid balance sheet clean-up in recent years strengthened the Greek banking sector but depressed profitability, which finally recovered in 2022. The sector's growth prospects will be strongly correlated with political stability, continued reform progress and the continued reduction of non-performing loans (NPLs). The latter could rise again if insolvencies increase during harder economic times. Capitalisation of Greek banks remains one of the lowest in Europe and may not be sufficient to cover future spikes in NPLs.

Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised measure) accelerated to an average of 9.3% in 2022, mainly driven by surging global energy prices. We expect it to slow to 4.1% in 2023, reflecting base effects, but price levels will remain much higher than before the Ukraine crisis. With significant slack remaining in the domestic labour market and an easing of global price pressures, we expect inflation to slow further, averaging 1.8% per year in 2024-27.

The euro depreciated sharply against the US dollar in 2022, owing to a more aggressive monetary policy by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) compared with the ECB and the damage to the euro zone's terms of trade from the war in Ukraine via higher energy prices, which pushed the region's current account into deficit. However, the single currency has appreciated markedly against the dollar in recent months as the ECB has accelerated monetary tightening and Europe's economic outlook has brightened. We expect the euro to return to its pre-Ukraine-war exchange rate in the second half of 2023. The currency could depreciate against the dollar again if an energy crisis re-emerges during the 2023/24 winter (not our core forecast), weighing on the region's economy. Over the medium term, the value of the euro will continue to be supported by the euro zone's current-account surplus.

Greece's current-account deficit expanded sharply in 2022, to an estimated 9.9% of GDP, as a large surplus on the services account following a bumper tourism year failed to offset the impact on imports of higher global energy prices and a worsening in the primary and secondary income accounts. The deterioration in the secondary income balance was largely the result of ANFA/SMP profits not being transferred to the Greek government in December 2022 as they were in December 2021. We expect the current-account deficit to shrink to about 7% of GDP in 2023 and an average of 6.7% of GDP in 2024-27 as energy prices remain elevated, domestic demand recovers and the impact of further disbursements of EU recovery funds wanes.
