Political outlook: Political stability The former ruling coalition, comprising the centre-right Conservatives and two smaller centrist parties-the Liberals and the Christian Democrats-lost the September 2021 general election and was replaced by a centre-left coalition led by the Labour Party. The Conservatives lost significant support compared with their 2017 result, securing 36 seats, down from 45 (out of a total of 169). The party's popularity had ebbed after eight years in power, whereas the Labour Party's emphasis in their election campaign on addressing social inequality resonated with the electorate, particularly following the coronavirus-induced recession. The Labour Party secured 48 seats and leads a minority coalition with the populist-agrarian Centre Party (28 seats).
Despite the lack of a working majority, EIU expects political stability to remain firm by international comparison. This reflects Norway's solid track record of cross-party co-operation and consensus-building, as well as the fact that the Labour Party and the Centre Party are fairly well aligned in terms of policy priorities; these are likely to include addressing social inequality through increasing public investment in education and healthcare, as well as streamlining government services. The Centre Party is likely to press for measures to accelerate decentralisation and bolster infrastructure and incomes in rural areas.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Norway boasts a high-quality governance framework, similar to its Nordic peers. With its long tradition of transparent parliamentary democracy, the country's multiparty structure and consensual style of politics have tended to deliver legislation that is typically passed after broad consultation with opposition parties and interest groups. Elections are free and fair, with universal suffrage, and the transfer of power is peaceful and accepted. Corruption is low, the public administration is competent and the legal framework is stable and non-discriminatory. These factors all underpin an effective political system that is characterised by higher levels of public trust and political legitimacy than in most other countries. This transparent and trusted political framework has almost certainly contributed to Norway faring relatively well (in a regional and global context) in containing the coronavirus pandemic, in terms of health outcomes and the macroeconomic impact, as well as delivering one of the world's highest vaccination rates.
We expect Norway to retain its high score for government effectiveness, and the country's robust institutional structures will remain one of its main strengths. The consensus-driven nature of Norwegian politics can at times lead to sluggish progress in the passage of legislation and implementation of reforms relative to some peer countries, but it is a matter of opinion as to whether this is a positive or a negative feature.
As European integration has proceeded since 2007, the Storting has taken a more strident role in scrutinising European rules transposed into law as part of Norway's membership of the European Economic Area (EEA). In the context of the UK's exit from the EU, there is support in some sections of parliament for a more distant relationship with Europe, particularly within the FrP. However, we view a substantial revision of Norway's relationship with the EU, either for or against future integration, as unlikely.
There is a large amount of devolved power to regional authorities Policymaking is centred in the capital, Oslo, but implementation is largely left to regional authorities, which decentralises the government's functions. The system works well, with sub-national government comprised of municipalities and counties that have equal rights and responsibilities, regardless of their size. Functions are divided between these regional branches. Municipal government supervises junior education, health and social care, and town planning and infrastructure. County government oversees region-wide development and planning, including roads, public transport and adult education. The growing role of digital administration has contributed to a steady reduction in red tape across all aspects of government, and successive governments have attempted to make central and municipal administrations more efficient. However, disparities persist in digital capabilities among different local governments, with more populous regions, such as Oslo, providing more expansive services than rural regions.
A reform of local government was implemented in January 2020, reducing the number of municipalities from 428 to 356 and the number of counties from 19 to 11. The stated aims of the restructuring are to reduce costs, strengthen local democracy, and improve the quality of local services by giving municipalities more autonomy and greater scope to exploit economies of scale. The measure is similar to that implemented by Denmark in 2007, which was broadly effective in streamlining government administration, although the impact on services is more open to interpretation. The reforms destabilise some aspects of regional government and devolve new areas of responsibility, including road networks, broadband development and innovation, to the restructured municipalities. The reform has met with some strong public and political criticism, especially among more rural and isolated communities, amid fears over reduced local influence and a loss of financial autonomy compared with the previous framework. The populist-agrarian Centre Party, the junior partner in the current coalition, could push for revisions to the reform.
Political outlook: Election watch The last general election was held on September 13th 2021. The Storting (parliament) cannot be dissolved before completing a full four-year term, meaning that there is no risk of a snap election before the next poll in September 2025. The political scene is fairly fragmented, with the Labour Party securing the largest share of the vote (only 26.4%) in the last election, followed by the Conservatives (20.4%), the Centre Party (11.6%), the far-right Progress Party (FrP; 11.6%) and the SV (7.6%). Before the election, there had been significant focus on two smaller parties, the left-wing Red Party and the environmentalist Green Party; they polled only 4-5% each, but fared much better than in the 2017 election and collectively increased their parliamentary representation to 11 seats, from just two previously. This could amount to a significant pull towards more green initiatives.
Political outlook: International relations EU relations will remain a significant foreign-policy focus. As a member of the European Economic Area, Norway has access to the single market (in exchange for contributions to the EU budget), but must accept relevant EU regulations while having limited influence over them.
Russia's invasion of Ukraine on February 24th has led to most Western economies, including Norway, imposing strict sanctions on Russia on most non-energy commodities, while banning firms from engaging with Russian businesses, banks or key individuals. Norway is particularly critical to the EU's stated ambition to move away from Russian oil and gas imports. Russia has been periodically reducing its gas flows to Europe since the invasion, causing the EU to scramble to find alternative sources of gas. As the next-largest exporter of natural gas to the bloc, Norway has come under pressure to increase supply to make up for Russian gas exports to EU countries dependent on these imports. Equinor, the state-owned energy company, has said that it will work to increase production, although significant bottlenecks in the production process will limit the increase. The Baltic Pipe project, a gas pipeline from Norway to Poland and the Baltic states via Denmark, is expected to come online in October and will cover roughly 60% of Poland's imports from Russia. Norway is also generally a net electricity exporter (much of which is generated by hydropower) to its neighbours, including Denmark, Finland, Sweden and the UK. However, after a significant drought depleted its reservoirs, the government has proposed suspending electricity exports to its neighbours if water levels remain low, drawing criticism from the affected countries. A full cut-off remains a risk, although it will be dependent on rainfall in the coming months.
As a NATO member sharing a border with Russia, Norway's relations with Russia had deteriorated even before the invasion, with Norway accusing Russia of having orchestrated a cyber-attack on its parliament (particularly targeting the Labour Party). The government responded with a drive to upgrade defence infrastructure in the north of the country. We expect Norway to continue to bolster its defensive capabilities as the war continues.
Relations with the UK following its exit from the EU will also remain a focus of Norway's foreign policy. The UK's withdrawal from the common fisheries policy (which grants fishing fleets access to domestic waters) has been replaced with annual negotiations between the UK and Norwegian governments over fishing access. An agreement was struck in June 2021 and renewed in 2022, giving British farmers market access to Norway in exchange for UK concessions on fisheries.

Norway offers one of the world's most attractive businesses environments Norway's score in EIU's business environment model improves from 7.95 (out of 10) in the historical period (2017-21) to 8.13 in the forecast period (2022-26). The country rises by five places in the global ranking, to ninth, and four places at the regional level to be ranked as the fourth most attractive business location in western Europe. Norway scores reasonably highly in most business environment categories, and modest improvements are expected in financing, the tax regime, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. A slight fall in the score for the macroeconomic environment mainly reflects exogenous factors and is less severe than in most peer countries.
Norway's strengths are stable and transparent political and regulatory environments, resilient macroeconomic conditions, a low regulatory burden, openness to trade and foreign investment, a skilled labour force, good financing options, and high-quality transport and digital infrastructure. The macroeconomic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic was less disruptive than in many regional peers, and Norway's large oil and gas sector means that the country is relatively shielded from negative spillover effects from the Russia-Ukraine war. Policy towards foreign investment will remain fairly attractive, with oil and gas investments supported by soaring global demand. The lagged impact of earlier reforms is reflected in the improved score for taxes, amid a modest shift towards indirect taxation. The new left-leaning government aims to target social inequalities by raising taxes on wealth and energy, while easing the labour tax burden on lower-income earners. Given geopolitical developments, there will be limited progress in diversification of the mainland economy. Weaker areas of the business environment mostly relate to Norway's small market size, elevated living and labour costs, restricted access to some product and services markets, skills mismatches and capacity constraints due to labour shortages.

Business environment outlook: Norway's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2022-23: State involvement in the economy remains at a higher level than in pre-pandemic period. Some restricted market access amid relatively high level of state ownership. Low regulatory burden for most firms.
2024-26: No significant privatisation expected State intervention continues to push green and digital goals.
Policy towards foreign investment 2022-23: Generally positive stance towards foreign investment, but inflows constrained by tightened investment-screening regime and regional pushback against inflows from China.
2024-26: Gradual ongoing economic diversification efforts to attract investment across the non-oil mainland economy, such as in information and communication technology (ICT), business services, life sciences and marine sector.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2022-23: Expanded hydrocarbons exports to Europe in the aftermath of Russian invasion of Ukraine. Deteriorating EU-China trade relations likely to hinder (already sluggish) progress towards Norway-China free-trade agreement (FTA).
2024-26: Gradual progress on bilateral trade deals via European Free-Trade Association (EFTA). Changes to European Economic Area (EEA) membership unlikely. US-China trade tensions become entrenched.
Taxes 2022-23: Modest changes under left-leaning government aimed at shifting the tax burden more towards the wealthy and lowering labour tax burden. Major overhaul of petroleum tax regime from 2023. New withholding tax on interest and royalties.
2024-26: Gradual multi-year rise in carbon tax. Possible reforms to generous housing-tax incentives and structure of various wealth-related taxes. Moves to broaden the value-added tax (VAT) base and reduce complexities.
Financing 2022-23: Gradual tightening of financial conditions amid rising interest rates.
2024-26: Growing imbalances in real estate market amid strong house price inflation and structural constraints pose a modest risk to balance-sheet stability and could trigger new macroprudential measures. Further tightening of anti-money laundering rules.
The labour market 2022-23: Skills shortages increases the focus on targeted training and job-search support. Unemployment remains low.
2024-26: Ongoing skills mismatches and labour shortages likely to trigger reforms aimed at raising labour participation of older workers.
Infrastructure 2022-23: Ongoing improvements to strong transport and digital infrastructure. Mobile operators target nationwide fifth-generation (5G) coverage.
2024-26: Focus on rural broadband expansion to meet target of nationwide gigabit-capable fast broadband network by 2025.
Technological developments 2022-23: Focus on strengthening digital skills in labour force and business digitisation. High risk of state-sponsored cybercrime from Russia, China and others.
2024-26: The Open Artificial Intelligence (AI) lab grows in size and importance, underpinning AI preparedness.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The economy is relatively shielded from spillover effects of the war in Ukraine Norway has solid macroeconomic fundamentals that include robust public finances (backed by the Government Pension Fund Global-the vast sovereign wealth fund that invests profits from the dominant oil and gas sector), high average income levels, a large external surplus, substantial corporate and household savings, low unemployment, a resilient financial sector and strong institutional underpinnings. The modest fall in the category score in the forecast period primarily reflects greater exchange-rate volatility, given the weak and uncertain regional (and global) economic outlook amid the Russia-Ukraine war, elevated inflationary pressures and continued supply-side frictions. Despite this, Norway rises slightly in the rankings, mainly owing to the fact that, as the largest energy exporter in Europe, and against a backdrop of high commodity prices, the country is relatively shielded from negative economic spillover effects from the conflict. The government has pledged to increase hydrocarbons exports in an effort to mitigate a deepening energy supply crisis in Europe, but there is limited scope for bringing new capacity online. Norges Bank was the first developed-economy central bank to raise interest rates after the pandemic. Gradual tightening will continue into 2023 (when inflation is expected to begin to soften). Structurally weaker aspects of the macroeconomic environment include elevated private-sector indebtedness, a frothy housing market (with the pandemic accentuating imbalances in the real estate sector), ageing demographics, skilled labour shortages and a significant dependence on the oil and gas sector (with related exposure to fluctuations in world demand and the oil price). Against a global backdrop of rising protectionism, trade tensions, changing environmental perspectives and anticipated slower growth of the sovereign wealth fund, prospects for medium-term growth and strengthening productivity are likely to become more closely tied to economic diversification away from the hydrocarbons sector.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
8.3 8.3 12 12 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
State ownership of strategic assets is higher than in other countries Norway offers a fairly attractive environment for private enterprise, with a low burden of regulation, strong property rights protection, an effective legal system and support for entrepreneurship. However, overall market access is more limited than in most other regional economies, reflecting a comparatively high level of direct state ownership. In common with many peer countries, we do not expect a material improvement in 2022-26, with the category score and regional ranking unchanged. State involvement across the economy has increased (as in most European countries) in response to the pandemic and the Russia-Ukraine war and will remain at a higher level than in the pre-crisis period, reflecting also a moderate policy shift since late 2021 under the new left-leaning government. The Norwegian Competition Authority (NCA) has proved reasonably effective in its policing of cartels and abuse of market dominance, but its enforcement powers and competition legislation remain weaker than in some peer economies.

- Some 70 companies are directly state-owned, including the largest energy group, Equinor; the largest telecommunications provider, Telenor; the largest financial services institution, DNB; the postal service; and other major businesses in the transport, energy, chemicals, finance, forestry and communications sectors, among others. The eight-year term of the previous centre-right coalition saw limited divestments of state shareholdings, and we expect little privatisation activity under the Labour-led government.
- Owing in part to differing degrees of state ownership across the economy, levels of regulation in services vary considerably by sector. According to the OECD, Norway compares favourably in terms of legal, accounting and rail freight transport services, but has fairly high barriers to competition in insurance, air transport and banking. Although scope for private enterprise in a number of product and services markets is restricted, the bureaucratic burden for companies operating in Norway is generally modest. Administrative processes involved in establishing a new business, payment of taxes, cross-border trading and contract enforcement compare favourably with most peer economies, but there is room for improvement in access to utilities and credit (mostly among small and medium-sized enterprises), and strengthening the insolvency regime (minor business restructuring reforms were introduced during the pandemic).

State involvement has risen since 2020 and will remain a prominent feature
- Most state-backed pandemic-support measures-loan-guarantee and credit-insurance schemes for businesses, a wage-subsidy furlough scheme, tax deferrals and revised petroleum tax rules, and sector-specific direct grants for companies-have now expired, but indirect liquidity support will continue. The war in Ukraine and the related spike in energy costs have prompted new, targeted state-funded support for affected companies and subsidies for households. More broadly, ongoing targeted measures to address the imbalanced fallout from the pandemic and the war; recently tightened foreign investment screening rules; a global drift towards protectionism and "industrial sovereignty"; and the moderate leftward policy shift under the current government imply that state involvement will be a more prominent feature of the business environment than in the pre-pandemic period.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
8.7 8.7 10 5 8 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The category score is unchanged, but Norway sees a relative improvement in its global and regional rankings, mostly driven by recent more protectionist policy steps in some EU countries (and elsewhere) towards foreign takeovers and external investment in "strategic" sectors. Given its small economy, Norway has long adopted a broadly welcoming approach to inward investment, albeit with access to certain markets constrained by the relatively high level of state ownership. Mirroring global trends, political and public resistance to foreign influence is on the rise, but specific restrictions on foreign ownership are fairly limited, applying mainly to parts of strategic industries (such as fisheries, maritime and transport) and natural resources. The gradual long-term depletion of offshore hydrocarbon reserves and increasing public consciousness of climate change have given some impetus in recent years to efforts to attract non-oil foreign direct investment (FDI) as a means of diversifying the economy, although this will probably diminish temporarily given the current high-profile role of Norway's energy sector amid the fallout from the Russia-Ukraine war. Focus areas for Invest in Norway (the official investment promotion agency) include green energy, "cleantech" (such as battery production and data centres), marine industries, life sciences and a growing professional services sector, especially information and communication technology (ICT). There have been advances, but overall progress on diversification has been modest, with the hydrocarbon sector still among the most appealing to foreign investors. Selective start-up grants and research and development (R&D) support are available, with additional incentives for projects in less populated areas of the country.
National security plays a prominent role in foreign investment decisions
- Norway adopted a new investment screening regime in 2019, giving authorities greater powers to investigate and block foreign acquisitions (from EU and non-EU investors) on the grounds of national security, national financial stability and autonomy. This mainly reflects heightened regional concerns-amplified by the pandemic and the war in Ukraine-at the involvement of state-backed foreign actors in strategic industries and infrastructure assets, as well as the transfer of intellectual property, and is targeted primarily at restricting Russian-and Chinese-backed investments. This regional pushback has implications for Norway, which has long been seeking to finalise a free-trade agreement (FTA) with China, has seen increased involvement by Chinese firms in transport infrastructure projects and has placed greater emphasis on attracting FDI from a more diverse range of countries such as China, other parts of Asia and the US.
- In 2018 a British transport provider, Go-Ahead, won the first competitive tender for Norway's passenger rail operations, covering services in the south of the country for a ten-year period. In 2019 a Swedish operator, SJ, won the rights to an additional seven routes. The previous centre-right government had earmarked a gradual expansion of public-private collaboration in Norwegian infrastructure, including more areas of the rail network around Oslo, but this is now on hold under the new left-leaning coalition. Upon entering office the Labour-led minority government halted further competitive tendering of passenger rail services and track infrastructure operations.
- Foreign and domestic investors receive equal treatment in the awarding of new blocks for exploration and production of oil and gas, based on annual licensing rounds that cover more mature parts of the shelf (awards in predefined areas-APAs) and licensing rounds held every two years for more risky frontier areas. Prior to the Russia-Ukraine war, the growing focus on environmental issues among voters and calls from parts of the Labour Party to reduce tax-related incentives for offshore oil exploration had raised the prospect of a less supportive policy stance for the oil and gas sector. However, the fallout from the conflict will tip the balance towards supporting greater offshore investment over the coming years. On a longer-term basis, however, environment-related pressures and the gradual transition of the Norwegian economy away from oil imply a tightening of rules on exploration and reduced support for foreign investment on the Norwegian continental shelf.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
9.1 9.1 16 18 9 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
As Norway is a net energy exporter with a small domestic market and limited manufacturing capacity, successive governments have adopted broadly pro-free-trade policies, despite a longstanding reluctance to join the EU and the protectionism afforded to home-produced agriculture. The category score is unchanged in the forecast period, with limited progress expected in diversifying Norway's export base. Global trading conditions will be challenging, amid increasing regionalism, ongoing supply-chain disruption (from the pandemic and war in Ukraine) and worsening trade tensions between the world's major economies (particularly US and EU relations with China). Norway's institutions are largely welcoming to foreign trade. Profits and dividends earned in all sectors may be repatriated, with no restrictions on capital flows. Through the country's membership of the European Economic Area (EEA), domestic and foreign-owned companies in Norway have full access to the single market, which accounts for about 60% of Norwegian exports. EU access provides for free movement of persons, goods, services and capital between Norway and member states. Norway has adopted about three-quarters of single-market legislation, with notable exceptions around fisheries and agriculture (the fisheries industry is among the largest in Europe). Trading outside the EU is promoted mainly through FTAs concluded by the European Free-Trade Association (EFTA), which comprises Switzerland, Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein. As at August 2022 there were 29 FTAs covering 41 countries, with talks ongoing over future deals with India, Malaysia, Thailand and Mercosur (the South American trading bloc), among others. A Norway-UK FTA took effect from December 2021 with little material change from the EU-based arrangement, introducing duty-free status for some important Norwegian exports but also more red tape in some areas. Annual negotiations between the two governments now dictate the terms of fishing access in domestic waters. Following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Norway joined most Western countries in imposing sanctions on Russia and banning firms from engaging with Russian businesses, banks or key individuals.
Norway is unlikely to renegotiate the terms of its EEA membership
- Norway's position on the fringe of European institutions is unlikely to change. It is not a member of the EU and will not consider joining in the forecast period, amid strong opposition from a number of political parties and mixed support from voters. There have been calls in recent years by the Centre Party and the far-right Progress Party to renegotiate the terms of Norway's EEA membership, but this remains unlikely, with a majority in parliament supportive of the existing arrangement and in view of the UK's tortuous Brexit process.
- The substantial boost to hydrocarbons export revenue since the Russia-Ukraine war will bolster near-term investment in the oil and gas sector. Direct exposure of the economy to trade with Russia is low, but export-focused businesses will be affected indirectly through increased logistical upheaval and transport costs, elevated energy and raw materials prices, and scarcity of some inputs. These factors will hinder Norway's efforts to strengthen the mainland economy. The war, along with the pandemic, will exacerbate existing geopolitical trends such as rising protectionism and may spur more regionalised nearshoring of supply chains, although Asia (primarily China) will remain a key source of many import components.
- Negotiations on a bilateral Norway-China FTA have been ongoing since 2008. Both countries will continue to adopt a pragmatic view with regard to strengthening trade ties, but against the backdrop of heightened EU-China tensions-fuelled by disputes over competition, strategic sectors, human rights issues and China's stance on the Russia-Ukraine war-it is highly unlikely that a Norway-China FTA will be concluded in the forecast period. We expect a deterioration in EU-China diplomatic ties in 2022-26. Trade will continue, but the operating environment for Western firms dealing with China will worsen, amid an increasing compliance burden of disruptive regulations.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
6.0 6.8 46 36 12 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Recent reforms have involved a shift from direct to indirect taxation The tax regime is one of the weaker aspects of the business environment, notwithstanding reforms in recent years that have improved Norway's global and regional standing. Reforms have aimed at encouraging labour participation and private investment via shifting some of the overall tax burden from direct to indirect taxation. This has included cuts to personal and corporate income tax rates, levies on some financial activities and high-sugar products, changes in excise duties, and a rise in the carbon tax. Norway's tax/GDP ratio has been fairly stable over recent years at about 40%-slightly below the EU average and its Nordic peers. The shares of total tax receipts from personal and corporate income taxes, and value-added tax (VAT), are all above the EU average, whereas social security contributions and revenue from taxes on property, energy and non-VAT indirect taxes each account for a below-average share.

- Since 2019 the headline corporation tax rate has been 22%, close to effective tax rates among regional peers and the OECD average. Additional corporate income tax rates (from 2022) are levied on offshore petroleum firms (56%) and hydropower production (37%). These have trended moderately higher, but effective tax rates have been largely stable, as the tax rate of investment-based depreciation-the "rate of uplift"- has been gradually lowered. Temporary changes to elements of the petroleum tax system (covering depreciation, uplift and treatment of tax losses) were applied in 2020-21 amid the pandemic disruption to encourage new investments. An overhaul of the petroleum tax regime will take effect from 2023, with a shift to a more cashflow-oriented system. This will also reduce the tax allowance for investments and phase out uplifts, but expand deductions and refunds, aiming to improve the "neutrality" of the overall regime and liquidity conditions for oil-sector companies.
- Since 2016 the income tax system for individuals has comprised a progressive four-tier framework. Recent reforms have included a reduction in the flat tax rate on net income, from 27% to the current 22%, increases in the personal allowance, some reductions in wealth-related taxes and a tightening of various exemptions. As at 2022 additional income tax rates ranged from 1.7% to 16.4%. VAT is levied at a standard rate of 25%, although reduced rates of 15%, 12% and 0% apply to a wide range of goods and services.
- Norway compares well in global terms on most measures of income and wealth equality, but imbalances have steadily widened, with rising inequality a prominent issue in the 2021 election. A new withholding tax of 15% on interest and royalty payments was introduced in mid-2021. More recent changes have mostly comprised temporary measures to ease the energy-price shock. The new government will prioritise increased progressivity, via (moderate) tax cuts for low- and middle-income earners and higher taxes levied on the wealthy and some businesses. Phased increases in the already relatively high and broad-based carbon tax are also expected, as is further implementation of corporate tax avoidance provisions under the OECD's Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) initiative. Broadening the VAT base and limiting the extremely generous housing-related tax incentives are also possible.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
8.5 8.9 3 4 1 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The financing environment is sound, but some risks to stability will pesist Financing conditions for business will remain favourable, with Norway retaining elevated global and regional rankings. This reflects the underlying resilience of the banking sector, comparatively modest risk exposure, and the impact of earlier improvements to the regulatory framework. Annual stress tests prior to the pandemic and since show that the banking sector is more profitable than most regional peers, with strong capital and liquidity buffers, comparatively modest costs, and low levels of credit losses and non-performing loans. Banks remain more reliant on wholesale funding than in many peer economies, reflecting the limited scope to expand the deposit base. This implies liquidity risk via exposure to global market trends, although the maturity of this funding has lengthened in recent years. Since 2018 revelations of several major money-laundering scandals involving major Nordic-Baltic banking groups have prompted a significant tightening of previously lax anti-money laundering and terrorism financing legislation across the region, and further measures are likely.

- Risks to financial instability remain fairly low, but a backdrop of steadily tightening financial conditions, elevated inflation, the winding down of liquidity-support measures from the pandemic, volatile international capital markets, an overvalued real-estate sector, and spillover risk from war-related disruption to business and a recession across the EU economy could expose vulnerabilities in the tightly integrated Nordic-Baltic banking system.
- Prior to the pandemic, new macroprudential measures were introduced to strengthen bank capital buffers and tighten rules on consumer credit and higher-risk mortgage lending. These dampened growth in real estate prices and mortgage lending temporarily, but house price inflation accelerated strongly during the pandemic (as in many countries), amid rising household savings and expansionary monetary policy. Structural factors such as generous mortgage-interest deductibility tax rules and limited new housing supply (given tight planning regulations) also underpin house price growth. Rising policy interest rates and gradual normalisation of other policy tools will dampen housing market activity, but new macroprudential measures could be needed.
- Foreign companies have access to the same capital sources as domestic firms, but often work through foreign banks, which tend to have offices in Oslo and in cities where the oil industry is based, especially Bergen and Stavanger. Demand for (and supply of) venture capital and private equity has strengthened over recent years, and we expect a further expansion.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
6.9 7.0 19 20 9 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
A tight labour market and the risk of skills mismatches will persist Norway's score for the labour market over the forecast period remains around the regional average. The labour force is productive and highly educated, with a strong level of technical and language skills. An employment rate of about 75% is above the EU and OECD averages, but trails regional peers. This implies some scope for raising participation, growth of which is partly constrained by the effects of a generous sick leave system and above-average early retirement take-up amid a gradually ageing population. There is a high level of unionisation and a highly centralised system of collective bargaining between government, the Confederation of Norwegian Enterprise and the Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions. This involves a high degree of co-ordination, with manufacturing wages providing a benchmark for sector-specific and company-level bargaining. Median wage levels are elevated and earnings inequality fairly low, but regional and sectoral variations have been intensified by the pandemic. The cost of living is among the highest in the world. Industrial actions have been part of the wage-bargaining process in recent years, particularly in the large public sector and offshore petroleum industry. However, the government reserves the right to enforce arbitration in disputes that are likely to have a major impact on the economy or be detrimental to public health.

- A temporary state-backed wage-subsidy scheme limited job losses during the pandemic. Headline indicators have since recovered strongly, with unemployment in mid-2022 at a 14-year low and a growing number of skilled labour market shortages and skills mismatches, (although these trends were on the rise even before the pandemic). This is exacerbated in part by reduced inflows of foreign labour, which remain below 2019 levels. An influx of refugees from the conflict in Ukraine (Norway has signalled that it will take about 45,000) will provide only a partial boost to the labour supply. A stated aim of the new government is to strengthen workers' rights (by advocating full-time jobs and permanent employment contracts over temporary forms of work) and incentivise job creation for young and migrant workers. Given Norway's labour-supply issues and demographic trends, measures are likely to focus on bolstering labour participation among older workers.
- A relative lack of labour mobility will continue to restrict opportunities for development in remote regions, and a mismatch of education and skills among immigrants and asylum-seekers settling in Norway will hamper integration into the workforce. Political pressure to restrict immigration will remain high.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
8.3 8.5 11 11 8 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Infrastructure planning is set out on a decade-long time horizon Norway has well-developed transport networks and high-quality digital infrastructure, with few of the problems, such as traffic congestion, that affect countries with higher population densities. Gradual improvements to road and rail networks are scheduled over the forecast period, based on an updated ten-year national transport plan published in early 2022. The new government will roll back elements of the previous government's plans for stronger public-private co-operation on infrastructure projects. Road tolls are an important source (about 10%) of infrastructure funding, although they are politically unpopular. Norway is a global leader in electric vehicle (EV) adoption, with an extensive charging network. Good ferry and internal air transport services, including oil-rig helicopter links, mitigate the logistical challenges posed by the country's diverse topography and weather-related vulnerabilities. Digital infrastructure is among the most advanced in the world, with Norway ranking among the leading countries in the European Commission's Digital Economy and Society Index (DESI). Provision and uptake of high-speed broadband services, online business use and level of e-government services compare favourably with regional peers.

- Infrastructure policy is guided by a 12-year national transport plan (updated every four years), which focuses on maintenance and upgrading of transport infrastructure, pollution reduction, rolling out intelligent transport systems and ongoing digitisation. The baseline scenario of the updated plan for 2022-33 allocates 47% of an overall financial framework of Nkr1.2bn (US$116m) for road improvements; 33% for railways (which includes new double-track lines for intercity routes, Oslo-Skien and Halden-Lillehammer, and a second light-rail line in Bergen); 7% for other green urban transport measures; and 3% to coastal infrastructure schemes to benefit the fishing and shipping industries. The government has set a target for all new passenger cars and light vans to be zero-emission from 2025 and for transport sector emissions to be cut by 50% by 2030 compared with 2005 levels.
- A relatively early schedule of auctions for 5G-compatible spectrum provided momentum for Norway's fifth-generation (5G) network rollout, although deployment remains largely limited to major cities. Telenor launched Norway's first commercial 5G mobile services in March 2020, with its main competitor, Telia, debuting its 5G network soon after. The operators are targeting nationwide coverage from 2023. A Broadband Development Act, adopted in 2020, aims to facilitate the development of ultrafast broadband networks and 5G by encouraging co-operation in infrastructure construction and promoting joint utilisation of existing networks. In March 2022 the government distributed Nkr304m (US$29m) to local governments to develop regional broadband networks, aiming for a nationwide gigabit-capable fast-broadband network by 2025.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
8.0 8.3 22 22 11 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
We expect gradual improvements in technological readiness over 2022-26, but little change to Norway's rankings. Stronger aspects are the quality of digital infrastructure, high rates of e-commerce and e-business technology, good penetration of e-government services, widespread internet usage, above-average digital skills levels, and good cyber-security preparedness (which has recently been bolstered). Total investment in R&D corresponds to just over 2% of GDP-slightly below an OECD average of 2.4% and well below levels of more than 3% in Denmark and Sweden. Norway ranks in the second-highest group in the European Innovation Scoreboard, scoring well for its innovation-friendly environment, strong public-private linkages and lifelong learning. Weaker aspects include impact from sales and exports of knowledge-intensive products, implying scope for improvement in translating the country's innovative capacity into entrepreneurial activity.

- As one of the world's most digitised economies, with tense relations (and a direct border) with Russia, state-sponsored cybercrime and cyber-espionage pose a clear threat to Norwegian companies and public authorities, particularly in light of Russia's actions in Ukraine. Norway adopted a revised national cyber-security strategy in 2019, but this failed to prevent several major cyber-attacks (widely believed to be by Russian and Chinese state-sponsored actors) in 2021, since when Norway has taken steps to bolster its cyber-resilience and strengthen regional security co-operation. According to the Global Cyber-security Index 2020, published by the International Telecommunication Union, Norway ranked 17th globally for its commitment and capacity to deal with cyber-related attacks.

There will be a focus on strengthening digital skills and e-government
- Recent budgets have earmarked new funding for the Norwegian Digitalisation Agency to strengthen various digital platforms used by the public. Norway ranks highly for use and integration of digital technology by government and businesses, but the accelerated paradigm shift towards digitisation amid the pandemic implies ongoing pressures to meet rising demand. A focus of the new government's digital strategy is to bolster digital skills levels and expand the available stock of higher-skilled ICT workers.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The coalition's long-term policy priorities include long-running efforts to diversify the economy away from hydrocarbons, particularly towards fishing, professional services and light manufacturing. The government is also likely to pursue efforts to increase spending on healthcare and education, accelerate progress on green initiatives, and incentivise job creation (particularly in industries affected by skills shortages). However, in the short term the hydrocarbons sector will increase in importance: with the withdrawal of Russian gas, Norway now provides more than 25% of Europe's gas supply. As a result, the government is likely to focus on reliability of supply in the short term. In the longer term the move towards decarbonisation is likely to exacerbate divisions within the Labour Party between its youth and trade union wings over oil reimbursement allowances (which allow 70% of oil exploration costs to be reimbursed if there is no discovery), which threaten to remove the tax incentives for investment in offshore oil. However, given the imperative of providing for European energy security, any change is unlikely during this parliamentary term.
Although inflation is far lower in Norway than in other European countries owing to its status as an energy producer and net exporter, the government is likely to provide additional support for households struggling with higher prices. High profits in the energy sector, along with tight labour markets and increasing cost-of-living concerns, have led to labour unrest, with Lederne, the trade union for the crude oil industry in Norway, staging a series of work stoppages between July 6th and 9th. The government implemented a compulsory arbitration proceeding, effectively ending the strike. However, high energy sector profits, tight labour markets and escalating inflation make labour unrest an ongoing risk.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators

General government debt 43.2 35.8 31.3 28.6 26.1 25.3
Fiscal conditions are supported by the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG), the country's US$1trn sovereign wealth fund, which has insulated the public finances from cyclical fluctuations. Owing to its long history of fiscal probity, Norway has a greater level of fiscal space than most, meaning that it remains in a strong position to increase stimulus again in 2022 if high inflation requires increased support to households, without placing any pressure on public debt, which remains low.
After a deficit of 2.6% of GDP in 2020, the first since 1993, strong revenue growth, particularly in the oil and gas sector, returned the budget to a surplus of 9.9% of GDP in 2021. EIU expects the surplus to remain elevated in 2022, at 11.3%, with higher energy prices more than offsetting increased social support amid accelerating inflation and higher social spending under the new government. Norway typically runs a significant fiscal surplus, near 10% of GDP, in periods of high oil prices, and we expect this to resume in 2023-24. A combination of falling hydrocarbons prices as new global supply comes online and reasonably firm expenditure growth in the second half of the forecast period is likely to erode the surplus slightly, to 8.7% by the end of the forecast period.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2021 2022 2023 2024 2025 2026
3-month Nibor rate (av) 0.5 1.7 2.9 3.3 3.5 3.7
10-year government bond yield (av) 1.3 2.0 3.4 4.3 4.8 5.0
Norges Bank (the central bank) began tightening monetary policy in September 2021, lifting the policy rate (which had been at a record low of 0% since May 2020) by 25 basis points. It raised the policy rate by 25 basis points again in both December 2021 and March 2022, followed by 50-basis-point increases in June and August, bringing the rate to 1.75%, as inflation continued to accelerate owing to higher import costs. Further gradual tightening is likely in the remainder of 2022. However, the trajectory of future rate rises is likely to moderate in 2023 in order to avoid choking off economic growth altogether. Norges Bank's inflation target of close to 2% over time means that there is some latitude for the central bank to raise rates fairly gradually, even as inflation remains elevated. Moreover, much of the acceleration in inflation stems from higher energy prices and supply-chain disruption for manufactured goods, which will be unaffected by central bank tightening. As a result, we expect the policy rate to stabilise at about 3.5% by the end of 2023.

Full-year real GDP growth was strong in 2021, at 4%. An increase in new covid-19 cases in December 2021 and the implementation of new restrictions in January, along with the corresponding weakening of consumer confidence, led to a quarterly contraction of 0.9% in the first quarter of 2022. Growth returned in the second quarter, at 0.7%, with private consumption fully rebounding, but weak investment holding back overall GDP growth. We expect that over the full year real GDP growth will slow somewhat to 2.3%, with the quarterly pattern of activity of individual GDP components likely to be volatile, reflecting instability in global markets following the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Private consumption will rebound strongly, although much of this is due to base effects from the lockdown-depressed 2021 base year, whereas the government's withdrawal of coronavirus-related stimulus will prompt much slower public consumption growth. Fixed investment will remain volatile, as increased investment in the offshore (oil and gas) economy will be partly offset by the ongoing weak performance of the non-energy sector amid higher interest rates and crowding out by offshore investment. Increasing oil and gas export volumes will support growth. However, a rebound in imports following the lifting of covid-related travel restrictions in the tourism sector will limit the contribution of the external sector to overall growth.
In contrast to most of Europe, where growth is expected to slow, Norwegian growth will remain slightly above trend in 2023, at 2.8%, reflecting increased export values from the hydrocarbons sector and a modest increase in hydrocarbons production, as well as base effects from the covid restrictions in the first quarter of 2022. These will offset weak private consumption growth, which will be hampered by high inflation (which will erode real incomes). From 2024-26 the economy is still forecast to grow relatively firmly-at an annual average of 2.4%, roughly in line with the pre-pandemic trend-assuming growth in both the energy and non-oil sectors (with the former slowing towards the end of the forecast period as energy prices decline gradually and Europe's energy transition gathers pace). Exports will remain firm, which will help to support a fairly strong pace of overall growth in the medium term. In the hydrocarbons sector, a temporary tax break in 2020, resilient sectoral investment and exploration activity during the pandemic indicate that new capacity will come on-stream over the forecast period, offsetting reduced output from ageing fields. This revival in offshore activity is likely to raise production to a 15-year high by 2024-26, although it will remain below the peak reached in the early 2000s.
In the context of growing concerns about the reliability of Russian gas supplies to Europe, Norway's gas exports are expected to rise over the forecast period, as they represent a secure and stable source of supply for European gas-importing economies. However, capacity issues will limit the pace of gas export growth. In the longer term the broader role of the oil and gas sector in the Norwegian economy faces growing scrutiny amid climate change, societal shifts, "net zero" emissions targets and the gradual diversification of global energy demand away from oil and gas. Towards the end of the forecast period, this could hamper investment growth and (beyond the forecast period) affect exports more significantly.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends In common with most advanced economies, the majority of the Norwegian economy is derived from services, at 64% in 2021. However, this figure is lower than Norway's neighbours (with Denmark at 76% and Sweden at 66%), highlighting the importance of natural resource extraction, particularly in the hydrocarbons sector, to the Norwegian economy. Industry accounts for 34% of the economy, with agriculture making up the remaining 2%. Services have generally risen as a share of GDP over recent decades, although they remain below their all-time high of 65% in 2019 owing to the pandemic. Within the industrial sector, the manufacturing industry comprises a fairly modest 7% share of GDP, similar in scale to the construction sector, although the latter is on a gradually rising trend.
The oil and gas sector has been the primary driver of economic development since Norwegian oil was first exploited in the 1970s. The influence of the oil and gas sector (as a share of GDP) has declined steadily in recent decades, from about 30% in the early 2000s, amid growth of the services sector, volatile oil prices, disrupted production on major (and in some cases ageing) oil platforms and shifting environmental pressures.
A 2020 tax credit and surging demand will boost oil production in 2022-26 After falls in output in 2018-19, oil and gas production rose in 2020 despite the pandemic, supported by a temporary tax break in mid-2020 that encouraged new exploration, and increased further in 2021 and 2022 following rising hydrocarbons prices and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. As at end-2021 a total of 94 fields were producing, up from 83 in 2018, with four new fields beginning production in 2021 alone. Early phases of exploration took place in the North Sea (on the country's south-west coast, with 71 platforms currently operating), but later efforts have also concentrated on the Norwegian Sea (on the north-west coast, with 21 platforms) and the Barents Sea (further north, two platforms).
The exploration of new fields is likely to offset declining production in ageing fields, which will raise production to a decade-high level by 2024-25 (although this will remain below the peak in the early 2000s). Official forecasts from the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate (NPD), a government agency, point to continued growth in output to 2024-25, before tapering off thereafter, with gas continuing to grow through 2026. This is partly attributable to the reactivation of several oil platforms after maintenance operations, but the main factor behind the jump in production is the giant Johan Sverdrup field, which came on stream in late 2019. It is the fifth-largest oil discovery ever made in Norwegian waters and will account for 30% of all Norwegian oil production by the mid-2020s, according to the NPD.
In the short-term Norway will be under pressure to increase production further given sanctions on Russia and the corresponding energy crisis in Europe. In the longer term, however, the broader role of the oil and gas sector in the Norwegian economy faces growing scrutiny amid greater public and societal commitment to moving towards "net zero" emissions targets and diversifying the economy. Climate and environmental issues dominated Norway's 2021 election campaign, with a majority left-leaning coalition coming to power on a platform of more aggressive emisisons reduction. Most political parties and the public remain broadly aligned in the view that the focus should be to "develop rather than discontinue" the industry, given the economy's still high dependence on petroleum sector revenue, which has only been reinforced by the energy crisis. The longer-term direction of travel is clear, however, with the influence of the sector on the Norwegian economy set to decline gradually from the mid-2020s as the energy transition continues.
Non-oil manufacturing has declined over the past decade Since the exploitation of oil, Norway's manufacturing sector has diminished in economic importance, from an 18% share of GDP in 1970 to about 7% in 2021. The trend over the past decade has been one of gradual decline, from just below 8% in the late 2000s. Manufacturing is split between an oil-oriented component dominated by machinery, chemicals and ship-building, and a consumer-oriented component, of which the largest is production of food and beverages. The sector is highly capital intensive, with activity having rebounded since mid-2020 more quickly than most services sectors, amid a recovery in global trade and being less exposed to pandemic-related restrictions. Momentum slowed over the first half of 2021, hampered in part by supply-chain disruptions such as the global semiconductor chip shortage and rising freight costs, which have led to soaring producer price inflation that will persist into 2023. Non-oil manufacturing may receive targeted support in the coming years as part of a broader economic diversification strategy. The link between the krone and global oil prices will, however, continue to pose a challenge to efforts to boost the global share of manufacturing exports.
In the services sector, government and public administration account for the largest share of activity and employment, reflecting in part high-quality and extensive healthcare, education and social welfare structures. Wholesale and retail trade, business services, financial services, real estate, and information and communications technology (ICT) all make a sizeable contribution to services value added. Much of the sector services the internal market, but there are many service industries that have developed a significant advantage compared with their European and global competitors. Given Norway's geographical location and the influence of the oil and gas industry, these tend to be firms specialising in logistics or research and development.
Partnership with the oil sector has enabled transport and maritime services, alongside other professional or technical services (such as engineering, chemicals and research), to develop outside the oil sector. Business services, ICT, and wholesale and retail trade have been among the main growth drivers in recent years, and have remained fairly resilient throughout the pandemic. In contrast, activity in contact-intensive services such as hospitality, tourism, entertainment and arts was severely curtailed in 2020 and early 2021. However, the relative importance of these sectors to the Norwegian economy is smaller than in many peer countries, limiting the overall fallout.

Headline inflation has surged since its nadir of 0.7% in November 2020, to 6.8% in July 2022. The increase was initially driven by the higher cost of imported goods, particularly food and energy. Inflation as measured by Norges Bank's preferred measure, excluding energy prices and taxation, has remained lower, but, at 4.8%, has risen well above the central bank's 2% target rate, suggesting that inflation expectations have moved beyond those sectors and are starting to affect prices more widely. We expect inflation to accelerate from an average of 3.5% in 2021 to 6.2% in 2022 and remain elevated at 5.9% in 2023. Norway is less exposed to global price fluctuations in energy markets, as a major exporter, and the appreciation of the krone in the wake of the invasion of Ukraine will also have a deflationary impact, meaning that inflation is likely to remain below the levels seen elsewhere in Europe. We expect a gradual decline in energy prices and global monetary tightening to cause inflation to slow to 2.1% in 2024, stabilising at 1.8% thereafter.
In contrast to consumer price inflation, Norway's producer price inflation is much higher than in the EU, reflecting both high energy costs, and significant supply bottlenecks in the oil and gas sector as it expands to meet European demand. Producer price inflation averaged 37.9% in 2021, and we forecast that it will to accelerate to 56.5% in 2022 after quarterly growth of 11% and 13% in the first two quarters respectively. Given the ongoing bottlenecks in the energy sector, we expect producer price inflation to remain elevated in 2023, at 18%, before moderating from 2024.

The krone has largely followed the changes in global energy markets since January 2020, experiencing a substantial devaluation throughout 2020 before strengthening in 2021 and early 2022 as oil prices have risen and economic conditions have improved. This was particularly exacerbated by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, but has reversed as the initial shock to oil prices has subsided. We forecast that the krone will remain steady for the remainder of 2022 and 2023 against the euro, supported by still-high energy prices, forecast interest-rate increases and a large current-account surplus. It will slip slightly against the US dollar in the same period following a flight to safety among investors in the aftermath of the Ukraine war, and in response to the rapid tightening cycle by the US Federal Reserve (the central bank). From 2024 we expect the krone to weaken as global oil prices moderate. Further downward shifts in oil prices, chiefly from continued shocks to global demand, as well as geopolitical shocks due to Russian actions in the war in Ukraine and the corresponding sanctions, remain a risk to our exchange-rate forecasts.

Norway's current-account surpluses have historically been supported by large inflows on the trade and primary income accounts, reflecting the economy's position as a major oil exporter and the size of the GPFG respectively, with the size of the surplus strongly correlated to the oil price. All components of the current account improved sharply in 2021, with the third-quarter current-account surplus the largest on record, which contributed to a huge full-year surplus, at 14.9% of GDP. The surplus will expand further in 2022, reaching 17.4% of GDP, as export earnings continue to rise, and remain elevated in 2023 at 16.8% of GDP. Gradually decreasing commodity prices in the remainder of the forecast period, combined with steady growth in imports, will contribute to a moderation in the size of the current-account surplus, to a still-large 9.1% of GDP in 2026.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Norway Stocks and flows Developments in Norway's large oil and gas sector and in global energy prices are major determinants of annual inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI), which tend to be more volatile than in many peer economies. According to data from the IMF, the stock of inward FDI totalled US$257bn at the end of 2020, equivalent to 71% of GDP. Per head, the FDI stock was US$47,711, comparatively high on a regional basis and a similar level to Sweden. The strongest period of FDI inflows occurred in 2005-12, averaging US$17bn per year. Since then, inward FDI has fluctuated between positive and negative annual flows. These have generally been modest in scale, although there was a substantial disinvestment of US$19bn in 2016 and a stronger inflow of US$17bn in 2019. On average over the 2013-19 period FDI inflows amounted to a subdued US$1.1bn per year. There was disinvestment of US$6.7bn in 2020, mirroring a global cooling of FDI activity given the elevated uncertainty and restricted mobility posed by the coronavirus pandemic.
Origin and distribution Norway's oil-intensive economy means that FDI is largely focused on the oil and gas sector, in addition to ancillary services such as transport, infrastructure and finance. Most of the world's major oil and gas companies are involved in Norwegian oil production, including Chevron, ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil, Marathon (all US-based), BP (UK), RWE (Germany), Engie (France), Eni (Italy) and RoyalDutchShell (UK/Netherlands). According to Statistics Norway, in 2020 the mining and quarrying sector (including oil and gas) accounted for the single largest share (18%) of the FDI stock, followed by financial services (18%), manufacturing (12%), wholesale and retail trade (9%), and real estate (8%). Both manufacturing and financial services have considerable overlap with the oil and gas industry. Real estate and manufacturing accounted for the largest shares of FDI inflows in 2019. Based on unadjusted FDI data, Sweden is by some distance the single largest investor in Norway, accounting for 20% of the FDI stock in 2020, ahead of the US (10%), the Netherlands (9%), Luxembourg (9%), Denmark (7%) and the UK (7%). However, Norway is not always the final destination of this inward investment, serving also as a pan-regional distribution hub for third-country investment. As in many countries with established financial services sectors, Norway's FDI data are also partly skewed by inflows associated with "corporate reconfigurations"-changes in complex ownership structures of multinationals-rather than greenfield investment. Based on adjusted data whereby Norway is the "ultimate destination" of FDI, the single largest investor is the US (19% of the FDI stock), followed by Sweden (12%), Germany (7%), the UK (7%), Denmark (6%) and Finland (6%).
Determinants Aside from the potential large returns on offer to investors in the oil and gas sector, Norway offers a comparatively stable political and macroeconomic environment, a strong institutional framework, a generally low regulatory burden for firms, high-quality public services and infrastructure, a highly skilled workforce, openness to foreign investment and foreign trade, and established high value-added industry sectors. The constraint posed by Norway's small market size is partly mitigated by membership of the European Economic Area (EEA), which gives Norwegian firms access to the wider European market. However, its geographical location does imply comparatively high transport and logistics costs, while limiting the country's attractiveness as an outsourcing or re-exporting base. High labour costs (in terms of wages, payroll taxes and fairly restrictive labour regulations) will tend to deter most labour-intensive industries, and scope for private enterprise is still constrained in some product and services markets, reflecting Norway's fairly high level of direct state ownership.
Impact FDI has encouraged the transfer of foreign knowledge to Norway and accelerated the development of the oil and gas sector over recent decades. The oil sector has, in turn, encouraged wider growth in the mainland economy through higher wages, consumer spending, and investment in infrastructure and public services, as well as via ancillary services such as transport and finance. Several of these ancillary services, notably supply and maintenance services, have become internationally competitive, despite the historically strong krone. Moreover, high taxation on developed oil wells has led to a resilient fiscal balance and a vast sovereign wealth fund, the Government Pension Fund Global. Employment in the oil and gas sector has trended lower since a 2014 peak, but various estimates suggest that it still accounts (directly or indirectly) for about 150,000-200 000 people, equivalent to approximately 6% of the labour force. It can be argued that a longstanding focus on the oil and gas sector has held back investment in other industries, leaving the Norwegian economy less diversified than some of its peers and playing catch up in key sectors. A majority of non-oil inward FDI has tended to involve the acquisition by overseas interests of existing Norwegian-based companies, rather than establishing new companies or facilities. As in many countries, increased foreign investor interest over recent decades has contributed to augmented imbalances in the real estate market.
Potential Gradual diversification efforts over the forecast period are likely to provide more opportunities for FDI in Norway's growing professional services industry (finance, information and communication technology, and legal) and in areas such as fintech, "cleantech" and biotechnology. Policymakers have made the development of the "High North" (the areas adjacent to the Arctic) a wider policy priority, offering various incentives and grants, including a reduction in the scale of employer contributions, with a focus on encouraging stronger growth in the maritime, healthcare and IT sectors there. Nevertheless, the bulk of opportunities for foreign investment will remain in the energy sector, encompassing oil, gas and green energy (such as wind power). Amid an increasing global focus on climate change and the environment, public sentiment towards new exploration and investment in the petroleum sector is gradually shifting. This is unlikely to trigger any dramatic near-term change in official policy towards fossil-fuel production in Norway, given its revenue-raising importance for the wider economy, but could lead to a gradual tightening of tax-relief measures and other incentives in the sector, reducing its overall attractiveness for new investment. Norway's robust political, macroeconomic, financial and institutional structures will remain appealing features for potential investors, as will the quality of the labour force and infrastructure. Set against this are the country's high labour costs, small market size and a comparatively high level of direct state ownership, which is likely to persist in 2022-26.

Population growth has slowed recently, but will remain positive in 2022-26 The population of Norway totalled 5.4m at end-2021, up from 4.9m in 2010 and 4.5m in 2000. Population growth averaged 1.2% per year in 2011-15, but has since moderated, averaging 0.6% per year in 2017-21. This slowdown has mainly been in response to reduced net immigration, alongside a gradual fall in the "natural increase" (annual births minus deaths). EIU expects a mild acceleration in population growth over the forecast period (2022-26) as global economic conditions improve and as international travel normalises. A gradual ageing of the population will continue, amid a slowly declining fertility rate and increasing life expectancy.
Annual net immigration was fairly stable throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, averaging about 12,000 per year. Net inflows increased sharply from 2005 to a peak of 47,000 per year in 2011-12. Since then, net immigration has fallen steadily in response to domestic economic conditions, shifting regional migration trends, hardening public sentiment that has driven a tightening of immigration rules in Norway for those outside the European Economic Area (EEA), and most recently the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Net immigration reached 19,650 in 2021, a rebound from 11,331 in 2020 (the lowest level since 2003), but still well below its pre-pandemic level of 25,327. We expect net migration to rise in 2022, supported by the normalisation of travel following the pandemic disruption, as well as an influx of refugees from Ukraine, before continuing its downward trend thereafter.
There were just over 819,000 foreign citizens in Norway as at January 2022, equivalent to 15% of the total population. Polish migrants accounted for the largest share, with a population of 105,000, followed by Lithuanians (42,000), Swedes (36,000) and Syrians (34,000).
The fertility rate in Norway edged higher during the 2000s, but has fallen steadily over the past decade from a peak of 1.98 in 2009. The fertility rate reached 1.55 in 2021, its highest level since 2018 and up from a low of 1.48, the lowest level ever registered by Statistics Norway. However, this probably represents distortion driven by pandemic-related uncertainty delaying births in 2020, rather than a break in the trend. The overall downward trend reflects in part a sharp decline in births by women in the 20-30 age group. With life expectancy increasing, the overall population will continue to age gradually over the forecast period. The share of the population aged 67 or over is projected to rise to 19% in 2026, according to UN figures, from 16.3% in 2015. The share of the working-age (15-66) population peaked at 66% in 2009; since then it has gradually declined. The size of the working-age population is forecast to increase at a modest rate over the coming years, supported by net immigration. However, its share of the total population will maintain its downward trend, falling to 63.5% by 2026.
The demographic challenge is not as severe as in other European countries Norway's population is not ageing quite as rapidly as in some EU countries, but its upward direction nevertheless implies steadily increasing pressures on the public finances, with older citizens requiring more state support in the form of pensions, health and social care. Reforms aimed at bolstering the sustainability of the pension system via flexible retirement ages (from 62 to 75), adjustments for life expectancy and less generous indexation have been implemented since the early 2000s. Further changes are likely over the forecast period, with a focus on disincentivising early retirement. Healthcare expenditure will continue to rise steadily, along with the median age of the population. Greater fiscal burdens will also be placed on local and municipal government, as the burden of social care for the aged, in the form of live-in helpers or retirement homes, will also steadily increase as the average age of the population rises.
Owing to Norway's unique geography, with a long coastline and separated settlements, rural areas are far more dispersed than in many other European countries, raising the cost of services provision for isolated communities. This is aggravated by an increasingly concentrated population as a whole, with 83.3% of Norway's population living in urban areas in 2021. Areas in the far north of Norway are remote and underpopulated; Finnmark, the northernmost region, has a population of 76,000 dispersed across 48,600 sq km. The cost of maintaining public service provision in rural areas was a driver behind the "municipal reform" implemented by the Conservatives-led government in 2020.

Norway will remain one of the world's wealthiest countries Norway is one of the richest countries in the world, with elevated levels of GDP per head and median household income, and access to the EU single market via membership of the European Economic Area (EEA). Market opportunities are constrained, however, by the comparatively small size of the domestic market, its geographical location and high operating costs. In terms of GDP per head (at market exchange rates), Norway ranked fourth in the world in 2021, at about US$94,394, behind only Luxembourg, Switzerland and Ireland. Measured at purchasing power parity (PPP), adjusting for different price levels between countries that are not always captured by market exchange rates, Norway ranked seventh, behind also Singapore, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. The country's population of 5.4m is among the smallest in western Europe, just above that of Ireland and marginally lower than in Denmark and Finland. In terms of market size, nominal GDP of US$480bn in 2021 was about one-third larger than in Finland and Portugal and similar in scale to Denmark, accounting for a modest 0.5% of global GDP. Estimates of the distribution of household income (such as the Gini index) point to a comparatively low level of inequality in Norway, reflecting relatively high rates of marginal taxation and redistribution, alongside high levels of trust and co-operation within its society.
Norway's consumer goods market is modest in size, similar to those of Denmark and Portugal and about one-tenth that of the UK. Household consumption per head (at US$34,730 in 2021) is among the highest in western Europe and above all its Nordic peers. Norway's share of private consumption in total GDP is lower than in most west European economies, mainly owing to a large public sector. In 2021 household consumption accounted for 39% of GDP, well below that of the UK (61%), Italy (58%), France (52%), Finland (51%) and Germany (49%), and slightly lower than in Denmark (46%) and Sweden (44%). Real consumption growth averaged 3% per year in 2010-15, moderating to 1.7% per year in 2016-19. The pandemic triggered a slump in consumer spending in 2020, but also a spike in household savings. EIU expects that the savings glut will be exhausted by 2023, with household savings rates returning to pre-pandemic levels. Consumer spending is therefore likely to slow markedly in late 2022 and 2023 owing to higher inflation across Europe (although it will remain positive, unlike in many of Norway's European peer countries). We expect a gradual rebound in 2024-26, with household consumption per head in 2026 forecast at US$45,830 and GDP per head at US$114,458 at market exchange rates.
