Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability Climate change is expected to have a moderate, but clearly negative effect on Italian living standards and the economy. Hotter summers increase the risk of drought, particularly in the country's southern and island regions, in many parts of which water is scarce. This will have an impact on food crops and agricultural production, and could affect human health, especially among the country's growing elderly population. In addition to putting traditional agricultural products such as citrus fruits and wine grapes at risk, an increased incidence of drought will also heighten the risk of wildfires. Italy has about 7,600 km of coastline, and rising sea levels could put some low-lying coastal areas of the country at risk of flooding. Rising seas will be particularly problematic for the city of Venice, a major tourist destination and a regional capital, and more erratic weather patterns are likely to strain ageing infrastructure. EIU's model to evaluate the impact of climate change on long-term growth finds that the Italian economy will be 2.8% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
Technological developments Despite Italy's sizeable manufacturing base and the presence of some notable high-technology firms, technological uptake has been limited, constrained in part by small average firm size and family management, which in some cases limits innovation. In 2017-18 a representative survey of nearly 24,000 industrial firms conducted by the Ministry of Economic Development found that only 8.4% had implemented technologies associated with "Industry 4.0" or the trend towards automation and data exchange in manufacturing, such as 3D printing, the internet of things, cloud technologies, or "big data" analytics. The share rises sharply in firms with 250 or more employees, to about 47%, compared with 6% for firms with fewer than ten employees. In 2017 research and development (R&D) spending accounted for just 1.35% of GDP-well below the EU average of 2%. Meanwhile, the trade balance of high-technology goods stood at -0.54% of GDP in 2015 (latest data available). Since 2016 a series of tax credits and deductions known as Impresa 4.0 has been introduced to encourage investment in R&D and productivity-enhancing technologies, but a higher level of direct support and possibly an upskilling of the labour force may be necessary to take full advantage of technological advances. Persons with a tertiary degree or employed in science and technology account for about 33% of total employment, and higher education suffers from relatively high dropout rates and long university completion times.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. EIU's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows the EIU to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by the EIU for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2017-21) and from EIU assessments for the forecast period (2022-26). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by the EIU for 2017-21. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2022-26 are based on EIU assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; the EIU, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2017-21 ranges are then used to derive 2022-26 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2022-26, not to the likely situation in 2026 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2019 or 2024). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - Political volatility will increase in the run-up to and the aftermath of the next election, due to be held no later than early 2023. The unpopularity of the incumbent military-aligned coalition under the leadership of the Phalang Pracharat (PP) party and the prime minister (and coup leader), Prayuth Chan-ocha, means that the opposition is likely to make major gains, although the tilted political landscape could still allow the pro-military parties to form a government. EIU does not expect the return of massive and sustained student-led protests; demonstrations will remain too modest in scale to oust the incumbent or future pro-military governments. In any case, after 2023 the royalist-military alliance will maintain its strong influence on Thai politics.

Thailand--highlights: Business environment outlook

- Thailand's business environment score improves in 2022-26. However, faster progress elsewhere means that its global ranking has fallen by four places to 42th, from 38th in 2017-21. Its regional position remains at ninth out of 17 countries. The higher overall score reflects minor improvement in a number of subcategories. Thailand's score for policy towards foreign investment will improve as the government rolls out incentives and liberalises the regulatory regime, partly via the implementation of multinational trade agreements, to attract much-needed foreign investors. Likewise, EIU expects an improvement in the market opportunities category as household income and, therefore, domestic demand resume a steady growth trajectory after 2022. An anticipated acceleration of infrastructure projects, including in digitalisation and 5G, will also boost Thailand's scores for infrastructure and technological readiness.

- We expect Thailand's real GDP to expand by an average of 3.3% per year in 2022-26. The post-pandemic rebound will only be fully realised in 2023, as tourism will remained curtailed in 2022 by the pandemic. The growth rate will become steady but will remain slower than before the pandemic. It will take until early 2023 for the economy to recover to its pre-pandemic level of output. Growth will rely more heavily on public investment and the external sector as household spending stagnates. The tourism sector will return to pre-pandemic levels only in early 2024, as travel restrictions are likely remain in China throughout 2022-23.

- The rate of population growth will slow in the forecast period as a result of effective family-planning programmes and changing social norms, such as later marriage and smaller families. Improvement in the prevention and treatment of infectious disease will contribute to a longer life expectancy and an ageing population; this will put a burden on healthcare provision. Migrant labour from Cambodia, Laos and especially Myanmar, after the junta seized power there, will grow in absolute terms after a slump in 2021-22 amid pandemic-related travel restrictions, but the overall labour force is still expected to contract. Foreign workers will play a more prominent role in Thailand's labour market during the latter part of the forecast period, as the trend of a declining domestic workforce persists amid a marked increase in the elderly population compared with its peers.

- Thailand is a sizeable market, with a population of nearly 72m and nominal GDP equivalent to US$505.8bn (at market exchange rates) in 2021. As with the broader economy, the retail sector will resume a steady growth trajectory from 2023. However, household debt will continue to dampen consumer sentiment in the forecast period. The continued rise of e-commerce and digital payments will irrevocably change consumers' habits and create new market opportunities at the expense of traditional bricks-and-mortar stores.

Thailand--highlights: Long-term outlook   2022-30 2031-50 2022-50

- Thailand's long-term outlook hinges on the assumption that governments in the next ten years will prove capable of enacting structural reforms and upgrading infrastructure. There will be persistent challenges owing to an inefficient bureaucracy, political deadlock and a tourism-oriented economy. Without such reforms, Thailand's growth will consistently fall well below its potential and lag behind regional neighbours. In later decades, Thailand's unfavourable demographic profile and the impact of climate change will also affect GDP growth and political stability.

Background: Thailand's absolute monarchy was replaced with a constitutional monarchy in 1932. Although the elected government gained prominence, democracy was turbulent and has subsequently been subject to 19 coups. The latest took place in 2014, when the democratically elected government, led by Yingluck Shinawatra, was removed following months of political turmoil. Yingluck's older brother, Thaksin Shinawatra, another elected prime minister, had been removed in a coup in 2006. Thaksin was a populist leader, and his political standing created a divide between the rural population, particularly in the north-eastern provinces, and the urban population-a lasting feature of Thai democracy. A return in 2019 to a limited form of democracy, led by military-aligned parties, is likely to renew rivalry between the two camps.
Political structure: Following the recent transition from junta administration to nominally civilian government, parliament takes the form of a bicameral National Assembly, consisting of an elected 500-seat House of Representatives (the lower house) and a 250-seat Senate (the upper house) appointed by the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO). The prime minister is appointed by the National Assembly, and King Maha Vajiralongkorn remains the symbolic head of state.
Policy issues: The government will continue to prioritise reviving the economy in the short term, amid the protracted fallout from the pandemic. It will return to its focus on improving the investment environment in Thailand, which will include the acceleration of a planned infrastructure upgrade, to facilitate the country's economic breakthrough in the longer term. This emphasis on long-term policy continuity should reassure many foreign investors deterred by potential political instability, but growing regional competition will detract from Thailand's attractiveness as an investment destination.
Taxation: Corporate income tax stands at 20%. Tax concessions are available for firms that list on the stock market. Value-added tax (VAT) stands at 7%. Personal income tax rises to 35% on annual taxable earnings exceeding Bt5m (US$150,000). As the economy reopens, one-off waivers and the deferral of tax payments introduced during the pandemic in 2020-21 have been largely phased out.
Foreign trade: Thailand recorded a merchandise trade surplus (fob-fob) of US$40bn in 2021, remaining on a par with US$40.8bn in 2020. However, a rare deficit on the services account resulted in an overall current-account deficit of US$10.6bn, compared to a substantial surplus of US$20.3bn in 2020.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance A military-aligned civilian government assumed power in July 2019, following the election held in March. The government consists of an 18-party coalition led by the Phalang Pracharat (PP), with a former general and coup leader, Prayuth Chan-ocha, as prime minister. Following the turbulent events surrounding the dissolution of the second-largest opposition party, Future Forward Party (FFP), in February 2020 and subsequent defections, the coalition cemented its hold on power, and this has remained intact despite frequent factional in-fighting, including a split in the PP in January 2022, and the return of student-led protests in 2020-21. Prior to the 2019 election, the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO, the military junta) had ruled Thailand since the coup of 2014, and the military continues to exercise substantial political influence through a constitution drafted by its members in 2016-17. The legislature comprises a 250-seat Senate (upper house) appointed by the military and endorsed by the king, and a 500-seat House of Representatives (lower house) elected democratically. These features will incline future governments to be aligned with the junta's preferences. Nonetheless, the military's power is not entirely unchecked, made evident by the fact that PP governs in a fractious coalition with a long tradition of jockeying for positions within government. The lower house also includes a sizeable anti-junta opposition (led by Puea Thai, the party of two former prime ministers-and siblings-Yingluck and Thaksin Shinawatra, and the Move Forward Party, which is a continuation of the now-disbanded FFP).

King Maha Vajiralongkorn, who was formally crowned in May 2019, will oversee stability in the monarchy. Although the king will remain removed from day-to-day politics, he will adopt a more centralised style of leadership than that of his revered late father. Throughout the forecast period, the military will continue to look to (and defend) the monarchy to legitimise its own political role as the mutually beneficial royalist-military alliance, which has dominated the country's politics since the coup in 2014, endures. Nonetheless, the king's prominent place in Thai society will diminish in the medium term, as the new monarch-stung further by criticism about his performance during the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic-fails to command the same level of reverence among the public that his father did.

Political outlook: Political stability EIU believes that the military will retain strong political influence in the forecast period. Prayuth Chan-ocha, a former junta leader who is supported by the Phalang Pracharat (PP) party, will serve out his four-year term as prime minister, ending in 2023, despite questions over the constitutionality of his serving more than eight years in the post. However, the risk of the ruling party not selecting Prayuth as its candidate for prime minister in the 2023 election has risen, following three by-election defeats in January 2022 and a heavy loss in the gubernatorial election in the capital, Bangkok, in May; the results reflect a decline in his popularity. It is still unclear who would be the most likely alternative candidate for PP. Under Thailand's constitution, the prime minister is not required to be a member of parliament but must be approved by a parliamentary majority. If Prayuth opts out, the field for his replacement as PP's candidate is wide open.
As the general election due in 2023 approaches, student-led protests could resume, causing local disturbance for businesses. However, they would not result in the removal of Prayuth's government or democratic reforms that would loosen the tight grip on power held by royalists and the military. Protests will centre on similar demands to those in 2020: constitutional amendment and an end to the harassment of the government's critics. Reform of the monarchy and an end to the draconian lese-majesty law could also feature.
Our baseline forecast is that the protest movement will not seriously disrupt the basic functioning of public institutions. We do not expect any major constitutional reform to be introduced ahead of the next general election. Crucially, there is no sign of a split in the alliance between the military and the royal establishment, which has been influential in Thailand's politics for years. With strong command over the security and legal apparatus, the government will continue to keep protest leaders and other critics in check through legal means. Under such circumstances, the risk of a crackdown by force will also persist over 2022-26.
In terms of day-to-day governance, stability will be maintained. The ruling coalition will hold until the end of its term, despite growing internal disputes and the opposition's attempt to launch a no-confidence motion before the next general election. King Maha Vajiralongkorn, on the throne since 2016, will not exert the same stabilising influence as his revered father, although the military establishment will continue to depend on royal endorsement for its political legitimacy and will suppress criticism of the monarch.
The localised insurgency in the three Muslim-dominated southern provinces will continue in the form of small-scale attacks on the security forces. However, this presents only a minimal threat to overall political stability.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness The outlook for political and institutional effectiveness will be underpinned by policy continuity under the auspices of the junta-drafted constitution of 2016-17. In particular, the incumbent and future governments' ability to pass and implement legislation will be supported by the constitutionally mandated 20-year "National Strategy"-a blueprint for develop-ment devised by the junta. Until the next election (to be held no later than early 2023), the current pro-military government will continue to possess expanded unilateral executive and legislative power through the emergency decree issued in 2020 in response to the covid-19 pandemic. Prayuth still enjoys a comfortable majority in the lower house despite the recent expulsion of a rival faction from PP in January 2022, following a series of defections from the opposition in 2020. Nonetheless, frequent disputes and factional struggles within the coalition on issues outside the National Strategy could return to stall major policies after the end of the pandemic-related emergency decree in the latter part of our forecast period, made evident by the delayed passage of previous budgets.
Threats to government effectiveness will also arise from the vocal opposition, especially from the resilient street protests that have vehemently decried the military's continued grip on power. The anticipated alleviation of a protracted public health and related economic crisis in 2022-23 will lead to a return to more intense political confrontation as pent-up grievances among the opposition re-emerge in the run-up to the general election. Such grievances will focus largely on the government's handling of the pandemic and the economy remaining mired on a long and uncertain road to recovery. This will lead to instances of legislative gridlock and stymied policymaking. Later in the forecast period, a potential boycott of parliament, coinciding with the aforementioned street protests, could impede the government's ability to enact new legislation.
Nonetheless, PP, with an eye to the upcoming election, will devote significant resources to populist policies, in order to appease interest groups such as farmers and tourist operators, while simultaneously pursuing a pro-business push. The junta has made little progress in reconciling the longstanding political differences between the rural population of the north (who supported Thaksin) and the "elite" in southern Thailand (who are repre-sented by his detractors, the current establishment), as well as emerging calls from metropolitan youth for liberal democracy. The military-aligned government will consequently continue to find it difficult to satisfy the three major camps and may face rising opposition from multiple fronts in the medium term.
Political outlook: Election watch The exact date of the next general election, scheduled to be held in the first half of 2023, will probably be announced after Thailand hosts the Asia-Pacific Economic Community (APEC) meeting in mid-November.
The gubernatorial election in Bangkok in May, which Chadchart Sittipunt, a transport minister in an earlier Puea Thai party (PTP) government, won by a landslide, is another sign that the government's handling of the economy remains unpopular, and indicates an edge for the opposition.
Following in-fighting within both the ruling coalition and the opposition, several new parties have been established, representing factions that split from the main parties. Nevertheless, alliances are still formed loosely around the pro-military and opposition camps. Within the opposition camp, there is a split between the PTP, which remains dominated by the Shinawatra family, and the Move Forward Party (MFP), which appeals more to younger voters through its left-leaning and anti-establishment stance.
Although we expect the opposition to make significant gains in the upcoming election, it is not clear that they can attain a clear majority in the House of Representatives (the lower house). There is also a pending amendment concerning the electoral system, which, in a reversal of the new law approved only last year by the governing coalition, would again favour smaller factions at the expense of big opposition parties. In addition, the military-aligned bloc still enjoys the advantage of a tilted political landscape that allows the appointed Senate (the upper house) to vote on the selection of the prime minister. Therefore, we do not rule out the possibility that the military-aligned bloc may again string together a majority coalition, as it did in 2019, even if its flagship PP loses ground. In any case, we expect the royalist-military alliance to retain its strong influence on Thai politics in 2022-26. A truce between the PTP and the military-aligned bloc cannot be ruled out entirely, depending on the outcome of the election, but remains unlikely in our view.
Political outlook: International relations The partial return to democracy in 2019 has created more favourable circumstances for deeper ties with Western governments compared with the last period of junta rule in 2014-18. In the wake of the pandemic, developments will include the resumption of talks on an EU-Thailand free-trade agreement and more frequent high-profile visits by Western leaders. Meanwhile, Japan will also pursue a closer economic partnership, both bilaterally and through the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN). Thailand will stay engaged with the US and China; both superpowers have moved to pursue closer ties with the country as their rivalry intensifies. Thailand has indicated its willingness to join the fledgling Indo-Pacific Economic Framework championed by the US and will continue to adopt a neutral stance on the Russia-Ukraine war, reflecting a desire to avoid being drawn into the conflict.
China's influence in Thailand will remain strong. With the countries having no conflicting territorial claims in the South China Sea and a shared hardline stance against liberal opposition, economic ties are set to strengthen further. Thailand will focus on attracting Chinese investment under two flagship initiatives: "Thailand 4.0" and the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC, a large special economic zone south-east of Bangkok). Contractual and financial issues will continue to delay the implementation of some of the more costly and long-term projects under these initiatives.
Bilateral co-operation with China will be accompanied by Thailand's ongoing efforts to engage with fellow member states of ASEAN on economic integration, including the implementation of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade agreement, which took effect in January 2022.
The government will remain critical of the junta in Myanmar, but will refrain from undertaking measures such as economic sanctions. Inflows of Burmese citizens into Thailand will rise markedly, but will not be sufficient to destabilise the country or the wider region.

Thailand's overall score improves in 2022-26 as domestic economic conditions normalise following the lifting of coronavirus-related restrictions. Most categories have recorded an improvement in scores amid expectations that the government will return to its priority of strengthening the country's economic competitiveness. The notable exception is the macroeconomic environment category, which has been weighed down by a pandemic-induced deterioration of the traditionally strong indicators in Thailand's fiscal and current accounts. An improvement in the scores for market opportunities and technological readiness is noteworthy and bodes well for the country's medium-term attractiveness and prospects for the digital-isation of businesses. An improvement in the scores for infrastructure and policy towards foreign investment will encourage a moderate rise in investment in the medium term. Some relocation of supply chains to Thailand, amid persistent China-US tensions, will also provide a modest boost to manufacturing activity in the latter part of the forecast period. This will be aided by an open capital account and a relatively stable currency. The "Thailand 4.0" initiative, which entails an ambitious infrastructure upgrade, will proceed, but will growing challenges during the forecast period, as future construction projects to stimulate economic growth will be constrained by tighter fiscal space after the pandemic. Lacklustre domestic demand will remain a major drag on business sentiment. Rapid inflation (amid the war in Ukraine) and high household debt will weigh on private consumption prospects following the exhaustion of the immediate rebound from the lifting of pandemic-related restrictions.
The BOT will continue to raise the policy rates gradually in 2023 The Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) will remain independent. Its governor, Sethaput Suthiwart-Narueput, will have to strike a balance between reviving the economy and curbing inflation. This will translate into a gradual but longer monetary tightening cycle compared with those of its peers and the US.

Business environment outlook: Thailand's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2022-23: The authorities put off management reform and provide substantive financial support for state-owned enterprises.
2024-26: Thailand improves its domestic intellectual property rights (IPR) enforcement regime, which leads to the country's removal from the US Trade Representative's IPR watchlist.
Policy towards foreign investment 2022-23: The Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) relaxes rules-on a short-term basis-on inflows into the country's financial markets, as it seeks a speedy recovery from the pandemic-induced recession.
2024-26: Opposition to the sale of assets to foreigners persists, particularly in the utilities sector. The authorities introduce new incentives to promote inward investment in targeted industries, while removing those in low-value-added sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2022-23: The country champions the quick implementation of the ratified Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP)-an agreement to harmonise ASEAN's exisiting free-trade agreements (FTAs) within the regional bloc.
2024-26: Thailand completes negotiations with the EU on a free-trade zone and starts talks on joining the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP).
Taxes 2022-23: The authorities continue to implement one-off tax breaks and fee waivers for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).
2024-26: The government raises the rate of value-added tax (VAT) slightly from its current level of 7%, which exempts cryptocurrencies and digital assets. Qualified, highly skilled professionals pay a reduced rate of 17% in income tax.
Financing 2022-23: Concessionary financing for the SME sector and selected debt holidays continue. Thailand links its QR code payment system with those of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore.
2024-26: As competition from foreign and digital banks heats up in the aftermath of the pandemic, the banking sector teams up with financial technology companies and expands its own digital service platform.
The labour market 2022-23: The daily minimum wages of 16 professions in construction, industrial art and service sectors are raised. The government extends the work permits of migrant workers.
2024-26: Shortages of skilled labour become more acute, driving up costs in high-value-added industries. The law is relaxed to raise the labour participation rate among women and older workers.
Infrastructure 2022-23: The expansion of utilities, road and rail infrastructure progresses, providing a boost to the construction sector.
2024-26: Expansion work is completed at Don Muang and Suvarnabhumi international airports in the capital, Bangkok. Infrastructure development under the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) scheme accelerates.
Technological readiness 2022-23: The rollout of the 5G network expands as the government implements regulations related to data privacy, e-commerce and cyber security. Grassroots digital literacy initiatives advance, but access is still challenging for remote areas.
2024-26: The Board of Investment continues to prioritise investment approval for projects in the sectors targeted by the Thailand 4.0 industrial policy. The private sector champions the expansion of digitalisation of the economy.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's macroeconomic environment score declines from 7.8 in 2017-21 to 6.9 in 2022-26. This translates into a steep fall in the global ranking from 16th to 40th, and a fall in the regional ranking from 5th to 10th. Economic growth will accelerate from 2.9% in 2022 to an average of 3.4% in 2023-26. The relatively modest economic rebound lags behind other economies in the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN), and its GDP will therefore be among the last in the region, barring Myanmar, to return to its pre-coronavirus level. Although almost all travel restrictions were lifted in July 2022, the tourism sector will continue to struggle until at least 2024, owing to a lack of arrivals from China, which will maintain its "zero-covid" policy throughout 2023. Ongoing tensions between the US and China, recurring lockdowns in major Chinese cities and the war in Ukraine will continue to fuel supply-chain disruption and inflation, which will dampen domestic consumption and investors' appetite for emerging economies such as Thailand. Weak recovery means that the Thai government will not be able quickly to bring down the swollen government debt, which has breached 60% of GDP.
The economy will return to its pre-pandemic size only in 2023
- The military will maintain a strong grip on economic affairs in 2022-26 and oversee the approval of major spending plans to stimulate the economy back to growth. The constitutionally mandated National Strategy (2018-37), the junta's 20-year blueprint for development, will undergo changes after an ongoing review by the government's National Economic and Social Development Council, with a stronger emphasis on generating tangible results in terms of job creation and GDP growth in the short term and strengthening the grass-roots economy in the longer term. This will include an acceleration of infrastructure projects and renewed commitments on the agriculture sector, where Thailand has traditionally been competitive, and the health sector. Strategy for the tourism sector will be tweaked towards targeting high-spending tourists amid the pandemic. The main objective of avoiding the middle-income trap will stay. The government will also ensure that business-oriented tax reform and investment incentives are maintained and expanded in 2022-26, and that major infrastructure investment projects continue beyond this period. In the early part of the forecast period, Chinese restrictions on outbound travel will slow the recovery of Thailand's tourism sector. Nonetheless, broad economic stability will be ensured by sound macroeconomic fundamentals, including a still-healthy current-account surplus and manageable levels of public debt. This will be helped by the normalisation of global economic conditions in 2022-26.
- The Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) under its governor, Sethaput Suthiwart-Narueput, will uphold its traditional credibility, as it remains relatively free from political pressure in setting policy rates and managing excess volatility in the local currency, the baht. It will balance the objectives of supporting economic recovery while preserving financial stability, which aligns with the economic agenda of the prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
6.5 6.5 32 36 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition in 2022-26 remains the same as in 2017-21. Thailand's global ranking falls from 32nd to 36th. However, the country's regional ranking will remain unchanged despite the slight improvements in the business conditions in other Asian countries.. Corruption and favouritism will continue to distort free-market dynamics, made evident by the slow progress of cases, despite the media attention that the National Anti-Corruption Commission (NACC) has received in recent years. Big business groups with ties to the political elite retain a disproportionate influence on commercial affairs. Individuals with ties to military and political leaders tend to extract concessions from government and influence legal outcomes. Against this backdrop, the return to a quasi-civilian regime since the March 2019 election will not lead to any significant improvement in government accountability.
The pace of privatisation of SOEs will remain glacial in 2022-26
- Reforms to bolster the operational efficiency of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) have been proposed in recent years, but the prospect of their implementation has grown even more remote in the wake of the pandemic. Any such reform would redistribute economic rents away from current holders. Privatisation remains a sensitive issue among both powerful interests and the public. It is unlikely that the military-aligned government will sell off state assets, especially after those assets have received government bail-outs and will probably remain at a discounted price for the foreseeable future. The continuation of price controls will distort competition in Thailand, as the government will maintain them for some basic goods to make them affordable.

Intellectual property infringement will remain an issue despite tougher laws
- Thailand has been on the US Trade Representative's lower-priority Watch List for intellectual property (IP) since 2017. Attempts to regulate intellectual property rights more effectively have led to the amended Copyrights Act, which came into effect in August 2022. This revised law extends the protection for photographic works to align with international standards, and strengthens reporting and enforcement mechanisms. Although the country has continued to make minor progress on matters related to patents and copyright legislation in recent years, instances of IP infringement remain relatively frequent. This comes from a combination of legislative and enforcement issues, such as Thailand's absence from the World Intellectual Property Organisation's (WIPO) Copyright Treaty, a limited level of punitive measures and patent application backlogs. As the country seeks to reinvent itself after the pandemic as a "digital economy", under its Thailand 4.0 initiative, we expect improve-ments in the legal apparatus that will offer greater protection for patent holders during the latter part of the forecast period. However, enforcement will remain flawed.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
6.4 6.9 46 35 9 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for policy towards foreign investment improves in 2022-26, raising both the country's regional and global rankings. Thailand will continue to encourage inward investment, especially in higher-value-added industries, as part of the Thailand 4.0 industrial policy. The Board of Investment (BOI) will continue to fast-track investment approvals. The government is keenly aware of intense competition for foreign investment and will prioritise improving the country's attractiveness. It will also decline to revive proposals to amend the Foreign Business Act, which would make it more difficult for foreign companies to control Thai entities unless they own a majority of shares.
The government will focus on attracting investment to "S-curve" sectors
- The BOI's Investment Promotion Strategy (2023-28) is slated to be completed in September 2022. The new strategy will focus on attracting investment to high-technology "S-curve" sectors and the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC, a development initiative covering three eastern provinces). As part of the Thailand 4.0 policy, the scheme aims to galvanise 12 value-added sectors: next-generation automotive; high-value and medical tourism; biofuel and biochemical; defence; intelligent electronics; food for the future; aviation and logistics; digital; advanced agriculture and biotechnology; automation and robotics; medical and comprehensive healthcare; and education and human resource development. Leadership changes at the BOI could lead to changes in investment incentives.
- The Thai cabinet has approved a foreign land ownership programme. Effective from September 2022, the programme will allow foreigners to own up to 1 rai (0.16 ha) of land for residential purposes, on the condition that they invest Bt40m (US$1.1m) in selected Thai properties, funds and securities over the next three years. This scheme is aimed at attracting Bt800bn (US$22.9bn) in foreign investment between 2022 and 2026. The Ministry of Land will outline the regulations, with more details on qualification criteria and requirements.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
8.7 8.7 28 29 4 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for foreign trade and exchange controls in 2022-26 remains the same as in 2017-21. Thailand's global ranking has dropped slightly to 29th, from 28th in 2017-21, and its regional ranking fell from 4th to 6th. Non-tariff barriers such as licensing and labelling requirements continue to impede trade. Authorities will be more likely to accommodate the demands of influential domestic groups, especially farmers, in 2022-23, with an approaching election and the expectation of a full recovery in major export markets. The government will be keen to diversify export markets and will continue to pursue trade agreements, both individually and in partnership with other ASEAN members.

- Meanwhile, the country will adhere to its commitments as a member of the World Trade Organisation. Thailand has accepted the obligations laid down in the IMF's Article VIII, which stipulates that transactions on the current account should be free of restrictions. Foreign investors do not face restrictions on the repatriation of profits and dividends. The central bank has eased restrictions on outward capital flows, and temporary measures to control capital inflows imposed in 2019 and early 2020 will not remain in effect amid the ongoing pandemic, as the country urgently seeks a return of foreign investors.
- Although the ASEAN Economic Community, the bloc's single market, had already led to the lifting of most tariffs and freer movement of services, investment and skilled labour (in eight selected sectors) since end-2015, a commensurate increase in customs regulations and non-tariff barriers continued to limit intra-regional trade. Phenomenal growth in services trade as a result of the ASEAN Trade in Services Agreement is unlikely to materialise in 2022-26, or will, at best, be delayed to the later part of the forecast period.

RCEP will attract more investment into Thailand's competitive sectors.
- The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), effective since January 1st 2022, enables Thailand to diversify its import sources and export markets. RCEP's 40% rule-of-origin requirement allows the country to source inputs totalling up to 60% of the value of final goods from non-RCEP economies and to sell the final products duty-free within the bloc. The Investment Chapter adopts a negative list and abolishes performance requirements. These elements will spur investment into Thailand's most competitive sectors: automotive and electrical and electronics.
- The lifting of travel restrictions characterised by the elimination of the Thailand Pass since July 2022 will boost tourism and trade in services. Striving to revive the pandemic-battered tourism sector, the cabinet declared 2022-23 as "Visit Thailand Year" and will roll out measures to revitalise the industry.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
7.9 8.0 13 13 5 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's score in the taxes category increases marginally in 2022-26; the country's global and regional rankings maintain at 13th and 5th respectively. The marginal increase in the score is due to the implementation a new and fairer tax for property and land. Thailand's tax regime remains relatively simple, and changes have been made in recent years to reduce the overall burden on households and firms. The standard rate of corporate tax was reduced from 30% in 2011 to 20% in 2013. We expect it to remain at 20% during the forecast period, given the government's priority of attracting foreign investors. Personal income tax is also relatively favourable, with the top marginal rate standing at 35% for Thai and foreign workers with annual earnings of more than Bt5m (US$145,000).
VAT will remain low at 7% until September 2023
- Successive governments have repeatedly postponed an increase in the rate of value-added tax (VAT) from 7% to 10%. The government has declared that it will maintain the current rate of 7% until September 2023. The authorities will raise the rate in 2023-24 as the need to plug the fiscal gap arising from a jump in expenditure in 2020-21 takes precedence. However, this decision will be influenced by the prevailing political climate, as such an increase could serve as a catalyst for protests. Attempting to spur growth in the digital asset industry, the cabinet has exempted trade in cryptocurrencies and digital assets on authorised digital asset exchanges from VAT until the end of 2023.
- From 2023 onwards, the government will opt to curtail spending growth, rather than raise taxes, to reduce the fiscal deficit. As a longer-term initiative, the government will make efforts to expand revenue collection. These will include measures to enable digital and mobile payments to broaden the tax base, as well as the imposition of capital gains tax later in the forecast period. Meanwhile the tax on property and land will be implemented in September 2022. It will have only a minor impact on foreign business, with the tax rates most applicable to foreign investors likely to be set at less than 2%.
- The new long-term resident visa scheme, effective from September 2022, aims to make Thailand a regional hub for living and working for foreigners under four categories: wealthy global citizens, wealthy pensioners, work-from-Thailand professionals and highly skilled professionals. This programme grants 10-year renewable visas to qualified individuals and their dependants. Qualified highly skilled professionals will pay a reduced personal income tax rate of 17%.
- The Multilateral Convention to Implement Tax Treaty-Related Measures to Prevent Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (MLI) has been effective for Thailand since July 2022. MLI will reduce opportunities for profit-shifting and tax avoidance by multinational corporations.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
7.0 7.0 25 35 8 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand will focus on containing the covid fallout on its financial stability. Thailand will focus on containing the fallout from the pandemic on its financial stability. Thailand's score for financing remains stable in 2022-26, as the banking sector has remained resilient in the face of headwinds from the pandemic-induced recession. However, Thailand's global ranking for the category falls from 25th to 35th, and its regional ranking drops marginally from eighth to ninth. The ratio of non-performing loans (NPLs) to total loans remains relatively low, standing at 2.9% at end-March 2022. Although it has remained around this level since 2020, there is a substantial risk of rising NPLs when support measures are withdrawn. This will have a negative effect on the banking sector's asset quality and profitability, although the systemic risk is mitigated by the sector's ample capital adequacy and liquidity.

- The BOT and the Ministry of Finance will continue to focus on containing risks to the financial sector from the pandemic with a view to preserving financial stability. The central bank has extended its assistance to vulnerable groups, especially unsecured loans, until end-2023. NPLs will remain a threat to the profitability of banks during the latter part of the forecast period, especially those with a portfolio of mostly SMEs and individuals. The ongoing negotiations on liberalising banking services under the ASEAN Banking Integration Framework will drag on amid the pandemic and will only be concluded towards the end of the forecast period. However, Thailand's pursuit of increasing interoperability across ASEAN markets-via the facilitation of local-currency settlement and standardised digitisation of payments-will progress more quickly.
- Thailand is working with Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Singapore to link the countries' QR code payment systems by November 2022. This will facilitate payments among these economies and enhance financing in the forecast period.
- The local bond market will continue to expand under the guidance of the BOT. The bond market expanded by 6.6% to Bt15.1trn (US$432.7bn) in 2021, because of the introduction of the corporate bond stabilisation fund. Thailand's strong macroeconomic fundamentals and credible central bank, with a reputation for prudence, have made it ASEAN's largest local-currency bond market. Although government bonds continue to dominate the market, at 45% of total outstanding value, debt-laden large and medium-sized companies are increasingly using the bond market to refinance their bank loans and offshore borrowings.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
6.6 6.6 25 32 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's score and regional ranking in the labour market category remain unchanged in 2022-26, while its global ranking drops from 25th to 32nd; this reflects its waning competitiveness. The country is a labour-scarce economy and the official unemployment rate remains consistently low, which continued to hold true even amid the pandemic. The labour market will, in general, remain adequate in terms of supporting the operations of foreign-invested enterprises, but weaknesses-especially rising wage costs and skill shortages-will persist. Thailand's advantages as a cost-efficient base for labour-intensive production will vanish quickly amid growing competition from low-income neighbours such as Cambodia and Vietnam, which also happen to boast a large workforce.
A poorly skilled workforce will remain the biggest hurdle for "Thailand 4.0"
- Shortages of labour trained to work in high-value industries will continue to pose a huge problem for the government's Thailand 4.0 policy ambitions, which are premised on developing the country's advanced technology sectors. These skilled labour problems stem in large part from Thailand's under-performing education system, which ranks poorly both globally and regionally. Educational reforms in the last two decades have been poorly and inconsistently implemented, and there are currently still no plans for a major overhaul of the system. The ability of the labour force to meet the needs of businesses (in terms of specialist skills) is therefore likely to remain below global standards. In view of this situation, hiring skilled foreign workers will become easier, with the government set to relax visa restrictions during the forecast period, especially for the research and technology sectors. There is a urgent sense of the need to accelerate digital skills training among the labour force and students, but the skill upgrade process will take time to show results.
- From January 2017 the nationwide daily minimum-wage schedule was replaced by minimum wages by province. The range of the wage floor was raised to Bt313-336 (about US$10) with effect from January 2020. With an eye on the upcoming election, the government recently approved a substantial rise in the daily minimum wages for 16 professions in construction, industrial art and service sectors to up to Bt650, with effect from September 2022. Despite long-standing opposition in parliament and among business associations, owing to the effect it would have on private-sector costs and Thailand's regional competitiveness, we expect the government to succeed again in raising the minimum wage in 2022-26, as a populist measure to appease the working class. The cabinet approved the establishment of the National Pension Fund in early 2021, but a timeline for its implementation is still uncertain.
- Thailand is facing the social and economic consequences of a rapidly ageing society, including a steadily declining workforce as a share of the total population. Proposals advocating a staggered increase in the retirement age for civil servants-from 60 years to 63, with the option of delaying retirement in steps for up to ten years-have been postponed, but may still be implemented in the later part of the forecast period. The private sector has followed a more flexible rule on the retirement age since a court ruling in 2017, which means that employees, depending on contractual clauses, can exercise the right to retire at 60 or continue working.
- Migrant workers accounted for more than 10% of the total labour force prior to the pandemic, according to the UN. These workers typically come from neighbouring Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos, and fill low-skilled vacancies in industries such as agriculture, construction and domestic work. Since the pandemic, the country has suffered from a shortage of unskilled/low-skilled migrant workers. The cabinet approved extending these workers' stay in Thailand to up to February 2025 to ease the labour shortage. The labour pool will also be driven by the development of special economic zones (SEZs), which the government has opened in border areas to capitalise on the supply of low-cost migrant labour from neighbouring countries. As a result, tensions will inevitably rise between local and migrant workers on issues of mistreatment and locals' resentment of job losses to migrant labourers.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
5.0 6.0 52 51 9 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Infrastructure will remain a key pillar of the government's plan for recovery The country's score for infrastructure improves in the forecast period. While its global ranking rises from 52nd to 51st in 2022-26, Thailand's regional ranking drops marginally from 9th to 10th because of faster improvements in other Asian economies. The military-aligned government will expedite medium-sized work projects while continuing to push for faster progress on long-pending "megaprojects". 4G coverage is widely available, and its speed has improved. Within South-east Asia, the average internet speed lags behind only Singapore and Vietnam. Improvements in utilities, including work on electricity, water supply and distribution and gas pipes, will continue. Electricity supply has grown, but the potential for shortages remains. More than 70% of Thailand's electricity is generated using natural gas, according to the Energy Policy and Plan-ning Office, making the country vulnerable to fluctuations in global gas prices, which has become a more prominent issue amid the war in Ukraine.

- The government has faced delays in the financing and implementation stages of its ambitious infrastructure development megaprojects, in particular on the regional rail network, owing to issues with land acquisition, environmental impact and commercial viability. This includes the construction of the much-vaunted Thai section of the high-speed railway linking Thailand and China, via Laos (which has started after long delays, but is still in early stages). The Thai government had pledged to complete the Bangkok-Nong Khai section, of which only 5% has been built, by 2028. Elsewhere, regional transport projects have faced similar delays owing to wrangling over financing with Chinese and Japanese investors. This partly reflects the government's efforts to take advantage of the ongoing competition for geopolitical influence between the two countries to secure the best deal. We expect these dynamics to result in uneven progress on priority projects in 2022-26.
- The planned upgrade of the country's three major airports by Airports of Thailand (a state-run management company) is still ongoing. The expansion in the capital, Bangkok, will be completed by 2024. Expansion plans on the existing Chiang Mai and Phuket airports will be carried out during the forecast period to prepare for the post-pandemic revival of tourism, but the construction of new airports at Chiang Mai and Phuket will probably only materialise beyond the end of the forecast period. Expansion work on U-Tapao airport, in the EEC, will also start in 2023; operations will begin by 2026.

5G networks will continue to improve, as part of the Thailand 4.0 initiative
- The government will continue to prioritise the development of infrastructure in the EEC. The cabinet endorsed the EEC Regional Infrastructure Construction Action Plan for 2023-27 to galvanise transport networks. The plan encompasses 77 projects worth Bt337bn, including high-speed railways, Chachoengsao dryport and U-Tapao airport. During the forecast period there will be accelerated construction of government-supported megaprojects under EEC, which will in turn attract more foreign investment The pandemic has spurred the development of 5G networks in Thailand, and the country now leads its ASEAN counterparts in the 5G race. Three operators have already launched 5G networks, providing such services to retail customers. In June 2022 the government unveiled the Thailand 5G Alliance, a public-private grouping with the purpose of promoting next-generation applications in various sectors to transform the country into a regional digital hub, to support the Thailand 4.0 initiative.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
4.9 6.9 60 42 12 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's technological readiness score improves significantly in 2022-26, which boosts its global ranking to 42th and regional ranking to 10th in the forecast period. The change reflects our expectation that the government will increase its investment in research and development (R&D) and science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and continue to improve digital infrastructure in 2022-26. To fulfil its Thailand 4.0 goals, the government will scale up incentives for international companies to set up research bases inside the country. According to DataReportal, while Thailand's number of internet users per 100 population increased to 77.8 in January 2022, it remains lower than in Brunei (95), Singapore (92), Malaysia (89.6) and Cambodia (78.8). However, high smartphone usage still makes the country a ripe market for e-commerce and digital banking. As at April 2022 there were 88m mobile banking accounts in the country, which has a population of 70m.
Benefits of digitisation will not extend beyond big cities
- The government has outlined plans to pursue digital infrastructure projects initiated by the junta as part of the Thailand 4.0 strategy and the 20-year digital roadmap. The Village Broadband Project (Net Pracharat), launched in 2017, aims to bring national broadband to 25,000 remote communities, with the aim of developing rural areas and giving private-sector enterprises access to public infrastructure. Progress on this front has been slow because of cost issues and the poor quality of wireless hotspots, but the pandemic has increased the sense of urgency to accelerate broadband access for rural villages so that residents are not left behind. As Net Pracharat provides the internet in public spaces (not individual households), usage has declined since the start of the pandemic, amid fears over viral transmission in public spaces. The government has blacklisted a state telecoms company, TOT, over its failure to deliver broadband to these villages on time. As a result, any socioeconomic transformation to be brought about by 5G internet in the forecast period will still be limited to the big cities and their surrounding areas.
- The BOI will probably step up incentives, such as import duty exemptions on raw materials used in R&D, to expedite the development of innovative capacities in the private sector, which has long shown a lack of commercial acumen in the deployment of technology. Companies focused on biotechnology, nanotechnology, advanced materials or digital technology are also eligible for up to 13 years' exemption from corporate income tax if they co-operate with public research institutions in R&D. Spurred by the pandemic, digitalisation efforts will increase in the private sector, and there will be greater adoption of artificial intelligence, big data and quantum computing, especially among large companies with resources.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The government has shifted its policy to "living with covid", treating the disease as endemic, and has allowed the resumption of normal economic activity. This has included lifting border controls and welcoming back international tourists. A vast majority of the adult population has been fully vaccinated, which reduces the risk of the healthcare system being overwhelmed by any potential future coronavirus outbreaks.
The war in Ukraine will discourage the Thai government from fiscal austerity, as it looks to avoid derailing the economic recovery in 2022. Domestic demand had barely recovered from the pandemic when prices of basics such as energy and food began to rise sharply. This means that some relief measures introduced during the pandemic will remain in place, and that price controls will be imposed on some essential goods as the government aims to cushion rising living costs. Growth is not expected to return to pre-pandemic levels in 2022, making Thailand a laggard among its regional peers.
In time, the government will return to its long-term focus on boosting economic competitiveness. The ambitious Thailand 4.0 industrial policy will remain the blueprint for the country's transformation into a sophisticated manufacturing and technology hub. This will entail the provision of generous tax breaks and more accessible working visas for foreign investors and professionals. However, Thailand's aspiration to become a high-technology economy will face obstacles-most notably the lack of skilled labour and fierce competition from better-positioned regional peers. Conflict with vested interests and political competition will continue to affect major public infrastructure projects, which will fall behind schedule and exert a drag on competitiveness.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)
  2021 2022 2023 2024 2025 2026
Government expenditure 20.1 20.9 21.3 20.8 20.8 20.5
Government revenue 14.6 15.9 17.1 17.2 17.5 17.6
Budget balance -5.5 -5.0 -4.2 -3.7 -3.3 -2.9
We forecast the budget deficit to remain wide by historical standards in 2022, at the equivalent of 5% of GDP, owing to the ongoing impact of the pandemic and surging inflation on tax revenue and government spending. Thailand has unveiled multiple rounds of stimulus totalling more than US$13bn since early 2021, the disbursement of which will add to the deficit in the coming years. Measures aimed at slowing the rise in consumer prices generated by the war in Ukraine, including fuel subsidies, will also contribute to the deficit in 2022.
The government will finance the deficit through the issuance of new debt, enabled by the authorisation of additional borrowing worth US$16bn in June 2021 and the raising of the debt ceiling from 60% of GDP to 70%. We forecast that this will drive total public debt to the equivalent of around 62.6% of the country's nominal GDP by 2023, from a pre-pandemic level of 41.2% in 2019.
Expensive relief measures have already been phased out gradually and further withdrawal of stimulus measures will continue this year, amid growing concern over the surging debt stock. This will markedly narrow the budget deficit in 2024 to a pre-pandemic level. Increased infrastructure spending and investment will form the bulk of the rise in government expenditure after the impact of the pandemic dissipates, funded in part by steady economic growth. An increase in value-added tax in the latter part of the forecast period, from the current rate of 7%, will also bolster revenue.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2021 2022 2023 2024 2025 2026
Commercial banks' prime rate (av) 3.1 3.3 4.2 4.4 4.5 4.7
Short-term interest rate (year-end) 0.4 0.6 1.4 1.7 1.5 1.3
Money market interest rate (year‑end) 0.5 0.6 1.5 1.7 1.3 1.2
The war in Ukraine will continue to exert upward pressure on domestic prices and depreciatory pressure on the local currency, the baht, against the US dollar. As economic recovery should firm in the second half of 2022 (albeit remaining modest compared to Thailand's peers), we now expect the Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) to raise its policy interest rates three times this year; the first of these was sanctioned at the monetary policy meeting in August. By the end of the year the interest rate should reach 1.25%, from a record low of 0.5%. Barring a recession among Thailand's major trading partners, gradual monetary tightening should continue until policy rates return to about 2% by the end of 2023. In the later part of the forecast period, we expect the authorities to switch to monetary easing again, as the priority will shift back to supporting growth, given Thailand's tepid expansion in comparison with its peers.
Despite aggressive tightening in the US, the relatively fragile recovery will prevent the BOT from mirroring that rapid pace in raising the policy rate. Concern about the high level of household debt, currently at about 90% of GDP, will also complicate any rapid moves to raise rates.
The latent impact of the economic fallout from the pandemic will lead to a rise in non-performing loans in the banking sector in 2022-23. However, the ongoing support measures for distressed debtors, spearheaded by the BOT, will help to keep the rise in bad loans manageable for banks.
