Healthy GDP growth will underpin macroeconomic developments India's score for macroeconomic environment remains unchanged in the forecast period, even as its position both globally and regionally improve to 51st and 14th respectively, from 54th and 15th in 2017-21, owing to setbacks among its closest peers in this category. India's growth will remain healthy over the forecast period, led by a strong acceleration in activity in sectors such as services and construction. Twin deficits on the fiscal and current accounts will persist in the forecast period. The current and next government will continue consolidating the fiscal deficit through a wider tax net and disinvestments of state-owned enterprises, while spending on infrastructure creation. The depreciation in the rupee will be more modest over 2023-26 than that over 2022, as geopolitical contagion due to the Russia-Ukraine war fades. India's current-account deficit will remain fairly manageable, at an average of 1.3% of GDP in the five years to 2026, while consumer price inflation will remain within the central bank's targeted band of 2-6%, after breaches seen in 2022. As the pressure from swift monetary tightening in the US abates, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, central bank) will embark on loosening monetary policy through rate cuts from 2024.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
4.5 5.8 58 48 11 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Stake sales will face resistance from vested groups but will proceed India's score for policy towards private enterprise and competition improves from 4.5 in 2017-21 to 5.8 in 2022-26, partly as a result of efforts to privatise state-owned enterprises, which will reduce the distorting impact of the state sector on the economy. The authorities have, however, set more realistic targets for selling stakes in government enterprises, after three years of failing to achieve ambitious disinvestment revenue. The disinvestment target for 2022/23 (April-March) has been set at a realistic and modest Rs650bn (US$8.6bn), incorporating stake sales of state-owned banks and oil marketing companies. The privatisation drive received a significant legislative boost in August 2021, albeit specific only to the insurance sector. The passage of the General Insurance Business (Nationalisation) Amendment Act in August 2021 has opened the door for the government to reduce its stake in state-owned insurance companies in a material way. The changes have removed the obligation for the central government to own at least 51% of the equity in an insurer. Currently, there are four major state-run general insurers. Delays to planned sales will continue amid opposition from unions and other vested interests. More success is expected from the government's initiative to monetise its infrastructure assets. In 2021 the government laid out a Rs6trn pipeline of assets to be sold by 2025. The projects span sectors like roads, railways and power.

- Areas of improvement include stronger protection for private property and more secure rights for minority shareholders. Overall, the country's higher score will raise it ten spots in the global table, to 48th, while its regional rank edges up from 11th to 10th. The government has made progress on streamlining the bureaucracy, easing the approval process for industrial and infrastructure projects. It has also encouraged competition between states by allowing them to experiment on pro-business liberalisation over and beyond the regulations imposed centrally. Despite these state-level measures, however, the scope for improvement remains huge and more reforms will come in 2022-26.
- We expect the protection of intellectual property in India to improve over the next five years. This will reflect pressure from domestic companies to toughen enforcement as local levels of investment in research and development (R&D) increase, while this also remains a major stumbling block in free trade agreements that India is pursuing with the EU and the UK. The regime is nonetheless likely to remain patchy, with courts in more developed parts of the country offering better levels of protection than those in poorer regions.
- The passage of the Tribunals Reforms Act in August 2021 should help to speed up the judicial process in commercial disputes. For example, the law has abolished the appellate boards under the 1957 Copyright Act, the 1970 Patents Act and the 1999 Trade Marks Act, transferring these functions to either the High Court, or its Commercial Division, or to the Commercial Court. The competitive environment should also be enhanced following the government's decision in February 2021 to amend the Companies Rules, paving the way for non-resident Indians to establish single-person companies. Moreover, amendments to what constitutes a small business should reduce the compliance burden; annual turnover can now rise to as high as Rs200m (US$2.5m), up from Rs20m, for these companies to be classified thus and to receive policy benefits directed to micro, small and medium-sized enterprises.
- Market-friendly reforms are likely to face resistance from vested interest groups, like the agriculture sector reforms, which were rolled back in 2021. However, we believe that the government's strong mandate will encourage controversial reforms on land and agriculture to be taken up after parliamentary elections in 2024.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
5.5 6.0 62 57 14 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India's score for policy towards foreign investment improves to 6 in 2022-26, from 5.5 in 2017-21, pushing the country up to 57th and 11th respectively in the global and regional rankings (from 62nd and 14th). The improvement is driven by friendlier government policy towards foreign capital. The NDA government, led by the BJP, has pursued gradual liberalisation of the foreign-investment regime since 2014. Nevertheless, some important sectors of the economy, such as multi-brand retail, banking, pensions and media, will remain subject to hard foreign direct investment (FDI) caps and/or more onerous approval processes. Discrimination and restrictions against investment from China will persist for the next few years, as India strives to shield the domestic market from Chinese influence, amid strategic competition in the region. Overall, the country's investment appeal remains strong.
Foreign direct investment will grow beyond traditional sectors
- The government will seek to give added impetus to its "Make in India" campaign and the "self-reliant India" initiative, which seek to boost local manufacturing in 2022-26. Its primary tool will be the production-linked incentives introduced at the height of the pandemic in 2020. Nearly Rs2trn (US$25bn) in funds has been allocated to this initiative by 2025, targeting 14 sectors including medical devices, consumer electronics and white goods. In 2022 the government has widened the Production Linked Incentive (PLI) outreach to solar modules and semiconductors. Overall, this scheme, which provides monetary incentives for incremental sales of domestically produced goods, should complement the temporary cut in corporate tax rates introduced in 2019 for newly established manufacturing companies, as long as they started operations before March 2023. The impact of these initiatives on the economy will only be visible towards the end of our forecast period, owing in part to continued problems with the business environment in areas such as land acquisition, and intense competition for FDI from emerging markets in South-east Asia, especially for companies looking to shift operations out of China.
- We expect the e-commerce market to attract a considerable amount of FDI over the forecast period as US and European firms vie to establish a presence. The Reliance Jio platform, with more than 430m subscribers, will prove particularly attractive for foreign firms by offering a simpler way to operate in the Indian online technology market.

PLI schemes have garnered investment across multiple sectors
- Chinese investors used to participate actively in Indian internet start-ups. However, structural tensions between China and India will significantly reduce the former's presence. More broadly, the requirement introduced in 2020 for any investor from a bordering country to seek the government's approval for any investment, regardless of size and sector, was aimed ostensibly at blocking Chinese FDI. In practice, the stricter requirements have slowed, rather than stopped altogether, Chinese capital from flowing in. A Right to Information request lodged in July 2022 found that the authorities have approved 80 out of 382 proposals from Chinese investors since the new entry process was introduced in mid-2020. Nonetheless, long-standing tensions at the country's disputed border with China will ensure a continuation of this nationalistic posture, which has also included a ban on companies from border countries bidding on public contracts.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
5.5 7.3 69 57 15 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Import controls will ease as bilateral trade agreements are ratified The score for foreign trade and exchange controls improves substantially from 5.5 in the historical period to 7.3 in 2022-26, driving up India's global ranking by 12 spots to 57th, while its regional position rises by two places, to 13th. This progress is due to improvements in trade-related bureaucracy and mild deregulation of capital-account restrictions. In recent years the government has lowered an array of export subsidies and harmonised them under general schemes for goods and services. It has also invested in infrastructure; reduced costs through greater use of online platforms; permitted the electronic submission of documents with digital signatures; and allowed exporters to self-seal their containers using radio frequency identification (RFID) technology. These measures form part of a broader effort to stimulate exports through supply-side reforms that are intended to boost the competitiveness of Indian exporters. However, tariff and non-tariff barriers have remained high in India, due in part to the country's reluctance to participate in regional free-trade agreements (FTA), as well as the strength of India's domestic business lobby. We expect the government to continue to sanction tariffs on selected manufactured goods in the coming years to promote domestic production. This will also encompass imports of military equipment, as several previously imported items (including ammunitions) have been put on the negative import list in 2022 to ensure a phased ban.

- Over 2022 India has met some success in strengthening bilateral trade relations with a number of countries. India and the UAE signed a comprehensive economic partnership agreement (CEPA) in February 2022, providing duty-free access for 90% of India's exports to the UAE and 65% of the UAE's exports to India, with further widening over the next decade. An interim agreement, the Australia-India Economic Co-operation and Trade Agreement, was signed in April 2022, while a final agreement is likely to be reached by early 2023 with a particular focus on strengthening trade in critical rare earth minerals.
- India and the EU relaunched the first round of formal free-trade negotiations in June 2022 after a hiatus of nine years. We believe that a diluted form of the deal is likely to be concluded over 2025-26, with negotiations continuing on other areas beyond that period A preliminary trade deal with the UK is expected to be completed by the end of 2022, paving the way for a broader FTA in 2023. Trade relations with the US will expand into the realm of defence acquisitions by India, and we expect India to be included in the US Generalised System of Preferences within the forecast period. A more limited trade deal focusing on sectors of major strategic interest, such as steel for India, seems likely from talks with the US.
- In July 2022 the RBI enacted a major structural reform to enable international trade to be settled in rupee instead of the traditional US dollar-denominated trade. However, the internationalisation of the rupee will take time, and is unlikely to make significant strides in 2022-26. Nevertheless, Indian exporters and importers will now have a mechanism to receive and make payments in rupee, militating against exchange-rate risks.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
4.5 6.1 78 52 16 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The corporate taxation regime will be stable and predictable India's score for taxes improves markedly to 6.1 in 2022-26, from 4.5 in 2017-21. This increase moves the country up to 52nd globally and 13th regionally, from its previous rank of 78th and 16th respectively. The higher score will be based on more generous fiscal incentives for investment, and a fairer and more seamless tax system, albeit from a relatively weak starting point. Although the government lowered corporate income tax rates substantially for domestic firms in 2019, the government also offers a lower 22% opt-in tax, down from the standard rate of 30%, to eligible firms that choose not to avail certain deductions. Meanwhile, a much lower 15% rate was introduced for newly established companies in the manufacturing sector. This followed a major reform in 2017, when the nationwide goods and services tax (GST) was introduced, replacing a slew of indirect central and state taxes and marked a significant step towards the creation of a single national market. Since its introduction, the GST Council (a group of ministers authorised to monitor and amend the tax) has taken measures to simplify the tax and streamline rates. In the latter half of the forecast period there will be additional impetus to widen the tax net by means such as increasing the capacity of the tax authorities, simplifying administration and clamping down on evasion.

- Collections from GST have been robust over 2020-21 despite the pandemic, and we expect this trend to improve further over 2022-26. The government will continue to rationalise GST rates and bring more items into lower tax brackets (although multiple tax slabs will remain in place). The inverted duty structure will also be corrected, wherein inputs are taxed at a higher rate than the final good or service. Several key items, including alcoholic drinks and petroleum products, will remain outside the GST net, as petrol duty remains vital for state public finance. Unpredictability will remain an issue, though, as rates are tweaked to cater for the current demands of the economy.
- Foreign companies are likely to have significantly more confidence in investing in India in the forecast period, following the passage in August 2021 of the Taxation Laws (Amendment) Act. This essentially abolished the risk of retrospective taxation for transfers of domestic assets, a real issue that has pitted the authorities for years against Cairn, a British oil and gas company, and Vodafone, a British telecommunications firm. Both of these disputes have since been settled.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
5.1 6.3 59 50 13 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Debt markets will open up for foreigners with bond index inclusion The score for financing improves from 5.1 in 2017-21 to 6.3 in 2022-26 as the quality of the financial regulatory system strengthens, and foreign investors gain deeper access into India's capital markets, and as access to investment finance improves. Accordingly, the country's global rank will improve by nine spots, to 50th, while it will rise by three places in Asia, to 10th. By definition, the government-guaranteed loans introduced during the covid-19 crisis in 2020 should not affect banks if they turn sour. However, if enough of them end up as non-performing loans (NPLs), the authorities' ability to fulfil those guarantees would be tested, given its-substantial budget deficit. In the most recent edition of the RBI's twice-yearly Financial Stability Report, published in June 2022, gross NPL ratio for commercial banks fell to a six-year low of 5.9% in March 2022. The proposed "bad bank", the National Asset Reconstruction Company, will facilitate the handling of non-performing assets accumulated by the public-sector banks.

- The pool of savings that can be channelled towards investment should improve in the forecast period, with the passage of the Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation (Amendment) Act in August 2021. The changes aim to ensure that depositors receive up to Rs500,000 (US$6290) within three months after the RBI withdraws the license of a troubled lender, up from a previous guarantee of Rs100,000. The minister for finance, Nirmala Sitharaman, has revealed that following the approval of the changes in 2021, it currently takes up to ten years for depositors to get back their funds, only after the bank is fully liquidated.
- We expect financial regulation in India to improve throughout the forecast period. However, the insolvency law will be amended: as court cases involving the insolvency law are decided, they will set precedents that could underline the effectiveness of the law. Better bad-loan provisioning and stricter regulation will support an improvement in the sector's health towards the latter part of our forecast period, improving the availability of financing.
- Public-sector lenders will continue to account for the bulk of total lending, especially in rural areas. We believe that amid deterioration in asset quality due to the covid-19 pandemic, further bank recapitalisation will be necessary. This will prove politically and fiscally challenging, weighing on the ability of banks to fund private-sector credit growth. Privatisation of state-owned banks will help on this front, though progress on sales is likely to be sluggish in the early part of the forecast period.
- Priority-sector lending (minimum mandated lending to specific sectors aimed at achieving socio-developmental objectives) will remain a feature of government policy throughout the forecast period. Indian commercial banks and foreign lenders with more than 20 branches in the country are currently required to provide 40% of their net bank credit to priority sectors, which include agriculture, housing and renewable energy.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
5.4 6.6 61 37 15 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India's score for the labour market will strengthen materially to 6.6 in 2022-26, from 5.4 in the historical period, moving the country up to 37th globally and 9th regionally, from its previous rank of 61st and 15th respectively. The improvement will be based on some relaxations in the country's strict labour laws, a general enhancement in the level of skills and the health of the workforce, as well as an improvement in wage levels. Progress on the liberalisation, simplification and harmonisation of labour laws is likely in 2022-26, given the passage of four new labour codes in 2020. That said, their benefits will only become apparent in the latter part of the forecast period. Progress will also be inhibited by opposition from trade unions (including those affiliated with the BJP).
Participation of women in the labour force will remain constrained
- The government completed the passage of four labour laws in 2020, on wages, social security, health and safety and industrial relations. Although they have yet to be implemented, their potential impact on the business environment is substantial. They will serve to consolidate around 75% of 40 central government laws that currently deal with the labour market. Firms will still have to navigate state-level legislation, as labour is within the list of responsibilities shared by both centre and local authorities. However, the four codes will establish a standard baseline for states to adhere to. One of the biggest areas of liberalisation is in the industrial relations laws, which will raise the threshold at which companies need government's approval before laying off staff. Colonial era rules markedly reduced the incentives for firms to grow beyond the current threshold of 100 workers.
- The government's skilling programmes to upskill the workforce will improve the quality of workers available. However, the sub-par level of primary education will hamper a swift improvement. The migration of qualified Indians to the West will also create a skills gap. However, the workforce will be far more productive than those in other South Asian countries.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
3.8 5.5 70 59 13 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Infrastructure creation will focus on roads, ports and power India's score for infrastructure improves markedly in the forecast period, albeit from a low base, to 5.5 from 3.8 in 2017-21. This will be enough to move the country up into the top 60 globally, while its regional position will rise two spots, to 11th. The improvement will be broad-based, but it will be driven in particular by faster broadband speeds and more adequate transport infrastructure, in terms of rail, air travel, ports, and road networks. Power supply should also be more reliable in 2022-26. Infrastructure improvements and expansion remain key priorities for the NDA government. We expect the bulk of public investment to be diverted to transport, energy and urban improvement projects. However, the pace of progress on projects that are already under way will remain constrained by slow land acquisition and delays in regulatory clearances (particularly environmental approvals).
The budget for 2022/23 lays out a substantial capital expenditure of Rs7.5trn, with spending geared towards important areas such as defence equipment, atomic energy, telecoms, metro rail projects, railway infrastructure, affordable healthcare and the National Investment and Infrastructure Fund (an investment fund created by the government in 2015 to invest in infrastructure).

- Infrastructure will remain a priority in the government's spending mix over 2022-26. The budget for 2021/22 included Rs200bn to establish a dedicated financial institution-the National Bank for Financing Infrastructure and Development-to spur construction activity. This institution started operations in 2022/23, and will eventually be bestowed with a Rs1trn lending facility. Ministries responsible for roads and railways have received record allocations in recent budgets, underscoring the government's commitment to boost interstate connectivity. Delays are likely to continue, but, once finished, these initiatives will bolster domestic goods and labour flows.
- India will make improvements in enhancing internet speed as well as connectivity. According to the International Telecommunication Union, the percentage of the population using the internet had risen to 43% by 2020 (the latest available data) from just 8% a decade earlier. The disparity is significant between rural and urban India, and the number of internet users in urban India rose by 4% to 323m in 2020, accounting for 67% of the urban population, while rural penetration remains much lower, although it is growing.

Infrastructure development will continue to be led by the government
- Progress on urban civic infrastructure projects, such as water supply, will be hindered by inadequate private-sector involvement. The limited returns on investment in these sectors mean that official efforts to draw in private-sector participation will struggle. The private sector will focus instead on areas that promise faster returns, such as airport construction, and there will be significant progress in these areas in 2022-26. In general, demand for infrastructure will continue to exceed supply by a significant margin in the forecast period.
- Two publicly funded connectivity projects, Bharatmala (road construction) and Sagarmala (port construction), will continue to be prioritised. The first phase of Bharatmala is aimed at connecting 550 of the country's districts through the highways network, from only 300 in 2017. The government plans to build highways totalling 18,000 km over 2022/23. A lack of capital investment constrains the expansion of railways capacity, but we expect it to pick up mildly over the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26 2017-21 2022-26
5.2 6.1 59 53 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Research and development will remain focal areas in India India scores respectably for technological readiness, improving from 5.2 in 2017-21 to 6.1 in the forecast period, because of a more conducive environment for e-commerce and an enhancement of information technology-ready government services. Accordingly, the country's global ranking will rise by six places to 53rd in 2022-26, while it will remain at 11th regionally. The country boasts a relatively advanced R&D infrastructure, owing in part to the education system's historical bias towards higher education institutions. This has facilitated the development of relatively research-intensive sectors such as pharmaceuticals and technology. India has also been an enthusiastic adopter of e-government systems, seeking to improve the effectiveness of public service delivery and reduce corruption, as made evident by the Aadhar biometric identity cards.

- We expect that the launch of 5G networks will contribute to higher internet speeds in urban areas from 2023. Bharti Airtel is expected to start 5G services in India by the end of 2022, while Reliance Jio is also on track to roll out its 5G network. India lags in terms of fixed broadband and mobile internet speed. According to the Speedtest Global Index, India ranked 72nd out of 182 countries in June 2022 for fixed broadband connectivity speed. Its ranking on mobile internet speed was poor, coming in at 118th place out of 139 countries. Charges for telecoms and internet services are low, making them broadly affordable for even the poorer households. The government's flagship Bharat Net project seeks to provide connectivity to 0.25m villages through optical fibre. The finance minister, Ms Sitharaman, clarified in February 2022 that the contracts for laying optical fibre connections in rural and remote areas would be awarded in 2022 and completed by 2025.

E-commerce is changing the face of India's retail business
- E-commerce has become the focal point of India's digital revolution, owing to factors such as a growing middle class, the availability of relatively cheap mobile connections and skilled labour to develop indigenous technology platforms. According to Indian Brand Equity Foundation, the Indian e-commerce market is expected to reach US$111bn by 2024 and US$200bn by 2026. Structural changes in spending behaviour prompted by the pandemic are likely to hasten the uptake of e-commerce, particularly in retail. The development of online commerce will also be facilitated by the government's Bharat-Net programme. The government's restrictions on e-commerce businesses will remain in place over 2022-26 to protect small brick and-mortar businesses, and policies in this space could be unpredictable, as this is a novel domain. Broadly, e-commerce will continue to expand in India, given the potential of the country's large and rapidly growing consumer class.
- India will leverage the technological ecosystem provided by Aadhar biometric identity cards in 2022-26. Aadhar provides residents with a unique identification number through a link with their biometric data. We expect that the system will allow both the government and the private sector to deliver official services, such as the transfer of benefits, more efficiently. However, it is also likely to face public scrutiny, amid privacy concerns.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The government will prioritise fostering a sustained economic recovery in 2022. Infrastructure development will remain the government's focus. This will encompass the creation and upgrade of ports, logistics parks, roads and railway networks. Costs of logistics will gradually decline over the forecast period, with major roads, highways and freight corridors due for completion in 2022-23. India is also likely to make progress towards its climate goals.
The liberalisation of land-acquisition laws will be an area of attention for the improvement of the business environment, but any major progress in this area is unlikely before the national election in 2024, as it might provoke widespread protests from the farming community. The government has also revamped the military recruitment scheme in June, meaning that most hiring will now be made without pensions and subsidies, saving on personnel costs and freeing up resources for the upgrading of military equipment. The administration will make piecemeal changes to legislation related to commerce and regulatory requirements. EIU expects the government to be moderately successful in privatising state-owned enterprises (SOEs), even as it faces lukewarm interest from the private sector.

In May 2022 the government reduced duties on petrol and diesel to mitigate the impact of spiralling consumer price inflation. The government also increased its budgeted fertiliser subsidy (which forms about 3% of total expenditure) by Rs1.1trn (US$14.1bn) amid a sharp increase in global prices for fertilisers. This was in line with our expectation of subsidy relief to ameliorate hardship for the electorally important farming population.
The budget for fiscal year 2022/23 (April-March) strives to improve the quality of government expenditure, with a focus on significant capital spending geared towards defence, energy, telecommunications, transport and infrastructure. However, lower duties on fuel and increased fertiliser subsidies will cost the exchequer an additional Rs2trn. The rate of a windfall tax for petroleum companies was cut on July 20th, shortly after its introduction on July 1st. We expect the government to modestly cut back on some capital expenditure on infrastructure to partially compensate for the cost of subsidies. However, the shortfall will remain and stand at an equivalent of 6.5% of GDP.
Expenditure commitments will remain elevated in 2023/24, owing to spending related to the national election, resulting in only a modest fiscal consolidation. The government will attempt to consolidate the public finances more quickly after the election, resulting in the budget deficit narrowing to 4.5% of GDP in 2026/27. This will also be helped by measures to widen the tax net and strengthened compliance norms. Rising interest rates will raise the costs of debt servicing, and public debt will remain significant, averaging 58.6% of GDP in the forecast period. Most of this will still be held domestically, reducing currency risks associated with external debt repayment. However, the federal fiscal picture does not reflect the true size of the deficit: the states' deficits and the liabilities of public-sector units represent an implicit fiscal burden on the central government.

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) undertook an off-schedule rate increase of 40 basis points in May, followed by a raise of 50 basis points at its scheduled meeting in June, to rein in persistent inflationary pressures. Inflation concerns, as well as aggressive monetary policy tightening by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) and consequent large portfolio investment outflows from India will influence the central bank's decision as the interest-rate differential with the US narrows. We expect the RBI to raise the policy rate by a total of 160 basis points in 2022.
We expect rates to be raised by 25 basis points in 2023, as consumer price inflation will remain high, albeit moderating from 2022. In 2024-25 the RBI, prompted by domestic elections, will switch to cutting policy rates, totalling 50 basis points, to support the domestic economy. This will bring the repo rate to 6% at the end of the tightening cycle at end-2023. Following cuts would bring the repo rate to 5.5% in end-2026, which is not high by historical standards.

Real GDP is expected to grow by 6.9% in year-on-year terms in 2022/23, slowing from 8.8% in 2021/22. Growth will benefit from the release of pent-up demand for contact-based services, especially in the context of recovered mobility. This has improved business confidence, while strong corporate earnings over the past few quarters will spur investment in sectors such as transport, information technology and pharmaceuticals. A favourable monsoon and better terms of trade for food will support rural incomes and consumption. Low inventories will keep construction momentum strong, especially for commercial real estate. Despite persistent rate increases over 2022, policy rates will remain low by historical standards, and we expect that financing conditions will remain low and are unlikely to deter a recovery in investment until late 2022. The government's capital spending budget will support infrastructure investment.
Factors that will weigh on growth in 2022/23 include a surge in raw material prices squeezing the profit margins of manufacturers and service providers. The pass-through of these higher prices to consumers will raise inflation and erode household purchasing power. Slower global growth over 2022 also means lower external demand for India's exports.
In the medium term, the privatisation of SOEs and progress on structural reforms, such as changes to the labour laws and strengthening performance of the manufacturing subsectors under investment incentive schemes, will provide support for economic growth. Nevertheless, the weakening of household and corporate balance sheets due to the pandemic and inflationary pressures, along with the government's attempts to limit expenditure growth to consolidate the fiscal account, will weigh on expansion. We expect economic growth in 2023/24-2026/27 to average 5% per year-slower than the annual average of 6.7% in 2015/16-2019/20.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends The rate of economic recovery has been faster in urban areas than rural areas over 2021 and 2022, as urban income streams were less disrupted by the pandemic than their rural counterpart. We expect agriculture, which is a major rural occupation to gradually become less important in contributing to growth as the economy moves up the value chain and productivity improves. However, the primary sector will continue to employ around half of the population, and its share in GDP will contract only modestly from 15.5% of GDP in 2021/22 to 14.7% of GDP by 2026/27. Although the reform to liberalise the marketing of agriculture produce and create self-sufficiency introduced in 2020 was rolled back amid protests in 2021, we believe that it will be reintroduced in a more acceptable format after 2024, and will support the outlook for the agriculture sector. As employment opportunities open up in the secondary and tertiary sectors, there will be a gradual shift in employment away from agriculture.
Agriculture will remain dependent on the vagaries of monsoon rainfall There is significant scope for investment to enhance agricultural productivity, as almost half of all cultivable land remains without irrigation cover, and is dependent on annual monsoon rainfall, rendering the sector vulnerable to poor or unevenly distributed rains. The government has recognised this, and has increased funding for irrigation schemes and crop insurance. However, capital investment into agriculture will remain inadequate, and the bulk of public funding will continue to come in the form of short-term grants and subsidies aimed at securing political support from farmers, who form an important vote bank. Income from agriculture will remain meagre, as subsistence farming will continue to be predominant. We forecast that the agriculture sector will grow by an annual average of 3.9% in2022/23-2026/27.
Manufacturing will gain traction as industries set up base in India The industrial sector will expand at a robust pace, as the business environment improves and the country's strong economic growth outlook attracts investment. We expect the sector to grow by an average of 5.7% per year in the forecast period, and that the share of industry in total GDP will increase slightly from 30.8% in 2021/22 to 31.9% in 2026/27. Manufacturing will remain concentrated in a few sectors such as cars, processed foods, engineering goods and garments in the early part of the forecast period, rendering it moderately vulnerable to swings in household and external demand. Government efforts to lift manufacturing employment and output will be effective in the latter part of the forecast horizon through initiatives such as product-linked incentives (targeting new investments in emerging sectors such as electronics, pharmaceuticals, consumer durables and semiconductors) and the administration's special economic zone strategy, which aims to develop manufacturing hubs throughout the country. Some of the manufacturing capabilities relocating out of China will set up base in India amid low input costs. Persistently rising foreign direct investment (FDI) will be channelled to manufacturing sectors, as some liberalisation of the laws governing land acquisition and the labour regime (especially local sourcing) will help to underpin growth in the sector. Policy continuity will also bolster confidence in foreign investor sentiment. However, India's absence from major regional trade blocs will impede streamlined export productivity.
Services like travel, hospitality and domestic trade will continue to flourish Accounting for 53.7% of GDP in 2021/22, the services sector will remain the primary engine of economic expansion over 2022/23-2026/27. The sector has recovered strongly, albeit unevenly, from the severe disruption caused by the pandemic, and has shown itself to be resilient and not dependent on buoyancy in external markets. Its expansion will continue to be driven by already strong areas of activity such as telecommunications and business services, as well as by services in numerous high potential but currently underserved areas, including healthcare, retailing, hospitality and education. Information technology (IT) and IT-enabled services will remain a major source of export revenue, even as growth will face increased competition from countries such as the Philippines. We expect the services sector to expand by an annual average of 5.7%; its share of GDP will rise to 55.7% by 2026/27.

We forecast consumer price inflation to accelerate to 7.3% in 2022, from 5.1% in 2021. Higher commodity prices in the wake of the Ukraine crisis will be passed on to consumers as the recovery in demand becomes more broad-based. Increased demand for discretionary services such as travel and recreation will create price pressures as well. Although the duty reduction on retail fuels will modestly cool transport price inflation over the next six months, increased demand for transport (due to the reopening of the economy) will mitigate that reduction to some extent. Although the monsoon season is expected to help to deliver a good harvest, this will cool food price pressures only in the last quarter of 2022. In the interim, the prices of perishable foods are expected to rise, while imported food inflation will rise through the channels of pulses and edible oil.
Consumer price inflation is expected to average 4.4% in 2023-26, near the midpoint of the RBI's 2-6% target band. Moderate economic growth over this period will reduce demand-side inflationary pressure. Supply-chain efficiency is also expected to improve, with improved logistics infrastructure. Given heavy reliance on seasonal rains for irrigation, a bad monsoon (which is not part of our forecast) would trigger a surge in food prices.
We forecast that producer price inflation will reach 15.5% in 2022, accelerating from 10.8% in 2021. This relates to high input costs generated by robust commodity prices and supply disruption. Producer price inflation will average 6.1% in 2023-26.

Economic forecast: Exchange rates   2021 2022 2023 2024 2025 2026

Purchasing power parity Rs:US$ (av) 23.20 23.05 23.10 23.27 23.46 23.63
The Indian rupee depreciated by 5.5% nominally against the US dollar between January and June 2022, reflecting a narrowing interest-rate differential with the US and geopolitical contagion from the Ukraine war, which has reduced the appetite for emerging-market assets. The RBI has consequently intervened heavily to slow the depreciation of the rupee by selling its foreign-exchange reserves. This is likely to continue, with the central bank defending the rupee against a stronger depreciation, and we believe that the RBI has enough reserves to defend the currency over much of 2022 without concern over import payments or the repayment of external debt. Some support for the currency will come from robust economic performance, as well as significant policy rate increases by the RBI. Overall, we expect the rupee to depreciate in nominal terms against the US dollar by 6.5% on average in 2022, with the currency standing at Rs81.4:US$1 at the end of the year, compared with Rs74.3:US$1 at end-2021.
We forecast that the rate differential with the US and a persistent current-account deficit will keep the local currency on a depreciatory trend. We expect the rupee to depreciate gradually between 2023 and 2026, moving from an annual average of Rs82.4:US$1 to Rs87.5:US$1 over that period, as portfolio investment flows are depressed in part by more conservative monetary policy in developed markets.

We forecast that India's current-account deficit will widen to 1.5% of GDP in 2022, from 1.1% of GDP in 2021, driven by a larger merchandise trade deficit resulting from higher import prices and the strengthening of import demand. However, elevated local prices will also curtail import demand for discretionary consumption items such as electronics and gems/jewellery. Nonetheless, merchandise exports will remain robust, the pace of expansion will ease sharply in comparison with 2021, given slower growth in major export destinations such as the UAE, the US and China.
The services and secondary income accounts will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period as India maintains its status as a leading exporter of IT services and continues to receive robust financial inflows from overseas Indians. However, this will not be enough to counter the large deficit on merchandise trade. As a result, the current account will remain in deficit in 2023-26, averaging the equivalent of 123% of GDP.
Our forecast assumes that tariff and non-tariff barriers, as well as strategic import substitution through incentive schemes under the government's "self-reliant India" initiative, will partly depress the goods import bill. India will continue to prioritise bilateral trade though pacts with friendly nations such as the UAE, the UK and Australia, and will continue to focus on bilateral rather than regional trade agreements. The country's absence from regional trade alliances will impede the government's efforts to establish the country as an export-orientated manufacturing hub.
The Production Linked Incentive (PLI) scheme, rolled out by the government for the domestic manufacture of electronics, pharmaceuticals, batteries and solar panels (among other products), will attract inflows of foreign direct investment. The move to incentivise semiconductor production under the PLI will, in the medium term, alleviate reliance on Chinese imports. A push to upgrade national infrastructure, coupled with the size of the market and a modest increase in access, will also create opportunities for foreign investors.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in India Stocks and flows India's large market and growing economy make it a favourable destination for foreign investors. Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows into India have been strong in recent years, averaging US$48.4bn in 2017-21, compared with US$35bn in the previous five years. Owing to an attractive growth outlook and significant market opportunities, the stock of inward FDI has been expanding rapidly, standing at US$514.3bn in 2021 (markedly higher than in 2019, when it totalled US$427bn). The 2021 figure was also higher than the corresponding stock in Indonesia (US$259.3bn), but lower than in China (US$2trn).
Origin and distribution According to the Department of Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT), the largest source of FDI has historically been Mauritius, which accounted for 27% of FDI inflows between April 2000 and March 2022. (Many foreign companies investing in India are incorporated in Mauritius for tax reasons.) With a similar tax treaty and some of the lowest rates of taxation in Asia, Singapore stands in second place; the city state accounted for 22% of cumulative inflows in 2000-22. It was followed by the US (9%), the Netherlands (7%), Japan (6%) and the UK (5%). FDI inflows from the US and Singapore surpassed flows from Mauritius in 2021/22, amid improving interest in India. The most important sector for FDI is services, which attracted US$94.2bn between April 2000 and March 2022 and accounted for 16% of cumulative inflows, according to the DPIIT. The computer software and hardware sector is the second-largest recipient (14% of cumulative flows), attracting US$85.5bn in the same period. The state of Maharashtra (which boasts the country's financial centre, Mumbai) attracts most FDI, garnering 28% of the total between October 2019 and March 2022. This was followed by Karnataka and Gujarat in the same period.
Determinants India's skilled, English-speaking workforce has been a significant attraction for FDI, particularly in the information technology (IT) sector. Since taking office the current government has liberalised the FDI regime in a number of areas, including defence, pharmaceuticals, insurance and single-brand retailing. It also provides a product-linked incentive that offers financial compensation for direct investments in emerging sectors such as electronics. The current administration will continue to open up the economy to foreign investors. However, more minor bureaucratic restrictions are often left unaddressed. Although structural reforms will make headway, difficulty in acquiring land, rules on local sourcing and hiring and firing of employees has loosened considerably, though disparities exist among states, with western and southern states having more flexible rules. The slow legal system also acts as a deterrent to the inflow of investment and hampers the ease of conducting business in India for foreigners.
Impact FDI has had the greatest impact on India's software industry and IT-enabled services. Although call centres and other forms of back-office administration have been important industries, India is moving up the value chain. The financial, pharmaceutical, automobile, telecommunications and construction sectors have also been influenced significantly by FDI. The online retail sector has gained importance over the pandemic, with US-based Amazon and Walmart (through its Flipkart subsidiary) having a significant presence in the e-commerce sector. Many online start-ups have been able to attract attention from venture capitalists and internet giants in the West. However, in offline retail, a significant relaxation of regulations for multibrand retailers is unlikely to occur in 2022-26. The product-linked incentive will spur investment in the electronics sector, but the sector is unlikely to expand significantly into a new pillar industry.
Potential Given the size of its market and rapid economic growth, India is attracting a significant amount of FDI. However, the potential for even stronger inflows is reduced by relatively poor infrastructure, excessive bureaucracy and wrangling between government departments. The infrastructure, energy, telecoms, IT and insurance sectors are likely to be important areas for FDI in 2022-26. Biotechnology, electronics and vehicle manufacturing (including parts) could also attract significant interest over the next five years amid significant government support.

Population growth will slow as education rises and fertility rates fall EIU forecasts that the population will grow by an annual average of 0.8% in 2022-26, slightly slower than the 1% recorded in 2017-21. This marginal slowdown is linked to an improvement in living standards, urbanisation and economic conditions for women, which is depressing fertility rates. According to the latest National Family Health Survey (NFHS) conducted in 2019-21, India's overall fertility rate has fallen to two per woman, lower than the replacement rate of 2.1-a level that is usually viewed as sufficient to replace a whole generation or keep the population from declining without immigration. However, disparities exist among the states of India. The populations of poor and populous states will continue to grow strongly, adding to social and familial tensions and exerting further pressure on the already overloaded infrastructure.
In 2021 men outnumbered women by 55m, and this trend will persist over the forecast period. Recent research from the National Family Health Survey shows that the gender ratio of newborns is 929 girls per 1,000 boys for the country as a whole, showing that gender selection is skewed towards males in most parts of the country. The disproportionate gender ratio also spills over to educational attainment and workforce contribution, as these are more available to men than women. Government policies targeted towards women's education and employment have seen uneven uptake in rural belts, which remain conservative and prioritise males. We expect this disparity to gradually even out with increased education among women. However, the proportion of women in the workforce is expected to remain low over the decade, as concerns such as house work, caregiving, safety and low wages compared to their male counterparts prevent women from joining the labour force in large numbers.
Caste-centric policies will continue to be enacted by successive governments Caste factors will be another important source of social strain within India in 2022-26. All governments have traditionally been supportive of affirmative action policies that favour caste-based "reservations" (quotas) for jobs and public services such as education, which may help those in low-status castes, and this will continue. Caste groups (including higher-status castes) that do not currently enjoy special job quotas, especially in public-sector jobs, will push for them in the next five years. Notably, castes can also influence policy decisions; the agriculture reforms were rolled back in 2021 owing to opposition by higher-caste farmers, who form an important vote bank. Regardless of the government's policy approach, the ongoing trend of workers moving from conservative rural regions to more metropolitan urban areas will help to slowly weaken the roots of the caste system.
Growth in the working-age population will remain relatively strong, at 1.3% per year on average in 2022-26. However, unlocking the economic benefits of population growth will prove challenging. In the 1990s and 2000s China was able to transfer workers from agriculture to more productive work in the cities, thereby boosting economic growth and exports. However, India's manufacturing sector has failed to take off in a similar manner. The manufacturing sector in India boasts more success in capital-intensive industries than their labour-intensive counterparts. Although the manufacturing sector is set to grow, advancing automation, which the government strongly supports, is likely to hamper sufficient job creation. The workforce moving out of agriculture will be increasingly absorbed in services, although low-skilled workers will still be largely employed in agriculture or construction sectors.
Educational focus will move from the public to the private sector A main challenge for the country's long-term development is the poor state of primary-level education. While enrolment rates have risen, educational outcomes remain sub-par, especially in state-funded schools. This reflects multiple factors, including underqualified and irregular teachers, the impact of caste within the education system and bad infrastructure within schools. The situation has resulted in strong demand (even among poor households) for private education, including online courses. The gap between primary education in rural and urban areas widened during the pandemic as a lack of technological availability in rural areas hampered education continuity. As technology becomes increasingly important for educational outcomes, this gap will widen, while the quality of state-funded education will remain sub-par.
Weaknesses in other parts of the education system will also come to the fore as more students seek secondary and tertiary education. Few universities operate at world-class levels barring a few clusters of excellence, and more skilling initiatives will be needed to bridge the gap in employability.

Robust personal income will spur discretionary consumption EIU expects personal disposable income to exceed the levels recorded before the onset of the pandemic. India's huge population will become an increasingly important market for consumer goods. Household consumption expenditure will rise from US$1.9trn in 2021 to US$2.6trn by 2026. However, GDP per head (at market exchange rates) will remain low at just US$2,819 in 2026, compared with US$17,197 in China. This will limit the bulk of consumer spending to food and essential items, especially in rural areas. Discretionary consumption will remain more prevalent in urban areas, given a growing number of middle-class households and a desire to purchase premium products, which offers considerable potential for suppliers of higher-value products and services. The rapid growth in personal incomes from 2021, combined with a more open domestic market, will make India an increasingly attractive market for foreign companies. Significant regional economic disparities exist, and the levels of opportunity for retail businesses will vary greatly across the country in the forecast period.
Opportunities for e-commerce will grow rapidly in urban areas, owing to their increasingly well-educated populations and the growing penetration of broadband and smartphones. Foreign firms are positioning themselves to take advantage of this trend. Assuming that the economy maintains its solid growth path in 2022-26, and as internet and logistics availability rises, e-commerce will claim more of the country's consumer market, creating opportunities for both domestic and foreign firms. Nevertheless, regulation will provide some obstacles to their competitive capacity. The administration has imposed strict restrictions on retail-related e-commerce businesses to protect the interests of small brick-and-mortar businesses, as well as domestic e-commerce businesses. However, foreign companies see these measures as discriminatory, and the government will come under pressure to revise them in 2022-26.
Urban consumers tend to display more brand loyalty, especially to high-end brands, than their rural counterparts and value loyalty programmes. For most Indians, price will remain the main determinant of the level of demand. Companies in the fast-moving consumer goods sector tend to address affordability by offering products in smaller sizes. This practice serves as a way to develop brand loyalty among new consumers.

As in most developing countries, food constitutes by far the largest category of consumer expenditure. However, spending on food as a percentage of income will consistently fall in 2022-26, as improving income allows more spending beyond food items. Spending on transport and communications will increase as mobility around India improves. The relatively poor state of government-provided services means that as Indians become richer, they will spend an increasing amount on private education.
Regional and cultural divergences will drive different consumption trends Several factors other than income must be weighed carefully when assessing prospects in the Indian market. First, purchasing power is as location-specific as it is income-sensitive, and prices can vary considerably from city to city as well as between urban and rural areas. Second, cultural factors matter to a significant degree. Third, Indian consumers, including those who are moving up the income scale, are highly price-conscious. Fourth, it is important to note that there is hardly a single consumer characteristic that applies across the entire country. India is a collection of widely varying markets, necessitating region-specific strategies. Finally, the steady expansion of consumer finance options will increase the willingness of consumers to purchase in the forecast period.

Initial conditions: The Indian economy began to move away from a state directed socialist model in the early 1990s, when a balance-of-payments crisis triggered the first round of economic reform and market liberalisation. Since then, India's GDP has expanded rapidly, with annual real GDP growth averaging 6.3% in fiscal years 1991/92-2021/22 (April-March). However, India's share of world GDP (at market exchange rates) remains low, at around 3.4% in 2021, compared with its 19% share of the world's population. This highlights significant scope for further economic development. Low average productivity in India remains a key reason for widespread poverty. The gap in productivity between the agriculture sector and high-growth industries such as information technology (IT) is vast. Corruption is still endemic in local authorities, despite the fact that attempts to reduce graft have made progress at the higher levels of government under the Bharatiya Janata Party (which has led the ruling coalition since 2014). India's courts have long suffered from crippling understaffing, and a case backlog has built up over decades. The judiciary remains largely independent despite some pressure from the government.
Automation will dampen employment opportunities to a certain extent Demographic trends: Continued growth in the working-age population over 2022-50 will support India's economic expansion. However, even as the economy grows, a large proportion of the workforce will not find employment in productive formal-sector jobs. A mismatch between the skill level of the country's workers and the demand for highly educated staff from employers will persist for at least the next two decades, as the quality of education provided by the government (on which a large portion of the population depends) and vocational training systems remain poor. Meanwhile, the rise of automation and growing use of artificial intelligence will dampen employment gains, even as India-based enterprises capture a larger market share of global manufacturing. Reaping the demographic dividend will prove difficult in this environment. EIU expects the vast majority of the workforce to be absorbed in low-productivity occupations in the urban services sector and the agricultural sector in 2022-50. Still, opportunities for better-educated Indians will proliferate amid rapid growth in professional services, manufacturing and high-technology areas such as telecommunications, IT and pharmaceuticals.
Persistent rural to urban migration will pressure infrastructure and resources Divergence in economic fortunes within the country will result in strong pressure for Indians from poorer states to move into more prosperous areas. In the absence of major improvements in governance, states such as Uttar Pradesh and Bihar will be a source of internal migrants, putting pressure on scarce resources in more prosperous and economically dynamic cities such as the capital, New Delhi, and the financial hub, Mumbai. Although there is divergence in fertility rates among states, fertility rates have dropped below two (the replacement level) in 2021 for all states but five in India, according to the National Family Health Survey. Therefore, population growth will slow, gradually alleviating pressure on scarce resources, athough this will only happen over the next two decades Significant levels of internal migration will be a source of political and social tensions. Meanwhile, workers will continue to look abroad for economic opportunities, with lower-skilled workers preferring the Gulf region, while skilled workers will migrate to the US and Canada. The migration of skilled workers will cause a "brain drain" that hampers the growth of India's high-technology sectors. Inflows from their remittances over the next few decades will be an important driver of economic activity in some states.
India's strategic power will grow consistently, wielding regional influence External conditions: As its economy expands, India will become an increasingly important diplomatic, military and economic power. Successive governments will seek to ensure India's primacy within South Asia and to cultivate ties with regional neighbours-excluding Pakistan, India's long-standing rival and China, with which India shares a border dispute. We expect India's relationship with Pakistan to remain tense, as the two countries will struggle to reconcile political and strategic differences, especially on the issue of Jammu and Kashmir. Temporary bouts of high tension are likely. However, the growth differential between India and Pakistan will remain high, and India's military advantage over its rival will increase. Over time, this should deter Pakistan from initiating overt conflict, although that country will resort to terrorism attacks, which will provoke a strong covert or overt military response from India. China's presence in South Asia (especially in Pakistan) will push India towards adopting a more defensive posture to shield its domestic market from China. Shared strategic and economic interests will bind India more closely to the members of the Quad (an informal diplomatic grouping between the US, Japan, Australia and India), most notably Japan and the US. India will also prioritise groupings initiated by the US, such as the I2U2 group comprising India, Israel, the UAE and the US, while simultaneously reducing its participation in China-inclusive blocs like BRICS, which comprises Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa. Still, even as it becomes a major diplomatic power, India will remain hesitant to align itself fully with the West. This is partially related to India's traditionally strong relationship with Russia, which has been a major source of military equipment. Long-standing links with the Gulf region and Africa and deepening investment ties will provide India with the opportunity to expand its political, economic and cultural engagement in these regions over the period to 2050. India will share strong bilateral strategic and economic relations with most nations despite not aligning or engaging in multilateral trade blocs over the longer term.
States in the west and south will perform better on all parameters Institutions and policy trends: Political power will be centralised under the current prime minister, Narendra Modi, in the 2020s, although regional parties will emerge as dominant players in the policy space, especially on matters over which states have the final say in legislation. Differences in policy approach at state level will have a significant impact on economic outcomes. Reform-minded states will see growth accelerate, while poorer states will demand increased funds from the central government to balance economic disparities. Despite state-level differences, India's democratic political system will remain firmly entrenched. The country's legal system will generally remain impartial (but slow) and the constitution will be respected (apart from a trend away from secularism, which is likely to dim after Mr Modi leaves office). Pledged reforms on labour law and land acquisition will make progress in 2021-30. India's integration into regional and global value chains will nonetheless be constrained by a lingering tendency towards protectionism. New technologies and the emergence of an increasingly vocal middle class will help the authorities to curb graft, particularly at the local level.
Technology adoption and reforms will keep the growth trajectory robust Long-term performance: We forecast that India's real GDP growth will average 5.1% per year in 2022-50. The country's economic progress is premised on a shift up the value chain in IT, manufacturing, business and information services, as well as other sectors. Continued government-led investment to upgrade infrastructure will improve the business environment and help to enhance the economy's performance. Improvements in the adoption of technology and greater supply-chain efficiency in the agricultural sector will make rural India more resilient to climate change. A stronger agricultural sector and declining fertility rates will partly temper the movement of people from rural to urban areas, and the urban population will overtake its rural counterpart only by the middle of this century. However, the shift of the workforce from rural labour into more productive urban jobs will remain the leading driver of India's economic expansion in the period to 2050. One major concern over the country's long-term economic performance is the extent to which the government can manage this transition. Upgrading the quality of public education will be crucial if the government is to achieve this successfully. We expect gradual progress on this front in the decades ahead; this will enable the expansion of the manufacturing sector, which will be crucial to India's medium-term growth prospects. A gradual improvement in the quality of education will also lay the groundwork for the development of the higher-value-added sectors that will be necessary to sustain the country's growth momentum in the longer term. A much faster pace of improvement in education and much deeper reforms in business regulations would produce a more significant level of economic growth over the long term; however, this is not part of our central forecast, and the economy will thus expand at a slower pace than its long-term growth potential.
